column1: Victoria Police criticised for extra police presence during inquest into Aboriginal death

column1: Spectacular delivery of extra Chinooks, as ADF's newest helicopters remain grounded
column2: Australia is purchasing more of the tried and tested aerial workhorses from the US, with two delivered ahead of major war games.

column1: Taliban fighters enter capital of north-western Afghan province, briefly take over police headquarters
column2: Taliban insurgents have stormed the capital of Afghanistan's north-western Badghis province, briefly taking over police headquarters and sparking panic among local people.

column1: What's more powerful than a supernova? The event that created this ancient star
column2: Scientists discover an ancient star formed from an explosion 10 times more powerful than a supernova.

column1: 'Censored': Chinese LGBT groups accuse WeChat of deleting their accounts
column2: Chinese LGBT groups accuse social media company WeChat of censoring their content online without warning, as the country's cyberspace watchdog promises to crack down on social media groups deemed a "bad influence".

column1: Ever Given container ship freed from Suez Canal after compensation deal reached
column2: A settlement deal is signed, allowing the shipping vessel that blocked the crucial east-west waterway to finally be released.

column1: Australia to send 2.5 million AstraZeneca vaccine doses to Indonesia and offers emergency aid as COVID-19 crisis deepens
column2: Australia will dip into its domestic vaccine stockpile and rush medical supplies to Indonesia as the country grapples with a devastating surge in COVID-19 cases.

column1: Haitian President Jovenel Moïse assassinated
column2: A group of unidentified individuals have attacked the private home of Haitian President Jovenel Moïse and killed him, Interim Prime Minister Claude Joseph says.

column1: Wallabies beat France 23-21 with last-gasp penalty goal
column2: In their opening Test of 2021, the Wallabies trail the French the entire match before Noah Lolesio kicks a penalty goal after the full-time siren to clinch a remarkable win at Lang Park.

column1: South Korea receives 700,000 Pfizer doses from Israel in vaccine exchange deal
column2: Under the deal, Seoul will return the same amount of coronavirus shots to Israel later this year, when officials hope South Korea's shortage will have eased.

column1: Patty Mills, Cate Campbell named Australia's Tokyo Olympics flag-bearers
column2: Basketball champion Patty Mills will become the first Indigenous Australian to carry the flag into an Olympic Games opening ceremony when he marches alongside swimming star and fellow flag-bearer Cate Campbell in Tokyo.

column1: Tim Tszyu belts Steve Spark inside three rounds
column2: Tim Tszyu beats heavy outsider Steve Spark in the third round of their super welterwight fight in Newcastle.

column1: Families not told of death of relatives being watched over by public guardian for days
column2: The body given powers to make life-and-death decisions for some of WA's most vulnerable people was never required to inform families their loved ones were dying or even dead, according to a report by the WA Ombudsman.

column1: Death of 61-year-old WA woman last month likely linked to AstraZeneca vaccine according to TGA
column2: Health authorities conclude the death of a 61-year-old woman in a Perth hospital last month was likely linked to the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine.

column1: Lamb House owners unveil $15m renovation plans for Brisbane's iconic heritage-listed riverside landmark
column2: The new owners of Kangaroo Point's Lamb House unveil major plans for a three-year $15 million restoration of the dilapidated heritage-listed mansion, which they say will occasionally be opened to the public.

column1: Queensland's Jai Arrow banned from State of Origin III following COVID-19 breach
column2: The Maroons forward will not play in next Wednesday's series finale in Newcastle and is fined $35,000 after he breached the NRL's COVID-19 biosecurity protocols while in team camp.

column1: 'Let's see how high it can go': Why these two little-known Melbourne musicians are taking Europe by storm
column2: While you may not have heard of Melbourne music duo Shouse, their 2017 song has become Europe's reopening anthem.

column1: Sydney man 'no stranger to justice system' facing charges over cash and guns seeks bail in Perth
column2: A Sydney man described as "no stranger" to the justice system and charged over the seizure of more than $5 million in suburban Perth applies for bail.

column1: Sydney woman who entered ACT without a valid travel exemption fined $1,000
column2: ACT police issue an infringement notice to a Sydney woman who entered the territory without an exemption, and then failed to leave.

column1: NSW backtracks on 'living with COVID' comment following warnings about border closures from WA, Vic
column2: The New South Wales Premier and Health Minister are walking back comments about living with COVID-19, after a backlash from state leaders including WA Premier Mark McGowan who has pledged to keep the border closed under that policy.

column1: Former South African president Jacob Zuma jailed after handing himself in to police
column2: In the culmination of a long legal drama seen as a test of the post-apartheid state's ability to enforce the rule of law, Jacob Zuma hands himself in to begin a prison sentence imposed when he failed to front a corruption inquiry.

column1: Botswana unearths second huge diamond in weeks, becoming the third largest ever found
column2: A 1,174-carat diamond unearthed in Botswana trumps another huge precious stone found in the country only a month before.

column1: In-store butchers face the chopping block in Coles proposal
column2: Hundreds of trade-qualified butchers may be "redeployed" and meat only provided pre-packaged under a proposal being considered by the supermarket giant.

column1: 'No chance of life': Authorities end search for survivors in rubble of collapsed Miami building
column2: No-one has been pulled out alive since the first hours after the 12-storey Champlain Towers South building fell. Authorities have now ended the rescue operation, with the Miami-Dade Mayor saying: "Nothing we can do can bring back those who are lost."

column1: Ship carrying COVID-positive crewman sets sail after being refused dock in WA
column2: A bulk carrier off Perth's coast is turned away from WA and sets sail for Indonesia after one of its crew members tests positive for COVID-19.

column1: Greater Sydney suffering pandemic 'fatigue' as $619,000 in fines handed out to people breaking rules
column2: As parts of NSW prepare to spend a third week in lockdown, authorities concede the community is feeling pandemic "fatigue" but warn that's no excuse to flout stay-at-home orders.

column1: Olympics may be held without spectators as Tokyo set to declare a fresh state of emergency
column2: The Olympics look set to be held under a state of emergency in Tokyo, with the Japanese government expected to today announce stricter measures in the capital.

column1: Fiery explosion on container ship in Dubai felt by residents 25 kilometres away
column2: An explosion on a container ship has sent a shock wave through Dubai and damaged one of the world's largest ports.

column1: NSW to receive 300,000 extra COVID-19 vaccines to help fight outbreak
column2: The Prime Minister says NSW will receive 300,000 extra doses of Pfizer and AstraZeneca vaccines as the state struggles to bring a growing COVID-19 outbreak under control.

column1: Liquid asset test for COVID payments waived in third week of Sydney lockdown, more vaccines on the way
column2: The Prime Minister says the liquid asset test applied to the federal government's COVID-19 temporary disaster payment will be waived from the third week of the Greater Sydney lockdown.

column1: 'This is a warning': Cameras targeting drivers on phones and people without seatbelts here to stay
column2: The Queensland government says a six-month trial detected more than 15,000 people illegally using a phone while driving and more than 2,200 people not wearing a seatbelt. The RACQ welcomes the move to make cameras permanent and hit offenders with hefty penalties.

column1: Veteran and Defence suicide royal commissioners announced
column2: The long-awaited royal commission into veteran suicides will conduct a "systemic analysis" of the risk factors inside military life that contribute to the high numbers of service men and women taking their own lives.

column1: Star of The Crown shares intimate journey in chest binding, shares non-binary pronouns
column2: Emma Corrin, known for playing Princess Diana, shares photos discussing chest binding and alludes to identifying as non-binary.

column1: Will Sydney's COVID-19 outbreak delay the high-profile trial of a NT police officer accused of murder?
column2: The Northern Territory Supreme Court hears prosecutors in the case of Constable Zachary Rolfe are stuck in a locked down city and may not be able to appear in a Darwin court.

column1: Road rage killer jailed for eight years after manslaughter guilty plea
column2: Jamie Saxon, who successfully overturned a murder conviction for stabbing a German backpacker in Brisbane, is sentenced to eight years in jail after pleading guilty to a downgraded charge.

column1: Judge resigns after 'sexualised' behaviour towards two women
column2: An investigation into the former Federal Circuit Court judge found he was involved in "inexcusable"  and "sexualised" behaviour towards a court staffer and a former law student.

column1: Japanese-inspired micro-forests are growing roots in Canberra and climate scientists are paying close attention
column2: What started as a single micro-forest the size of a tennis court grows into a movement to lower temperatures in Canberra's urban environment and mitigate the effects of climate change.

column1: After years of study to be a doctor, Kate fears it could all go 'out the window' due to a snap COVID decision
column2: Healthcare students who are not fully vaccinated from COVID-19 are banned from undertaking clinic placements in hospitals and other facilities, in a snap decision that is leaving students worried and confused.

column1: Decades after the wrong man was jailed, police name a suspect in young woman's brutal killing
column2: Thirty-seven years after a man was wrongly convicted of a woman's horrific death in Mt Isa, Queensland police have issued a warrant for the arrest of her suspected killer, Andrew Albury.

column1: Check In Qld app now mandatory at thousands of businesses — here's why
column2: For a long time it was only required at hospitality venues, now pretty much every shop and business you can think of requires you to flash your phone to register before entering. The government says it is an essential tool for COVID-19 contact tracers.

column1: From Canberra Shadows to making Australian Olympic history, Patty Mills has forged a path for young Indigenous kids
column2: Patty Mills's story starts with a quiet childhood in Canberra, shooting hoops in the suburbs, playing on an Indigenous basketball team run by his parents and dreaming big.

column1: NSW faces 'disaster' and an overloaded health system if lockdown ends too early, AMA warns
column2: The president of the Australian Medical Association gives NSW a stern warning — end the lockdown prematurely and the hospital system will buckle under pressure.

column1: Things to do in lockdown that don't include streaming TV shows and movies
column2: We asked our COVID blog readers what else they've been doing to pass the time. Here's what they said.

column1: 'Like Vietnam': Why the US Afghanistan withdrawal was so quick and why they left so much behind
column2: The departure from Bagram airbase effectively ends the United States' (and Australia's) longest war. Why is there a bunch of equipment left behind?

column1: Wage dynamics in Australia have been permanently changed by foreign labour
column2: RBA governor Philip Lowe says it could take years for wage pressures to build in Australia, with businesses used to having a wide pool of foreign labour to call upon.

column1: 'The most dangerous weapon was my tongue': Park Yeonmi's story tells you everything about North Korea
column2: Amid renewed speculation North Korea is under strain and could seek to reopen negotiations with the US, Joe Biden should remember the lessons of history, writes Stan Grant.

column1: 'Enormously disturbing': Queensland government paid a predator to help 'protect' children
column2: Before he was jailed for child sexual assault, celebrity psychologist Bob Montgomery was a go-to expert on vulnerable children, for clients including the Queensland Government.

column1: England fans might irritate everyone else, but have they finally got something to sing about?
column2: After decades of embarrassment and moaning at tournaments, the English have a chance to finally back up the bravado with a trophy — just listen to the team anthem: Football's Coming Home.

column1: 'He just grabbed me': One of Australia's most experienced parliamentarians says she was sexually assaulted at Parliament House
column2: Kate Sullivan, the second-longest-serving woman in federal parliamentary history says she was sexually assaulted at Old Parliament House while the Senate was in session.

column1: US military to leave Afghanistan on August 31, Joe Biden says
column2: The US President says Afghan leaders need to come together and create a future for the country. He says the US did not go to Afghanistan to nation-build and trusts the country's military to defend the government.

column1: Why you shouldn't file your tax return too early — and other advice from the ATO
column2: As the new financial year sees more than 14 million taxpayers file their returns, the Australian Taxation Office is keeping its eye on work-from-home expenses and warning taxpayers to take their time.

column1: South Korea says Kim Jong Un has not received COVID vaccine
column2: The National Intelligence Service says it does not believe North Korea has acquired any vaccines, as Kim Jong Un warns North Koreans that COVID-19 restrictions could stay in place for a while.

column1: Barty one win away from her 'childhood dream' of Wimbledon glory
column2: Ash Barty wins her way into her first Wimbledon final with a straight sets victory over former champion Angelique Kerber.

column1: Political appointments to embassies have doubled under the Morrison government. The number of women in top diplomatic jobs has too
column2: New research finds the number of women leading Australian diplomatic posts has skyrocketed in recent years, while a record number of former politicians have been appointed to senior diplomatic posts by the Morrison government.

column1: Financial shortfall prompts Adelaide Uni to consider job cuts
column2: The loss of revenue from international students during the pandemic is forcing the University of Adelaide to consider axing more than 100 jobs.

column1: NSW Premier in private meeting with multicultural leaders ahead of 'problematic' COVID-compliance operation
column2: The NSW Premier meets with key leaders from south-west Sydney ahead of a major police operation in the area which some say is unfairly heavy-handed.

column1: EU fines four German car makers $1.3 billion over emission collusion
column2: The European Union has handed down $1 billion in fines to four major German car manufacturers, saying they colluded to limit the development and rollout of car emission control systems.

column1: Raiders shock Sea Eagles with upset win
column2: After back-to-back defeats, the Raiders breathe life into their 2021 campaign with a 30-16 win over the fifth-placed Sea Eagles at Brookvale Oval.

column1: Demons down Power to return to their winning ways
column2: Rebounding from last week's defeat to GWS, Melbourne is back on top of the ladder with round 17 still to be completed following a 31-point win over the Power at Adelaide Oval.

column1: Independent investigation to probe Crown Casino allegations aired by former inspectors
column2: The investigation comes in the wake of Four Corners featuring five former casino inspectors who say their concerns about criminal activity were ignored.

column1: Barty beats Kerber in Wimbledon semi-final classic, as it happened
column2: Australian world number one Ash Barty beats three-time major champion Angelique Kerber in the Wimbledon semi-finals in straight sets.

column1: Self-described 'graffiti granny' fined but avoids community service for vandalism
column2: An elderly piano teacher and pensioner who defaced Adelaide road signs with the letters "WTF" in an act of protest against the installation of speed humps is fined $1,700 but avoids community service which her lawyer says she would be physically unable to complete.

column1: Caitlyn Loane, young farmer and TikTok star, remembered
column2: The family and friends of a young Tasmanian farmer who built a following on TikTok have remembered her as a "beautiful young lady", with mental health advocates urging people to be mindful of those in isolation.

column1: MP requests review of sentence for man who killed Mhelody Bruno
column2: An independent MP wants the NSW Attorney General to review the 22-month sentence given to the man who killed Mhelody Bruno.

column1: Tasmanian health worker returns positive COVID test after flying to London

column1: ACT steps up its response to latest Sydney outbreak, introducing quarantine requirements

column2: Western Australia to return to pre-lockdown life after no new local cases of COVID-19 recorded overnight, as $3,000 support grants are offered to small businesses.

column1: Westpac loses $290m to 'long-running' and 'calculated' fraud
column2: Westpac says it has fallen victim to an "elaborate fraud" which cost it more than $290 million. The alleged culprit is a Sydney-based company run by the former president of Sydney Olympic Football Club.

column1: Victims of serial rapist singer tell court of 'monstrous impact' on them
column2: Newcastle women raped by former band frontman Daniel "Jimmy" Hanson have choked back tears, delivering emotional victim impact statements in court.

column1: 'Hugely disappointing': Advocates say COVID vaccinations need to be mandatory for disability workers
column2: COVID-19 vaccinations are being strongly recommended for disability support workers, but National Cabinet has stopped short of making them mandatory.
column3: Nas Campanella, Celina Edmonds, and Leonie Thorne

column1: Newcastle police pledge to weed out rule-beaking fans ahead of State of Origin
column2: A person from a lockdown zone was fined for going to boxer Tim Tszyu's fight in Newcastle and police say they'll be watching Rugby League fans.

column1: People in Sydney can go 10km from their home, here's what that looks like
column2: New rules for people in Sydney mean they can only travel within their local government area or 10 kilometres from their home in any direction. Here's what that looks like.

column1: 'No jabs, no job': Fiji mandates vaccine for workers, threatens to shut down uncompliant businesses

column1: National Cabinet agrees to set up home quarantine trial in South Australia
column2: State and territory leaders agree to establish a home quarantine trial for fully vaccinated travellers in South Australia "as soon as possible".

column1: 'I don't think anyone is prepared': Women 'discouraged' from running for local council by workplace culture
column2: The Hobart City Council is leading a push for a review of workplace culture in Tasmania's local government sector after 40 representatives from 16 councils sign a statement expressing concerns, particularly for women.

column1: 'Life will never be the same': Scores of police gather to farewell officer killed in hit and run

column1: Former Afghan interpreter says 'death warrant has been signed by the Australians' after protection visa denied

column1: Sydney lockdown likely to be extended after 'shocking' COVID numbers

column1: Banks announce renewed COVID support measures in response to latest lockdowns
column2: Australia's major banks announce fresh support measures to help businesses and individuals affected by Sydney's extended COVID-19 lockdown and other snap shutdowns and travel restrictions around the country.

column1: The Olympic Torch relay reaches Tokyo but lacks usual fanfare amid COVID-19 restrictions

column1: China criticises Australia's human rights record at UN

column1: NSW's COVID-19 restrictions will be tightened today — here's what you need to know
column2: From 5.00pm today millions of people in NSW will be subject to even tighter COVID-19 restrictions around exercising nd shopping. Here's what you can and can't do.

column1: Man 'ashamed' and 'remorseful' for involvement in kidnapping, torture of elderly man lured on Grindr
column2: A Murray Bridge man who helped detain and torture an elderly man he met on Grindr, is "ashamed of his actions" and extremely "remorseful", a South Australian District Court has heard.

column1: Cronk blasts 'stupid, selfish' Jai Arrow for COVID breach
column2: Retired Queensland pair Cooper Cronk and Corey Parker unload on Maroons forward Jai Arrow after his "selfish and stupid" bubble breach.

column1: As mysterious missile silos pop up in the desert, experts warn Beijing 'always believes war is a possibility'

column1: Want to watch Ash Barty's shot at Wimbledon glory? Prepare for a late night

column1: A police crackdown with no arrests, and a health crisis putting Sydney to the test

column1: Australia's COVID crisis has morphed — and so have the politics fuelling it

column1: The 'postcode lottery' meaning people with chronic pain may not get the treatment they need
column2: Dean Earls was finding it so hard to access treatment for his chronic pain, he left his hometown. Doctors say his situation paints a portrait of what millions of Australians experience trying to get help.

column1: 'You can set your watch by it': Jupiter's pulsing auroras powered by giant magnetic vibrations
column2: Jupiter's mysterious x-ray auroras have puzzled scientists for decades. Now they may know how they are created.

column1: Australian girl among 13 people found after 36 hours adrift in banana boat off Bougainville
column2: The five-year-old's father is elated and is making a 20-hour trip to pick up his daughter, her dog and the 12 other passengers who were missing for two days.

column1: Police officer pleads guilty to murder of Sarah Everard in crime that shocked the UK
column2: A police officer admits murdering London woman Sarah Everard whose killing sparked anger across the UK about what police, government and society can do to stop male violence against women.

column1: Dozens of workers killed in Bangladesh factory inferno
column2: A frantic search for survivors is underway just outside the capital city, where dozens of people have been killed inside a factory that was locked from the inside.

column1: Independent assessments are 'dead': Federal government abandons controversial NDIS reforms
column2: State and territory disability ministers have shot down controversial reforms to the National Disability Insurance Scheme, in what advocates say is a huge win for the disability community.
column3: Nas Campanella, Celina Edmonds, and Leonie Thorne

column1: US basketball prodigy with three Guiness World Records becomes first African American to win National Spelling Bee
column2: After the tournament was cancelled in 2020, Zaila considered stopping her spelling, which she described as a side hobby despite practicing for seven hours a day.
column3: Nas Campanella, Celina Edmonds, and Leonie Thorne

column1: Savas Caruso, who rocks Adelaide's north in his underwear and sneakers, is arrested by police
column2: Once a week Savas Caruso plays his electric guitar on the front of his home in Adelaide's northern suburbs, wearing only sneakers and underwear. While some of his neighbours are fans, some aren't so impressed.
column3: Nas Campanella, Celina Edmonds, and Leonie Thorne

column1: State's second vaccination hub at Newcastle readies for July opening, 20,000 vaccinations a week
column2: New South Wales is about to get its second COVID-19 mass vaccination hub when a new facility opens in Newcastle on July 19.

column1: Slick Rabbitohs annihilate Cowboys in 46-18 triumph

column1: Dominant Bombers keep Crows to record low score as they stay in touch with top eight

column1: Ex-cop who impersonated deceased veterans took his 'fixation too far', court hears
column2: A former police officer who impersonated deceased servicemen and took "props" to work to relay fake war stories to his colleagues has received a good behaviour bond.

column1: Canberra prisoner who escaped custody found hiding in roof

column1: AG urged to review 'extremely low' sentence for man who killed Mhelody Bruno

column1: Even harder border with NSW considered in WA, as state set to remove all COVID restrictions

column1: Aged care and disability workers will get incentives to get COVID vaccines, PM says
column2: National Cabinet has stopped short of making COVID-19 vaccines mandatory for disability support workers, instead "strongly recommending them" — but the Prime Minister says the government is looking at providing incentives for the aged and disability sectors to roll their sleeves up.
column3: Nas Campanella, Celina Edmonds, and Leonie Thorne

column1: Queen of the turf: Jamie Kah becomes the first jockey to win 100 metro Victorian races in a season
column2: Horse racing superstar Jamie Kah has achieved what no other jockey has before her, breaking a wins record held for more than two decades.

column1: Australia will soon trial home quarantine for vaccinated travellers. Here's what it could mean for future travel

column1: Millions of fans will watch the Euro final — but here are three hidden consequences

column1: 'This story just poured out of me': Award-winning actress says First Nations stories are now being heard
column2: From the Bowraville Mission to Hollywood and back, Indigenous actress and playwright Sandy Greenwood is proud to be telling First Nations stories on stage. At age 40 she says there's now an audience for them.

column1: It's getting easier to throw out broken technology, and harder to repair it — but an Australian movement is pushing back

column1: How seaweed can help wounds to heal

column1: Daniel wants to buy and fly his home town's flag. But it will cost him $220
column2: Daniel Hennessy has a collection of 15 flags from around the world, but says his own city's flag costs too much for town-proud residents to buy it.

column1: Jonathan Coleman, a TV personality with a 'special gift to make people laugh', dies aged 65
column2: Popular television and radio presenter and comedian Jonathan Coleman, who had prostate cancer, is described as "the most eternally effervescent man", as tributes flood social media after his death.

column1: Marie regrets having an abortion. Jessie doesn't. But they both experienced grief
column2: Women who have an abortion are no more likely to suffer from mental health problems, research shows. But those who do experience grief say the politics make it a hard thing to talk about.

column3: Rachel McGhee, Alexandria Utting, and Jim Malo

column1: From the highest of highs to the lowest of lows: First Nations docos tell three incredible life stories
column2: A young woman's rise from youth crime to boxing champion, a slice of magical island life, and a musician's battle with abuse and search for purpose are three stories captured by filmmakers.

column1: Australians open T20 International series with loss to West Indies in Saint Lucia
column2: Australia's men's team have let victory slip with a batting collapse in their first T20I against the West Indies in Saint Lucia — however the tourists made team history by taking the knee pre-game to condemn racial injustice.

column1: Teenager, 21yo man dead after horrific three-car crash north of Brisbane overnight
column2: A teenager and a young man are dead after a horrific three-car crash north of Brisbane overnight, with their red Hyundai hatchback losing control, crossing a median strip and colliding with a black Holden Commodore.

column1: Italy in for special sporting weekend as Matteo Berrettini makes Wimbledon final
column2: Matteo Berrettini doesn't know if he will get the chance to watch Italy play in the Euro 2020 final — the 25-year-old has the small matter of a Wimbledon decider against Novak Djokovic first.

column1: Search this table to see if you've been to a NSW COVID-19 exposure site
column2: There are now about 14,000 close contacts linked to Sydney's COVID-19 outbreak and venues in Strathfield, Bankstown and Merrylands have been added to the list of exposure sites.

column1: How a tiny school defied a government order and became a model for remote Aboriginal learning
column2: The north-east Arnhem Land school ignored a government order to teach only in English for the first four hours of each day. Now, educators say the school's "both ways" approach using Indigenous language language and English in the classroom is yielding results.

column1: How 'highly trained killers' assassinated a president in the dead of night and shook a fragile nation
column2: Haiti's president Jovenel Moïse sought to maintain an iron grip on his power. But in a nation roiled by gang violence, political turmoil, poverty and natural disasters, no-one can stay at the top for long.

column1: From winning gold to stealing a flag — Dawn Fraser's Olympic career is one to remember
column2: The self-described "cheeky little rascal" made history in the Olympic swimming pool and even inspired a future Japanese prime minister when she competed at the 1964 Games in Tokyo, writes Tracey Holmes.

column1: Scientists on a mission to feed astronauts bound for Mars
column2: Designing food for space was once the stuff of science fiction movies but scientists in South Australia are now doing just that.

column1: 'Stupid, stubborn, ego-driven policies': What happens when a country chooses vaccines over lockdowns?
column2: Fiji has made vaccination compulsory for all workers, but refuses to impose a national lockdown. As cases linked to the infectious Delta strain surge, is the strategy working?

column1: 'Chasing the mutants': The Australian researchers searching for 'next generation' COVID-19 vaccines
column2: As mutant strains of the COVID-19 continue to appear, scientists and researchers are working feverishly behind the scenes to find the next vaccines. And Australia is part of the search.

column1: Their ancient order has too many men. To survive, they’re looking for love in countries with too many women
column2: They were made famous by a parable in the Bible, but today there are only 800 Samaritans left. Now they must find willing women to keep their ancient way of life going.

column1: These Australian parents gave their daughter a Balinese name after a life-changing journey to the island
column2: Heather's first trip to Bali was in a sailboat with her husband in the 1970s, and although it went awry she was in awe and has been back plenty of times.

column1: The newspapers dubbed her 'Miss Stayput'. Her story is still doing the rounds 40 years later
column2: The image of a modest Melbourne home swamped by a sea of cars in 1970s Camberwell has become something of a faded Melbourne legend. But there was nothing faded about the woman who dwelled within.

column1: Jack's choice was simple: Rot in a Nazi prison camp or jump from the moving train
column2: Private Jack Greaves was one of thousands of Anzacs sent on a mission to help save Greece from Hitler's menace. But instead, it was the Greeks who would end up saving Jack.
column3: Stephen Hutcheon, Alex Palmer, and Katia Shatoba

column1: Tears of joy flow from Ash Barty upon Wimbledon victory
column2: Australia's Ash Barty wins Wimbledon, defeating Czech Karolína Plíšková in three sets. She is the first Australian woman since Evonne Goolagong Cawley in 1980 to win the title.

column1: England fined for use of laser pointer, booing of Denmark national anthem at Euro 2020
column2: UEFA acts after a laser pointer was shone at Denmark goalkeeper Kasper Schmeichel at Wembley Stadium during extra-time of Wednesday's semi-final, won 2-1 by England.

column1: Dylan Alcott wins second Wimbledon singles title to keep 'golden slam' hopes alive
column2: The Australian wins his 14th quad wheelchair singles major with a straight-sets win over Sam Schroder, moving him a step closer to securing the "golden slam".

column1: Former England striker Paul Mariner dies aged 68 ahead of Euro 2020 final at Wembley
column2: The ex-Arsenal and Ipswich Town forward, who scored in the 1982 World Cup and became a coach and TV commentator, dies from brain cancer as England prepare to face Italy in their first major final in 55 years.

column1: State of Origin III moved to Gold Coast from Newcastle as NSW government bans crowd due to COVID-19 risk
column2: The ARLC makes the call after being advised the NSW government will not allow Origin III to be played in Newcastle with a crowd because of the risk of Greater Sydney's COVID-19 outbreak spreading to the regional city.

column1: Roosters post gritty win over Bulldogs to stay in touch with top four
column2: The Sydney Roosters are forced into an arm wrestle with Canterbury but emerge with a grinding 22-16 victory to move up to fifth place on the ladder.

column1: Swifts beat Vixens to stay top of Super Netball ladder, Lightning defeat Fever
column2: The NSW Swifts encounter little trouble on their way to recording a 62-48 victory over the Melbourne Vixens, while the Sunshine Coast Lightning get past the West Coast Fever 65-61.

column1: Hawthorn coaching succession plan an 'insult' to Clarkson, Malthouse says
column2: Mick Malthouse feels the Hawks have shown a lack of respect to four-time premiership coach Alastair Clarkson after announcing he will be succeeded by Sam Mitchell in 2023.

column1: Crane removes Charlottesville statue that sparked deadly white supremacy rally
column2: A statue of Confederate general Robert E Lee that became a rallying point for white supremacists in Charlottesville will be sent to storage this week.

column1: Biden warns Putin the US will 'defend its people' against cyber attacks
column2: Just weeks after their face-to-face meeting, another cyber attack has been launched against US interests — so Joe Biden called his Russian counterpart with a warning.

column1: The Taliban say they now control 85 per cent of Afghanistan
column2: Taliban officials say they have taken control of 85 per cent of territory in Afghanistan, although Afghan government officials dismiss this as propaganda.

column1: Tradies warning after several who worked at multiple sites in NSW test positive for COVID-19
column2: NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian says a number of today's new COVID-19 cases are tradies who worked at multiple properties. Ms Berejiklian has singled out essential workers who work at multiple sites, saying they should "assume that you have the virus or anyone you're interacting with has the virus".

column1: With NSW COVID cases expected to climb in the days ahead, what does it mean for lockdown?
column2: NSW health authorities expect to announce more than 100 new cases of COVID-19 on Monday. So what does that mean for the Greater Sydney lockdown, which is meant to end on Friday?

column1: NRL live: Sharks clash with Warriors to end round 17
column2: The last match of round 17 sees Cronulla come up against the Warriors at Kogarah Oval, with the Sharks looking to rebound after last week's loss to the Broncos. Follow our ScoreCentre for all the live scores and stats.

column1: Is tennis entering the age of Ash Barty?
column2: If her French Open win was her arrival, then Ash Barty's Wimbledon victory may well be the start of a dynasty, writes Paul Johnson.

column1: New advice over AstraZeneca vaccine for NSW residents 'might sacrifice long-term protection'
column2: Older residents in NSW are urged to get their second shot of the AstraZenica vaccine six weeks after their first jab despite national guidelines recommending a 12-week gap between injections.

column1: Messi finally pays his debt to Argentina with Copa America win

column1: How the longest winning streak in Aussie Rules is inspiring fans in league heartland
column2: When Matt Wallin's team last lost a game, the world hadn't heard of COVID-19, Donald Trump was a just businessman and a woman had never ridden the winner of the Melbourne Cup.

column1: Euro 2020 fans gear up for final as Queen sends support to England team
column2: Whether football is "coming home" or heading to Rome, the Euro 2020 finals are shaping up to be a colourful event, with fans of boths sides taking to the streets of London to support their teams ahead of the big game.

column1: Agility, toughness and sticking to a plan — how Ash Barty sealed her Wimbledon dream
column2: Ash Barty's Wimbledon dream is finally achieved — but what does it mean, how did she do it, and what's next for the new champion?

column1: Australian government releases new advertising campaign to boost vaccination rate
column2: A revamped advertising campaign encouraging Australians to “arm yourself” against COVID-19 has been unveiled by the federal government.

column1: AFL live: Tigers host Magpies at the 'G, Swans take down Bulldogs
column2: Richmond clashes with Collingwood at the MCG, while the Swans enjoy a 19-point win over the Western Bulldogs. Earlier, Gold Coast pipped GWS by a point in a thrilling finish. Follow our live AFL ScoreCentre for all the scores, stats and results.

column1: Queensland records third day of no community cases as Origin III moves to Gold Coast
column2: Queensland has recorded its third consecutive day of zero community cases, as the Origin moves its last fixture to the Gold Coast to prevent Sydney's COVID outbreak from spreading to regional NSW.

column1: 'People put their life on the line to win': Queensland cyclist rides his first Tour de France

column1: Aboriginal languages in 'relay race' to secure next generation of speakers

column1: Bikie gang 'decimated' as seven more charged with Shane Bowden murder
column2: Police charge seven more men with murder over the shooting death of Gold Coast bikie Shane Bowden in 2020.

column1: 'Last place on earth where it should be used': Roundup approved for use in World Heritage-listed Wet Tropics region
column2: The Wet Tropics Management Authority gives permission for local councils to use the weedkiller in the World Heritage-listed region.

column1: Indonesia sent oxygen to India during its COVID crisis. Now it faces a catastrophic shortage of its own
column2: The US and China look to provide assistance to Indonesia, following the provision of ventilators by Australia and Singapore to the COVID-ravaged country.

column1: Sydney woman died on same day she tested positive for COVID-19 as NSW records 77 cases
column2: NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian says it’s “highly unlikely” lockdown will end on Friday after the state recorded 77 new COVID cases and its first death since December.

column1: 'You're going to walk home feeling better': This choir is building community one song at a time

column1: 'A permanent, safe home': Australian-first LGBTQIA+ hub opens for Melbourne's queer community

column1: What this school is doing differently that's turning around the lives of disengaged students

column1: Shaan's 'invisible illness' took over her life. Now she wants menstrual leave to be normalised at work
column2: Shaan McNiece wants to see more support for people who experience painful periods. And she says introducing menstrual and menopause leave in workplaces would be a good place to start.

column1: Fans attempt to break into Wembley ahead of Euro 2020 final
column2: A number of ticketless football fans attempt to break into Wembley Stadium ahead of the Euro 2020 final between England and Italy.

column1: NSW set for worst day of COVID-19 outbreak, cases expected to top 100
column2: As the number of household contacts increases and NSW records its first COVID-19 death since December, Premier Gladys Berejiklian tells the community to be prepared for an extension to the lockdown.

column1: There's a lesson for Australia in Barty's historic win
column2: Ash Barty's success is a particularly significant one for First Nations Australians, writes Adele Pavlidis and Marcus Woolombi Waters.

column1: The Sydneysiders bracing for an extended lockdown alone
column2: The announcement of further COVID-19 restrictions for Sydney has dealt a heavy blow to people grappling with living alone during lockdown.

column1: ATO chasing hundreds of millions in fraudulent or ineligible JobKeeper, super withdrawal claims
column2: The ATO is chasing those that tried to rort or were overpaid or ineligible for stimulus payments such as JobKeeper.

column1: The four questions NSW needs answered as its COVID outbreak intensifies
column2: We desperately need to know more about how this outbreak is being handled, starting with these questions, writes Rafael Epstein.

column1: Warning tensions with China a 'big barrier' to tourism industry's recovery

column1: An empty grave, a missing man and an unfinished inquest: The 28-year mystery that's haunted a Queensland family
column2: Leslie Ball disappeared in suspicious circumstances in 1993. Police believe his son-in-law was "likely responsible for the murder", but he died in 2015 before the inquest into Mr Ball's death was finalised. Now the chief suspect's grave has been found empty.
column3: Lesley Robinson, Stephen Long, Lucy Carter, and Elias Clure

column1: Live: England takes an early lead in Euro 2020 final at Wembley
column2: England are looking to win their first major tournament since 1966, while Italy are keen to make amends for failing to qualify for the last World Cup. It's a battle of two footballing giants with the world watching. Follow live.

column2: South Australia's management of the pandemic has been nation-leading when it comes to employment, while Queensland has taken a hit because of the impact on tourism, according to new economic analysis.

column1: This copy of Super Mario 64 just sold for more than a million. Here's why

column1: NSW records worst day of COVID outbreak with 112 new cases, eight at Sydney unit block

column1: 'It will hurt like hell for the rest of their careers': England left to deal with more penalty agony

column1: Queensland's COVID-19 restrictions on track to ease as meetings held on NSW border closure

column1: Police investigate the death of a baby girl hit by a train in Melbourne

column2: The Central Australian landscape was once a vast ocean and home to the Endoceras, an oversized killing machine that preyed on fish species and trilobites.

column1: Pope Francis reappears after surgery, calls for free universal healthcare

column1: Decades of mass immigration haven't stopped Australia's skills shortages

column1: House damaged as flooding, damaging winds and wild surf again battering Perth and South West
column2: Damaging winds and heavy rainfall sweep across Perth for the fifth time in a week, prompting a severe weather warning from the Bureau of Meteorology.

column1: Journalist dies after being beaten by anti-pride march protesters in Georgia's capital Tbilisi
column2: Rallies are held after cameraman Alexander Lashkarava is found dead in his home, days after being bashed by a homophobic mob protesting against a pride march in the Georgian capital of Tbilisi.

column1: Australian Min Woo Lee wins Scottish Open after three-way playoff
column2: The victory secures Lee's spot in this week's Open Championship at Royal St. George.

column1: Two Victorians in isolation test positive to coronavirus after returning from NSW
column2: A COVID-positive Sydney man who works as a removalist and was working during the trip, also stayed overnight in Victoria on July 8, before travelling to South Australia.

column1: Zika virus cases detected in India's Kerala state
column2: Kerala was already battling a surge in COVID-19 cases, the highest number of any Indian state. Now, authorities have issued a statewide alert after detecting 14 cases of the Zika virus.

column1: David's house was 'so unhealthy no person could occupy it', but he lived in it for three years

column1: Man charged with murder of woman in Mount Gambier home
column2: A man will face court charged with the murder of a woman police said was "known to him", whose body was found inside a house at Mount Gambier.

column1: See if you've been to a NSW COVID-19 exposure site
column2: Medical centres in Greenacre and Fairfield are among more than 60 new venues added to the COVID-19 exposure sites overnight, as cases across Sydney surge.

column1: Some boys spend their weekends playing sport or gaming. Hamish Davis spends his flying high above Canberra
column2: Hamish Davis may only be 11, but he's already taken 120 hot air balloon flights and is in training to become a pilot.

column1: Talking, beeping, ringing phones: Research shows open-plan offices really do increase stress
column2: If you think the buzz of your open-plan office is getting you down, you're right. As workers return to the office after lockdowns, they could be giving up a lot of their concentration too.

column1: COVID slams CEO pay packets back to 2007 levels

column1: Will the Queensland NRL bubble keep the community safe?

column1: Commissioner charged with investigating veterans' suicides dumped as royal commission launches
column2: Bernadette Boss, hand-picked last year to investigate the spiralling rates of suicide in the military community, has been dumped — and it could be two years before her role is filled.

column1: Ray says anyone who doesn't get vaccinated is 'mad' — but the jab is just too far away
column2: Ray Green desperately wants his Pfizer vaccination, but due to injury cannot travel to a metropolitan centre to get it. One of the only GPs working in Ray's area is frustrated when he hears regional communities are being prioritised and says "that really just hasn't happened".

column2: Security experts warn Australia is a soft target amid a "tsunami of cyber crime" which is costing the global economy about $1 trillion.

column1: The women who have been the 'first' of their kind — and the men who have tried to stop them
column2: The story of women in Australian parliaments started with a blunder from an inept man with an not-quite-so ingenious plan.

column1: 'It may have been just a 15-minute drive but it was another world': Michael Brissenden on his most memorable story

column1: Police investigate defacing of England football star's mural as Prince William labels abuse 'abhorrent'
column2: Police investigate the defacing of a mural of English football star Marcus Rashford in the wake of England's loss in the Euro 2020 final, as Boris Johnson and Prince William condemn the racist abuse players have faced.

column1: 'Delta ripping around the world': WHO chief concerned about transmission speed of new variant
column2: With the infectious Delta variant spreading across the globe, the World Health Organization says the priority must be to get all populations fully vaccinated before ordering booster shots that are not necessary yet.

column1: NSW broke COVID-19 records yesterday, but Chant is in 'two minds' about infection numbers
column2: NSW is bracing for another day of soaring COVID-19 cases, but the state's Chief Health Officer says it won't necessarily be a numbers game going forward and she's in "mixed minds" about whether she wants to see an increase in numbers today or not.

column1: Curfew and a slow vaccine rollout: Bangkok back under COVID-19 restrictions
column2: More than 10 million people are under curfew in Bangkok as Thailand battles a COVID-19 surge of two highly infectious variants, Alpha and Delta.

column1: COVID-19 emergency payments set to be increased amid fears of long Sydney lockdown
column2: Individuals and businesses in NSW struggling under COVID-19 lockdowns will be entitled to more government support.

column1: 'Simply too much risk': Warriors lose NRL homecoming game after two years on the road
column2: As they approach two years since their last game in New Zealand, the light at the end of the tunnel for the Warriors was a potential Auckland homecoming to end the 2021 NRL season. But that is now off the table.

column1: Eleven people killed by lightning while taking selfies in India
column2: Senior police officer Anand Srivastava says some of the victims were posing for photographs near a popular tourist attraction in Jaipur when tragedy struck on Sunday evening.

column2: Victorian authorities add three Melbourne locations to its list of COVID-19 exposure sites. The locations include an apartment complex, a supermarket and a service station.

column1: Two Jordanians jailed for 15 years over plot against monarchy

column1: North scores third win of 2021, handing West Coast third straight ugly loss
column2: Coming off big losses to Sydney and the Bulldogs, West Coast is edged by the last-placed Kangaroos, who showed remarkable composure in a see-sawing final quarter at Perth Stadium.

column1: 'Provocative action': Beijing says it 'drove away' US warship in South China Sea
column2: While the US has yet to confirm the incident, China says USS Benfold illegally entered its territorial waters near the Paracel Islands on the anniversary of an international court ruling against Beijing's claim to the region.

column1: Here's what we know about the Sydney removalists who travelled through Victoria and South Australia
column2: Details are still emerging about the journey taken by two people working as removalists across multiple states last week who have since tested positive to COVID-19.

column1: Mount Gambier man appears in court accused of murder after woman's body found in house

column1: 'There's going to be a bloodbath tonight': Court hears of escalating feud before former detective shot

column1: NRL blocks Dragons return in COVID-19 breach fallout

column1: 'Our business is going to be smashed': Border communities fear the worst from another lockdown

column1: ATAGI advice on AstraZeneca vaccine remains unchanged for under 60s
column2: The expert panel advising on Australia's COVID-19 vaccine rollout does not changed its advice limiting AstraZeneca vaccines to people over 60.

column1: Just 25 big cities, mostly in China, driving majority of urban greenhouse gas emissions

column1: Domestic violence allegations aired shortly before man's stabbing death, court told

column1: Facebook group to be shut down as racist, homophobic comments by Queensland police officers investigated
