column3: Sophie Scott, Mary Lloyd, and Leonie Thorne

column1: Do students in China study too much? The government seems to think so
column2: It's not unusual for students in China, particularly those hoping to reach higher education, to study and do tutoring from early morning until late at night most days. But it now seems to have the government concerned.

column1: Different rules for different states. Where is the jab mandatory for quarantine workers?
column2: As the severity of the Greater Sydney outbreak began to become clear, National Cabinet agreed to make the vaccine mandatory for all quarantine workers — including drivers. But in many states that still hasn't happened.

column1: 'Feast of sacrifice': Your guide to the Muslim Eid al-Adha festival
column2: In the final month of the Islamic lunar calendar, Muslims around the world celebrate the 'Feast of Sacrifice' also known as Eid al-Adha.

column1: Britney Spears says she will not perform until her conservatorship is lifted
column2: In a lengthy Instagram post, the pop star says she prefers sharing videos from her living room rather than performing on stage under her father's control.

column1: 'Hollow victory': Lewis Hamilton wins after lap one crash sends Max Verstappen to hospital
column2: Max Verstappen was taken to hospital while Lewis Hamilton recovered from a 10-second penalty to pass Ferrari's Charles Leclerc on the third-last lap to win.

column1: Victorians wait to see what is in store for this week after premier flags update
column2: Melbourne epidemiologist Mike Toole says if Victoria can gets it daily case numbers below 10, and then five, we might only see a short extension of the current lockdown.

column1: Seventy wildfires force evacuations in western US with conditions predicted to deteriorate
column2: Dozens of wildfires in California and Oregon scorch hundreds of square kilometres, as emergency services brace for dangerous conditions.

column1: Queensland Premier leaves for Tokyo Olympics to support Brisbane 2032 bid
column2: Annastacia Palaszczuk makes the trip to Japan, along with the Brisbane Lord Mayor and federal Sports Minister, despite an online petition with more than 130,000 signatures, demanding that the Queensland Premier stay at home.

column1: Swans and Giants AFL players forced into isolation after visiting Melbourne exposure site
column2: Sydney Swans and GWS Giants players, including Toby Greene, withdraw from a match on the Gold Coast after visiting a COVID-19 exposure site in Melbourne last Tuesday.

column1: 'Stay vigilant': Regional NSW warned tighter restrictions ahead if COVID rules ignored
column2: The NSW Deputy Premier warns regional communities to "stay vigilant" in an effort to keep the highly-infectious Delta strain out — or face tighter restrictions.

column1: Eight crew members from cargo ship off WA positive to COVID
column2: All eight symptomatic crew members from a cargo ship docked at Fremantle in Western Australia test positive for COVID-19.

column1: Nightclubber kicked elderly man to death in his retirement unit, court told
column2: Sebastian Ruiz fatally assaulted 76-year-old Keith Moylan in his retirement village unit because he did not like the way the elderly man treated women, the WA Supreme Court hears.

column1: Veterans burn medals to protest Australia's 'moral failure' on protecting former Afghan colleagues
column2: Furious veterans burn their military decorations to protest the federal government's slow response in granting refuge to hundreds of locally engaged Afghanistan staff now facing deadly Taliban reprisals.

column1: Kain's opponent was found not guilty of racial abuse, but Indigenous footballers want systemic change
column2: Bundoora footballer Kain Proctor says he was racially abused in a Northern Football Netball League game two weeks ago, but a not guilty verdict for his alleged abuser has shone a spotlight on racism issues in club football.

column1: No lockdown but SA intensifies restrictions as daughter of new case now tests positive
column2: South Australia is significantly stepping up the level of social distancing measures after the daughter of a man with coronavirus also tested positive.

column1: Two new Victorian vaccine ads have dropped today. Will they persuade people to get the jab?
column2: Artists and ordinary Australians come together urging Australians to play their part in a performance of a lifetime — get vaccinated and keep each other safe.

column1: Couple face years of burns rehab after gas explosion at Gold Coast cafe
column2: The brother of a Gold Coast chef says the 26-year-old is still in an induced coma after suffering serious burns while setting up his "dream" cafe.

column1: Mother of charged removalists becomes fifth death during NSW Delta outbreak
column2: The mother of removalists who travelled from Sydney to Molong while infectious with the Delta strain has died inside her south-west Sydney home.

column1: Man accused of murdering 81yo Elizabeth Kippin was on 'violent rampage', trial hears
column2: A man charged with the murder of an 81-year-old woman and the attempted murder of two others told police he was on a "killing spree" and was "going to be famous", a court hears.

column1: 'He could fit on the end of my finger': Vet performs surgery on particularly petite patient
column2: This badly injured frog had its lung poking out of its wound when it was saved by the keen eyes of a vet nurse and the steady hands of a veterinarian.

column1: Here's what we know about SA's new COVID-19 cases, and exposure sites
column2: South Australia's latest COVID-19 cases have triggered a heightened state of alert and more social restrictions — with contact tracing ongoing after the daughter of an 81-year-old man with the virus also tested positive.

column1: Federal staffers make up majority of interviews in Parliament House culture review
column2: Only 16 current or former politicians have contributed to a review of workplace culture at Parliament House by Sex Discrimination Commissioner Kate Jenkins.

column1: Queensland anaesthetist accused of sexually assaulting unconscious women
column2: Police say the Toowoomba-based anaesthetist inappropriately touched three women in their 20s while they were unconscious between November and February this year.

column1: Why high profile people from Katie Hopkins to Matt Damon are let into Australia
column2: Australia's decision to boot far-right commentator Katie Hopkins raises the question of why she was given a visa in the first place — and the answer explains everything from Caitlyn Jenner to Matt Damon.

column1: These 19th century buildings have been home to historic moments, now they're up for sale
column2: The first version of the Australian flag was sewn in Launceston's Milton Hall. Now, the 19th-century building and the church next door are up for sale.

column1: Chief vet demands regulatory overhaul amid probe into Victorian dog deaths
column2: Victoria's chief vet is calling for tighter regulations amid a "complex" investigation into the supply chain after multiple pets died in the state.

column1: Tenants are facing their biggest rent hikes in 12 years, amid surging house prices
column2: Australian tenants are experiencing their biggest annual rent increases since 2009. Canberra was the most expensive rental market, while Sydney and Melbourne unit landlords saw the weakest returns.

column1: Brazil's President leaves hospital after days-long hiccuping fit caused by stabbing
column2: Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro is ready to return to work after four days in hospital suffering from abdominal pain and chronic hiccups.

column1: Former NSW Labor minister found guilty of conspiring over land deal that netted Obeid family $30m
column2: Former NSW Labor ministers Eddie Obeid and Ian Macdonald and Obeid's son Moses are found guilty of conspiring over a lucrative mine licence.

column1: Truck driver from COVID-19 hotspot tries to enter Queensland with false documents
column2: Police are cracking down on truck drivers crossing the border after two infectious removalists travelled through South Australia via Melbourne, sparking a statewide lockdown in Victoria.

column1: WA cycling star Ben O'Connor backed as future Tour winner after finishing fourth on debut
column2: Rising cycling star Ben O'Connor says it was a "magical moment" to finish fourth in his debut Tour de France, as experts back home tag the 25-year-old as a potential future winner of the race.

column1: Number of Phillip Island COVID-19 exposure sites grows to 30
column2: The local health service is reporting a drop in the wait for coronavirus testing as the number of exposure sites linked to two positive cases grows to 30.

column1: Footage shows moment New York mum foils kidnap attempt by grabbing son from getaway car
column2: A quick-thinking mother springs into action to save her five-year-old son after he is grabbed from the street in an apparent kidnap attempt.

column1: Ben Roberts-Smith trial to resume as mental health of witnesses deteriorates, court told
column2: Ben Roberts-Smith's defamation trial will temporarily resume on Monday with the war veteran's barrister telling a court the mental health of military witnesses was declining because of the trial's delay.

column1: Giants-Swans COVID drama reminds us how precarious AFL's season is
column2: The results in round 18 mean the top eight is not as set in stone as we thought, but the real uncertainty lies in how we get through the rest of the AFL season, writes Alister Nicholson.

column1: As the Islamic holiday of Eid al-Adha begins, we take a look at how diverse Australia's Muslims are
column2: While almost two-thirds of the world's Muslims come from Asia, Islam is often misrepresented as "monolithic". As Muslims around the world celebrate Eid al-Adha, we take a look at the vast array of cultures and beliefs within Australia's Muslim community.

column1: 'Assault on democracy': Judgement day for US Capitol rioter
column2: A man who carried a Trump flag on the US Senate floor has told a court what was going through his mind when he took part in the January 8 insurrection.

column1: Musician due to receive Order of Australia found collapsed in hospital hours after seeking care
column2: Thomas Langston died just weeks before he was due to receive an Order of Australia award for his service to music and the community. Now, his family and friends want to know why his death at a hospital was not investigated.

column1: Construction shutdown hits projects big and small, and doubles the lockdown's economic fallout
column2: A sudden ban on most construction, renovation and repair work in Greater Sydney leaves projects big and small in disarray and is set to double the cost of Sydney's lockdown.

column1: Infectious Delta strain prompts 'rethink' on COVID-19 vaccination for children
column2: NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian says children are being considered for inclusion in the COVID-19 vaccination rollout to help prevent the spread of the highly-infectious Delta strain. But it may still be a long way off.

column1: Stuck in Sydney's COVID-19 lockdown? See if you're eligible for financial help
column2: As the NSW COVID-19 lockdown continues into its third week, there is a range of government assistance available for individuals and businesses. See if you qualify for help.

column1: Milly Tapper's first attempt at table tennis was 'terrible' — now she's making history
column2: Milly Tapper has come a long way from being — as she puts it — "terrible" at table tennis. She made history playing at both the Olympics and Paralympics in Rio and is set to do it again in Tokyo.

column1: 'Military fanboys' shared a video threatening nuclear war. This is why China allowed it
column2: Was the sharing of a video threatening nuclear war a message from Beijing or a low-level official going a little rogue? One expert says it could be both.

column1: Rise of self-harm and use of mental health services since COVID pandemic began, new data reveals
column2: New data from the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare gives an insight into exactly how the pandemic has affected the mental health of Australians like Emily.

column1: 'Of course it's happening to me': The shocking experience almost all female MPs must learn to navigate
column2: I spoke to women MPs across different generations and political belief and was prepared for them to disagree with each other. But what shocked me most was the one experience almost all of them had in common, writes Annabel Crabb.

column1: No masks, clubbing and hugs: Freedom Day marks the end of coronavirus restrictions in England
column2: Doctors and scientists voice concerns over the rise in COVID-19 infections as people across England do away with masks and social distancing on what has been dubbed "Freedom Day".

column1: Fires are burning out of control in usually cold Siberia
column2: With more than 100 fires blazing across Siberia, planes are battling to seed cloud to bring down much needed rain before the flames reach a power plant.

column1: Astronomers capture image of a second black hole. And it's very different to the first one
column2: New images capture fiery jet of super-hot gas being spat out from the heart of a supermassive black hole at the centre of the Centaurus A galaxy.

column1: The three issues that will determine how long Victoria's lockdown runs
column2: Daniel Andrews is expected to let Victorians know how much longer they'll have to spend in lockdown later today. That decision will be based on three key factors: the number of cases, the chains of transmission and the number of mystery cases.

column1: US, Australia and UK accuse China of committing 'massive' Microsoft hack
column2: The Microsoft Exchange hack was first identified in January and was rapidly attributed to Chinese cyber spies by private sector groups.

column1: 'A remarkable life': Actress Mary Ward, star of Prisoner and ABC's first female announcer, dies at 106
column2: Best known for her role in Prisoner in which she played Jeanette 'Mum' Brooks, Ward also appeared in Sons and Daughters, A Country Practice, Neighbours and The Henderson Kids in a 70-year acting career.

column1: World Rugby dismisses red card against Wallabies winger Marika Koroibete
column2: Rugby Union's governing body says Australia winger Marika Koroibete did not deserve to be sent off during the Wallabies' test win over France last Saturday.

column1: Gym owner behind 'f*** lockdown' posts disputes fine, says COVID rules 'grey area'
column2: A New South Wales gym owner who has faced criticism for his attitude towards COVID-19 restrictions insists he is trying to work within lockdown guidelines.

column1: F1 champion Lewis Hamilton racially abused on social media following lap-one crash
column2: Formula One and the Mercedes team are denouncing a spate of racially abusive messages on social media at seven-time champions Lewis Hamilton.

column1: Police seek extradition of NSW man after woman's body found in box in Brisbane apartment
column2: Police searching for a missing woman find a body in an apartment block at Hamilton in Brisbane's north. The death is being treated as suspicious and homicide detectives are at the scene.

column1: Lewis escapes NRL suspension for scuffle
column2: Bulldogs five-eighth Lachlan Lewis can accept a $1,600 fine but will not miss a game after he was reported for his halftime scuffle with Rabbitohs opposition Cody Walker.

column1: Dogs gun Dunkley put in 14-day quarantine after visiting COVID exposure site
column2: Western Bulldogs AFL midfielder Josh Dunkley starts 14 days of home quarantine after visiting a cafe that was a tier 1 coronavirus exposure site.

column1: High-ranking bureaucrat issued with 'formal warning' after ICAC report into Darwin Turf Club
column2: The Chief Minister confirms one of the Northern Territory's most senior public servants was given a formal warning after the anti-corruption commissioner criticised him in a damning report examining the government's controversial $12 million grant to the Darwin Turf Club.

column1: Eight crew members from cargo ship off WA test positive to COVID as SA travel advice updated
column2: All eight symptomatic crew members from a cargo ship docked at Fremantle in Western Australia test positive for COVID-19.

column1: Why would Australia want to help Telstra buy a Pacific telco from an Irish billionaire?
column2: No-one wants to talk about it until it's inked, but the deal's all about China and making sure that Beijing doesn't get its mitts on a key strategic asset in the Pacific, writes Andrew Probyn.

column1: Former Defence Force member arrested, chemicals seized by bomb squad in Sydney raids
column2: A 54-year-old man is arrested after the bomb squad raided two properties in south-west of Sydney, following an "alarming" tip-off from Australian Federal Police.

column1: Trio accused of putting man through woodchipper overheard 'getting their story straight', court told
column2: A Supreme Court bail hearing is told three men accused of conspiring to murder Bruce Saunders in 2017 were overheard concocting a "falsehood" about his death being an accident.

column1: Russia tests missile that can fly at nine times the speed of sound
column2: Russia says it has successfully tested a hypersonic cruise missile that NATO forces are concerned may pose a greater risk of "escalation and miscalculation".

column1: The gloves are off as the dark arts of China's rivalry with the US moves out of the shadows
column2: After the US and its allies claimed China was behind large-scale cyber hacking, Beijing hit back hard and fast, writes Bill Birtles.

column1: Police seize more guns, weapons linked to man found with explosives in Canberra hotel room
column2: Thousands of dollars worth of stolen guns, explosives, drugs and cash are seized by ACT police after a series of raids across three Canberra suburbs.

column1: Meals on Wheels kitchen worker tests positive for coronavirus in SA
column2: A staff member at meal provider Meals on Wheels has tested positive for COVID-19 after recently spending time in one of the agency's Adelaide kitchens.

column1: New modelling reveals possible date for end to Sydney lockdown
column2: New modelling adds weight to the view that while NSW's harder lockdown was the right move, a drop in cases won't be seen until September.

column1: Bootleg megafire in Oregon climbing list of largest ever
column2: The megafire burning in Oregon now covers an area half the size of Australia's Capital Territory and continues to spread further each day, but mercifully into areas largely uninhabited by people.

column1: The world has blamed China for a massive cyber attack. Now what?
column2: A global coalition says China's hacking campaigns must stop, but pointing the finger over January's Microsoft Exchange attack seems the only consequence for now.

column1: The Olyroos who helped deliver Tokyo qualification but won't live out their Olympic dream
column2: When the Olyroos take on Argentina on Thursday night in their opening clash of the Olympics, only seven players who helped the side qualify for Tokyo will be in the final 22-man squad.

column1: SA's lockdown has businesses counting the cost, but others are battling panic buying
column2: As South Australia prepares to plunge into its biggest lockdown of the COVID-19 pandemic, businesses are in limbo about what support they will receive to tide them over — but the SA Premier says he has already approached the Prime Minister.

column1: 'You are my life': Twin's tribute to mother who died in Sydney Delta outbreak
column2: Brothers Roni and Ramsin Shuka express their grief over the death of their 57-year-old mother Saeeda, who became the fifth person to die in the current outbreak of the Delta strain of COVID-19 in NSW.

column1: Gippsland knackery breaks silence on dog deaths, issues meat recall
column2: A Gippsland meatworks linked to a dozen dog deaths and at least 50 illnesses has issued a recall on raw meat sold throughout Victoria.

column1: Criminals take advantage of Queensland police's pursuit policy
column2: A senior Queensland police officer tells a Gold Coast inquest — into a road death after a high-speed pursuit — that criminals deliberately drive dangerously because they know police will not chase them.

column1: COVID-19 cases on Fremantle-docked cargo ship rises to ten
column2: Another two people on board the BBC California ship docked in Fremantle have tested positive for COVID-19.

column1: ‘We’re getting blamed for everything’: Aged care worker frustrated over vaccine rollout
column2: Aged care worker Suzana says she had to organise her own COVID-19 vaccination and the soonest she could book was late August.

column1: Tasmania closes borders to South Australia as whole state declared 'high risk'
column2: Tasmania has declared the whole of South Australia a high risk area, meaning only essential travellers will be allowed to enter.

column1: More wet weather on the way as BOM declares negative IOD
column2: The climate phenomenon that brought Australia one of its wettest winters has been officially declared for the first time in five years.

column1: Man who worked with Kelly Wilkinson's estranged husband charged with murder
column2: Detectives allege the 25-year-old Pimpama man worked with Kelly Wilkinson's estranged husband and knew of his intention to kill the Gold Coast mum.

column1: Legal challenge over Christian Porter's lawyer could cost the pair $500,000
column2: A challenge over whether Christian Porter's lawyer had a conflict of interest in his defamation case against the ABC could cost the former attorney general and his Sydney silk Sue Chrysanthou half-a-million-dollars.

column1: First case of coronavirus identified in state's Central West linked to pet food delivery driver
column2: A factory worker in the Central West of New South Wales has contracted COVID-19, after a truck driver with coronavirus travelled to the region over several days.

column1: Riverina GP worries about 'wasted' AstraZeneca doses during current outbreak
column2: A southern New South Wales doctor has confirmed COVID vaccinations have been disposed of, because of a lack of available patients.

column1: Musician resigns from Tokyo Olympics opening ceremony over historical bullying
column2: Japanese musician Cornelius, whose real name is Keigo Oyamada, resigns just days out from Friday's ceremony after magazine interviews from the 1990s resurface.

column1: AFL investigating hotel 'disturbance' involving Hobart Football Club
column2: An off-field incident involving players and coaches from a Tasmanian football club has been referred to the AFL for investigation.

column1: Abusers turn to tech to torment victims amid increased lockdowns
column2: Researchers say the coronavirus pandemic has led to more referrals to family violence support services but it's harder for people to get access to help.

column1: When COVID is behind us, Australians are going to have to pay more tax
column2: If we want the latest health care, disability care and aged care, we'll have to be prepared to pay for it, writes Peter Martin.

column1: Olympians reshaping the future for female athletes
column2: Australian Olympians Lea Yanitsas and Nina Kennedy are part of a new athlete advisory group launched by the Australian Institute of Sport to shape the future performance and health of elite sportswomen.

column1: 'Not an aberration': Eighty per cent of Australian Muslims experience discrimination, according to study
column2: In a survey by the Australian Human Rights Commission, Australian Muslims say they experience unfavourable treatment when dealing with law enforcement and in the workplace.

column1: 'So far from our priorities': Pacific Islanders dismiss tussle as China and Australia vie for telco
column2: Telstra is in discussions to buy the Pacific arm of mobile service provider Digicel in partnership with the Australian government, in a move widely seen as an attempt to counter China's influence in the region.

column1: Can Batman save Jeff's business? Maybe not
column2: With almost half the Australian population in lockdown to prevent the spread of coronavirus, businesses are struggling because consumers are shutting their wallets.

column1: 'We are all concerned': Fear grows in regional NSW as Delta strain spreads beyond Greater Sydney
column2: There's growing concern the fast-spreading Delta variant has broken through the cordon placed around Greater Sydney after a factory worker in the state's Central West tests positive.

column1: 'We're not a priority': Pfizer is safe for pregnant women — so why aren't they eligible?
column2: Pregnant women are struggling to get vaccinated against COVID-19, despite health advice recommending they be offered the Pfizer vaccine.

column1: Explosive new claim: Did Juanita Nielsen try to blackmail crime boss Abe Saffron?
column2: Loretta Crawford was a key witness to the 1975 disappearance and suspected murder of journalist Juanita Nielsen, and the last person to see her alive. After 20 years she has broken her silence.

column1: Indonesia is averaging 1,000 deaths from COVID a day and coffin makers can't keep up
column2: As Indonesia faces a surging number of deaths driven by the Delta variant, coffin makers and crematoriums are increasing staff and extending operating hours in a bid to meet demand.

column1: Heavy flooding in China strands commuters, washes away cars
column2: Days of heavy rain has flooded a dozen Chinese cities and left people fighting for their lives in dramatic scenes in Henan province.

column1: Confusion, a handshake and secret bar crawls: Some foreign arrivals for the Tokyo Games cause 'absolute chaos'
column2: Olympic officials admit it's impossible to keep COVID-19 entirely out of the athletes village. And now the highly infectious Delta strain has left organisers scrambling to shift their protocols almost daily to stay ahead of the virus, writes Jake Sturmer.

column1: ODI live: Wounded Aussies try to regroup for ODIs against West Indies
column2: After losing four out of five Twenty20s, Australia's men's tour of the West Indies continues with the first of three one-day internationals in Bridgetown. Check out the live scores and stats in our ScoreCentre.

column1: Will Brisbane be the cost-neutral, sustainable Olympics?
column2: Brisbane is on the verge of being named as host for the 2032 Olympic Games, but beyond two weeks of sun, sand and sport, minds are turning to the prospective costs and benefits for Queensland and Australia — and the answers aren't yet all clear.

column1: Harvey Weinstein extradited to California to face new sex assault charges
column2: The former Hollywood producer is back in Los Angeles to face trial on a new set of charges relating to sex attacks on five women over nearly a decade.

column1: China says it was 'ganged up' on by US and Australia over hacking allegations
column2: China is rejecting accusations it is to blame for a hack of the Microsoft Exchange email system, complaining Chinese entities are victims of damaging US cyber attacks.

column1: 'You're not a princess who needs her own room, are you?': Victim of AMP sexual harassment case faced incident at another firm years earlier
column2: The woman whose complaint sparked the sexual harassment scandal that rocked AMP says years before her mistreatment at the financial services firm she was fired from another job for not sleeping with her boss.

column1: 'Permanently assigned': Britain deploys warships to support Japan over China fears
column2: With Tokyo expressing growing alarm over Beijing's territorial ambitions, the warships will travel to the region after the Queen Elizabeth aircraft carrier and escort ships are dispatched in September.

column1: South African court grants delay in Jacob Zuma's corruption trial
column2: The former president's legal team argues for a postponement so he can appear in person, amid fears of further riots across the nation.

column1: Rocket attack near presidential palace in Kabul disrupts leaders at prayer
column2: At least three rockets hit near the presidential palace shortly before Afghan President Ashraf Ghani was to give an address to mark the major Muslim holiday of Eid al-Adha.

column1: Less than a month after abandoning its Kabul post, Australia considering future return to Afghanistan
column2: The ABC has been told the government is considering re-establishing a presence in Afghanistan to monitor the resurgence of the Taliban.

column1: Naked man ran through streets announcing 'killing spree' before 81yo found dead, court hears
column2: Witnesses tell the Supreme Court in Townsville they encountered a naked man who "looked to be" holding a knife the night before Elizabeth Kippin's body was found.

column1: 'Disheartening': Why former Wallabies player Quade Cooper's application for citizenship keeps being rejected
column2: The rugby union player says despite representing Australia on the world stage he has had applications for citizenship knocked back four times since 2015.

column1: South Australians are now under a 2.5km exercise limit. Here's where that gets you — and the reasons you can go further
column2: In one of the strictest lockdown travel limits imposed across the country, South Australians cannot exercise further than 2.5 kilometres from their homes. Here's where you can go, and what the few exceptions to the rule are.

column1: Delta strain on the move and spreading to Western Sydney, health authorities warn
column2: Health authorities warn the Delta strain which has so far spread to the city's eastern suburbs, three LGAs in south-west Sydney is likely on the move again to Western Sydney.

column1: 'Australia is not walking alone': Japan's ambassador backs federal government's handling of China
column2: The Japanese ambassador in Canberra has praised Australia's handling of its relationship with China, saying it has faced up to tremendous economic pressure from China in a consistent and principled way.

column1: South Australia records six new cases of COVID-19 linked to winery and restaurant
column2: South Australia records six new cases of COVID-19 with five cases infected at the Tenafeate Creek Winery adding to the cluster.

column1: Former Labor MP Craig Thomson embroiled in fraud investigation after home raided
column2: AFP and Border Force officials search the Central Coast home of former Labor MP Craig Thomson as part of an investigation of an alleged fraud against the federal government.

column1: Repatriation flights considered for Afghans who worked with Australian troops
column2: Australia considers sending repatriation flights to Afghanistan to evacuate Afghan nationals who worked closely with Australian forces during the decades-long conflict.

column1: Who will make the next Diamonds team? Kim Green, Sharni Norder and Caitlin Thwaites make their picks
column2: Head coach Stacey Marinkovich is expected to name the next Diamonds squad in August, as the team looks to solidify its best combinations before the 2022 Commonwealth Games and 2023 Netball World C

column1: 'I want to go again – fast': 60 years after training as an astronaut, 82yo Wally Funk made it to space
column2: Aboard billionaire Jeff Bezos's rocket, the aviation pioneer becomes the oldest person to go to space, six decades after being denied by the US government because of her gender.

column1: Adelaide teen in hospital with meningococcal
column2: An 18-year-old from Adelaide is in hospital with meningococcal disease.

column1: Man accused of murdering woman found in box in Brisbane to be extradited
column2: The man accused of murdering a 30-year-old Chinese woman, whose body was found in a storage box at a Brisbane apartment on Monday, will be extradited to Queensland to be charged.

column1: India's coronavirus deaths could be in the millions, report says
column2: Researchers say the death toll could be 10 times more than the official count, with estimates that millions of people could have died from COVID-19.

column1: Melbourne couple put behind bars after working a personal slave to the point of hospitalisation
column2: A Melbourne couple who enslaved and brutalised a grandmother over an eight-year period are sentenced to prison for the "crime against humanity".

column1: A Canberra builder who scammed a family out of more than $60,000 avoids jail time
column2: Clinton Dotta pleaded guilty to tricking a family into paying him more than $60,000 for a renovation. Today he was spared time behind bars.

column1: 'I take responsibility': Prime Minister acknowledges COVID-19 vaccine failures, but rollout now on track
column2: Acknowledging the COVID-19 vaccine program's bumpy roll out, Prime Minister Scott Morrison says the country is now on track, with one million Australians vaccinated against the disease in the last week.

column1: 'My hands basically lost all sensation': Queenslanders rug up as cold-weather records predicted to tumble
column2: A burst of cool and dry air has Queenslanders scrambling for their coats as  "brutal" winds batter the southern interior.

column1: COVID quarantine breacher gets six months in jail for road trip through WA
column2: A "reckless" and "selfish" Tasmanian man who toured around Western Australia in a "blatant" breach of the state's tough COVID laws is sentenced to six months' jail.

column1: Cause of Victorian dog deaths revealed
column2: Victorian authorities say a toxin found in a native plant is behind the spate of dog deaths in the state.

column1: Communities 'on edge' after positive case located at Mareeba, the gateway to Cape York
column2: The mayor of a Far North Queensland Indigenous community says residents are 'on edge' after a woman tested positive for COVID-19 in the region, despite Queensland recording no new cases today.

column1: Sports Illustrated Swimsuit cover breaks ground with three women representing firsts
column2: This year's Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue features three women of colour on three separate covers who represent firsts for the magazine.

column1: Giannis stars as Milwaukee Bucks clinch NBA title with win over Phoenix Suns
column2: Milwaukee wins its first NBA championship since 1971, downing Phoenix in game 6 of the NBA finals.

column1: 'Our hands were tied': Education department responds to concerns over ICAC corruption findings of former Milingimbi principal
column2: The Northern Territory Department of Education defends its failure to detect the behaviour of a remote principal four years before she was found to be corrupt by the NT's anti-corruption watchdog.
column3: Chelsea Heaney, Fiona Poole, and Jack Hislop

column1: World leaders and human rights activists may have been targeted with military-grade spyware. Here's what we know
column2: French President Emanuel Macron is among more than a dozen world leaders whose phone numbers have appeared in a leaked database of potential hacking targets. Here's what we know.
column3: Chelsea Heaney, Fiona Poole, and Jack Hislop

column1: Winery, Greek restaurant named as 'high risk' sites amid South Australian COVID-19 cluster
column2: Two large shopping centres and a school in Adelaide's south have been named as exposure sites connected to the latest COVID–19 outbreak in the city, but health authorities say a winery and a Greek restaurant remain the places causing the most concern.
column3: Chelsea Heaney, Fiona Poole, and Jack Hislop

column1: UK woman allegedly swaps diamonds worth $7.8m with pebbles at London jeweller
column2: British prosecutors say Lulu Lakatos used "sleight of hand" to steal diamonds, including a 20-carat heart-shaped gemstone valued at more than 2.2 million pounds, from a London jeweller.
column3: Chelsea Heaney, Fiona Poole, and Jack Hislop

column1: 'You little beauty': South-East Queensland wakes to Olympic buzz after Brisbane wins 2032 bid
column2: There are only 4,019 days to go until Brisbane hosts the 2032 Olympic and Paralympic Games after success in Tokyo last night.

column1: How south-east Queensland will transform for the 2032 Olympics
column2: The 2032 Olympics will catapult south-east Queensland onto the world stage, but what will the region need to meet the demands of the major sporting event?

column1: Construction industry warns buildings will close if Sydney lockdown is extended
column2: There are warnings that a large number of building firms will go under, with thousands of jobs lost, if the NSW lockdown is extended beyond July 30.

column1: Kids are dropping out of sport and it's hoped Brisbane 2032 will get them back
column2: Brisbane 2032 will be a catchcry to get kids back into organised sport after a drop off, largely because of COVID. Sports bosses see the next decade as 'the golden runway', a path to creating future Olympians and improve the nation's health.

column1: With COVID as a distraction, the Coalition and Labor both have simmering divides they need to mend
column2: COVID has meant many other political issues have been neglected, with both sides of politics harbouring unresolved internal divisions that must be settled before the election draws too much closer, writes David Speers.

column1: This is Harry's fifth lockdown — and he knows exactly what to do with his extra time
column2: All over Australia, people are responding to COVID-19 lockdown announcements and extensions by asking: 'What can I do for someone else?'

column1: North Melbourne is improving, but where can we see the green shoots?
column2: They're still in contention for the wooden spoon, but North Melbourne are really starting to lift their game. Cody Atkinson and Sean Lawson explain how the Kangaroos are rising up.

column1: New digital 'patrol' uses facial recognition technology in bid to control underage gaming in China
column2: Every midnight, millions of younger Chinese gamers now face another foe — a digital 'patrol' using facial recognition technology that could boot them out of their virtual worlds.

column1: 'COVID's not going away': Calls for federal government to act now to secure drug treatments
column2: The federal government has been urged to secure supplies of COVID therapy drugs amid fears Australia could be left at the back of the queue as the world's focus turns from vaccines to medicines to treat the disease.

column1: Police refused to help find Mirna's son. So she started digging
column2: In a nation where tens of thousands have been disappeared, family members are being forced to dig for their own dead.

column1: 'Some had water in them': Ugandan medicos accused of delivering counterfeit jabs

column1: UK city becomes third in world to be stripped of world heritage status

column1: 'Indication of the severity of this outbreak': Fiji government announces two pregnant women have died of COVID-19
column2: The women presented to hospital with severe respiratory symptoms, Fiji's Health Secretary said, but could not be saved despite emergency caesarean sections being performed; both babies survived.

column1: Brisbane's celebration is why we love the Olympics
column2: While Brisbane's bid team spoke with pride and passion it was the reactions from Queenslanders on the city's riverfront that show why the human condition needs moments like these, writes Tracey Holmes.

column1: Fear and uncertainty are as contagious as COVID as Delta re-writes 2021
column2: Cities locked down, COVID spreading, and JobKeeper packed away in a box marked "do not open". This is the mess we're in, writes Daniel Ziffer.

column1: Matildas make hot start to Olympic tournament as top-ranked United States stumble to historic loss
column2: Australia's women's football team kicks off its Tokyo Olympics campaign with a classy 2-1 win over New Zealand, made that much sweeter by an earlier 3-0 loss for the USWNT in the same group.

column1: Police arrest teenage car passenger after fatal alleged hit-and-run crash in Adelaide's south
column2: A 19-year-old car passenger is arrested after a fatal crash at Morphett Vale last night.

column1: Sue Hickey fails in bid to become Glenorchy Mayor

column1: WA worst in nation for getting people vaccinated, sparking fears of more lockdowns to come
column2: WA having the lowest vaccination rate of all the states and territories is worrying local businesses who have already suffered through three lockdowns this year.

column1: Traffic Canberra 'hasn't seen in its history': Up to four years of disruptions expected for next stage of light rail

column2: A US couple whose gender reveal ceremony sparked a California wildfire that killed a firefighter are charged with involuntary manslaughter.

column1: Your daily guide to the Games: Australia kicks off the Olympics in football, softball

column1: Accused getaway driver involved in Hamzy murder granted bail

column1: COVID-19 clampdown sees popular music festival cancelled

column1: Sleep-deprived new mother jailed for stabbing partner in the neck with kitchen knife

column1: How you can tell if your phone is being monitored
column2: It's reported the Pegasus spyware can capture a user's keystrokes, intercept communications, track their device and tap into their camera and microphone, write Paul Haskell-Dowland and Robert Musotto.

column1: A growing list of countries have recently switched up their vaccine strategies. Here's why
column2: As outbreaks driven by the Delta variant take hold across the globe, a number of countries are changing their approach to vaccinations in a bid to improve effectiveness.

column1: How will Australia perform at the Tokyo Olympics? The signs are good

column1: 'Ask her': Coates says remarks to Palaszczuk were 'misinterpreted by people who weren't in the room'

column1: 'I'm very worried': Delta cluster rocks Sydney disability group home

column1: Everything you need to know about the Lambda variant, from a virologist
column2: Preliminary evidence suggests Lambda has an easier time infecting our cells and is a bit better at dodging our immune systems. But vaccines should still do a good job against it, writes Adam Taylor.

column1: Police hunt for woman, man with 'blood on face' after fatal Newcastle shooting

column1: Border communities in Queensland, NSW prepare for life again with restrictions

column2: A Supreme Court judge rules the trial of a police officer accused of murdering a teenager in a remote community will be delayed until further notice.

column1: Detained Australian Sean Turnell at 'grave risk' from COVID-19 if he is not released from Myanmar jail, wife says

column1: Olympic opening ceremony director fired over Holocaust joke

column1: South Coast workers fear no capacity for COVID-19 outbreaks
column2: Regional healthcare workers are pleading for the New South Wales government to mandate staff ratios, insisting the system is at a "breaking point", with no capacity for any COVID-19 outbreaks.

column1: Alyssa suffered a stroke after her COVID jab, but still thinks vaccination is the solution

column1: 'Tripled in six years': Survey shows alarming rise in emotional distress among WA students

column1: Morrison is a leader with his back against the wall and he's lashing out at the wrong place

column1: Warning for shoppers as COVID-19 spreads in supermarkets

column1: Who's a clever cockie? Bin-busting birds lift the lid on their secrets
column2: Move over bin chickens. Cockatoos are also raiding bins in suburbia and their skills are spreading fast.

column1: The five tropes that still plague women in power

column1: Generation X is the most 'stressed' when it comes to being able to pay their mortgage. Here's why

column1: 'No-one was listening': How did Indonesia's COVID-19 crisis get this bad?

column1: Billions of JobKeeper dollars went to businesses that increased turnover during height of pandemic

column1: It's never been more expensive to buy beef, and the price looks set to 'explode' further

column1: Which sports probably shouldn't be at the Olympic Games?

column2: Australia is trying to push China out of a telecommunications deal in the Pacific. There's a similar story in undersea cables but experts say the efforts may be too little, too late.

column1: This young, Australian troll spread racist hate from behind a mask but now it's off

column2: After both of Himanshu Malik's parents died from COVID-19, the 13-year-old has been left with the burden of acting as the head of the household.

column1: Morrison wants us to focus on the future, not the past. But what lies ahead is clear as mud

column1: COVID's escape from Sydney is a nightmare scenario. Could a 'ring of steel' have stopped it?
column2: COVID-19 has escaped from Sydney into regional centres. Catherine Taylor explores what went wrong and how rural communities will cope with Delta.

column1: Yes, it's safe to get the COVID vaccine while breastfeeding. Here's why

column1: The key moments from the opening ceremony of the Tokyo Olympics

column1: Barristers trained to 'bamboozle, belittle, slut shame' rape complainants, former Federal Court judge says

column1: The challenge for Victoria's Premier: Providing hope for a way out of the COVID-19 crisis

column1: Xi Jinping makes surprise visit to Tibet, the first by a Chinese leader in over 30 years

column1: Extreme weather hits India, with landslides killing dozens and cutting off hundreds of villages

column1: WHO urges collaboration on investigating COVID origin after China rejects plan for probe

column1: Novak Djokovic not feeling pressure at Tokyo Olympics as his 'golden slam' quest continues

column1: Great Barrier Reef avoids UNESCO 'in danger' tag after Australia says it makes 'no sense'
column2: The Great Barrier Reef will not be added to UNESCO's "in danger" list this year, after environment minister Sussan Ley's whirlwind diplomatic effort won enough support to override the UN body's scientific advisers.

column1: US launches air strikes to help embattled forces in Afghanistan

column1: Court hears there's a lack of evidence in Steven Hinrichsen murder trial

column1: Best bits of the Tokyo Olympics day 1

column1: Parting gift: Samoans reprise hotel balcony thank you after quarantine
