column3: Ros Lehman and Sarah Jane Bell

column1: All adults in Sydney urged by ATAGI to 'strongly consider' taking AstraZeneca
column2: All adults in Greater Sydney should “strongly consider” getting vaccinated with any available vaccine, including AstraZeneca, Australia’s expert vaccines body says.

column1: Mungo Man changed history. Where should his remains rest?
column2: When the history-changing 42,000-year-old remains of Mungo Man were returned to south-west NSW, traditional owners rejoiced. Now a planned burial is dividing Aboriginal and scientific communities.

column1: NRL live: Red-hot Rabbitohs heap more pain on Warriors
column2: South Sydney and the Warriors face off, before Manly takes on the Tigers and a Penrith-Brisbane clash wraps up the NRL action on Saturday. Follow our ScoreCentre for all the live scores and stats.

column1: Are wineries more susceptible to 'super-spreader' events for COVID-19?
column2: Australian wineries are internationally renowned for great drops, but in recent times they've developed an unfortunate reputation for something else — becoming 'super-spreader' venues for COVID-19.

column1: NT Police fine tourists who went to Kings Canyon instead of quarantine
column2: NT Police say two people feared missing in Central Australian outback have been found and escorted to quarantine. A seperate group of four people are also facing fines.

column1: Canada to fast-track Afghan resettlement amid fears of the Taliban's rise
column2: Citizens who had an "enduring relationship" with Canada while its military was in Afghanistan will be resettled, as veterans lobby the government to speed up the process amid Taliban's rise.

column1: AFL live: Kangaroos upset Blues, Lions host Suns at Gabba
column2: North Melbourne upset Carlton, while the Brisbane Lions play the Gold Coast Suns in a Queensland derby. Follow our live AFL ScoreCentre for all the scores, stats and results.

column1: Can Jeff Bezos be called an astronaut? New US rules make it unlikely
column2: The Federal Aviation Administration tightens the rules for civilians receiving astronaut wings, meaning US billionaires who launch into space are unlikely to be considered astronauts.

column1: Verstappen's Grand Prix crash cost Red Bull $2.4 million, says Horner
column2: Red Bull boss Christian Horner says Max Verstappen's collision with Lewis Hamilton has "massive"  financial ramifications and the team were considering all "sporting options" in regards to a review of the penalty imposed.

column1: Police charge 57 people after wild Sydney anti-lockdown protest
column2: NSW Police Minister David Elliott says 57 people have been charged after attending an anti-lockdown protest in Sydney today and that a strike force has been established to identify others who were there.

column1: From dance nights to paper bag portraits, travellers in COVID quarantine make their own entertainment
column2: In the NT, 2,133 people are in quarantine: the highest number to date. And travellers are finding unique ways to keep themselves occupied.

column1: Apartment blocks added to Victoria's growing list of exposure sites
column2: There are now more than 400 COVID exposure sites in Victoria. See the full list here.

column1: Here are some of the big moments to watch out for during the Tokyo Olympics
column2: No-one can predict all the highlights of the Tokyo Olympics ahead of time, but here are our picks for surefire excitement across the Games.

column1: State of Origin: Olympic swimming edition
column2: Queensland has held top spot in swimming's unofficial State of Origin rankings for years, but Victoria is fast improving with a strong contingent in the pool at the Tokyo Olympics.

column1: Kookaburras off to a winning start in Tokyo with 5-3 win over Japan
column2: Australia's men's hockey team opens its Olympic campaign with victory over the host nation — but not without a serious scare.

column1: Olympic hurdler who turned a country pub into a training hub
column2: In the Mallee town of Kerang, residents tell the tale of a former publican who once used some unlikely facilities to become a champion hurdler.

column1: SA records one more COVID-19 case linked to winery cluster
column2: South Australia records one new case of COVID-19 linked to a winery north-east of Adelaide, but health authorities say while other cases are likely, the state remains on track to come out of lockdown next week.
column3: Tom Fedorowytsch, Daniel Keane, and Alice Dempster

column1: 'Don't have a shower — it bothers me': Neighbour complaints over minor issues soar
column2: Have we forgotten how to talk to our neighbours? The WA Citizens Advice Bureau says complaints about neighbours have increased a hundredfold and most of them are over minor issues that could be resolved by talking.

column1: German reporter suspended after being caught smearing mud on herself during flood coverage
column2: Susanna Ohlen says she wiped mud onto her clothes before a TV report as she felt ashamed to be reporting on the floods in clean attire.

column1: 'Irresponsible': Eighteen COVID cases linked to family gathering, NSW records 163 new infections
column2: Police issue more than 200 penalty notices and health authorities plead with people to stop gathering as NSW's COVID-19 crisis deepens after a record number of new infections is announced.

column1: This humane breakthrough in feral pig control targets pigs' weakest part: their stomachs
column2: A newly released poison bait is being hailed as a major breakthrough in feral pig control.

column1: How do trans athletes see the question of fairness in competition?
column2: An openly trans athlete will be competing at the Olympics for the first time, but a decision coming after the Tokyo games could change the rules across many sports for trans participation.

column1: 'It means gold to me': Why Fiji rugby fans are clutching a rare $7 banknote during the Tokyo Olympics
column2: It's been four years since Fiji released the world's only $7 note to mark the Flying Fijians winning Olympic gold. Its owners hope this year the rugby-obsessed Pacific nation can do it again.

column1: Everything you need to know about Olympic skateboarding
column2: Skateboarding is one of the five new events at the Tokyo Olympics, but how does it work? And how many different types of skateboarding are there? Check out our handy guide for everything you need to know.

column1: Are we already sliding into another recession?
column2: Having not experienced a technical recession in almost three decades, Australia now faces the risk of having two in little more than a year as COVID ravages a previously recovering economy.

column1: The US and China started a battle for global chip dominance. Then a small but mighty competitor entered the race
column2: Computer chips are needed to power everything from phones to cars to fridges and keep economies rolling. But a global shortage is sparking a battle between China and the US to make more of them and South Korea has been caught in the middle.

column1: 'Here comes the sun': The philosophers who might help us through COVID's dark days
column2: How do we not fall prey to fear when all we hear is a drumbeat of doom and a daily roll call of new COVID cases, asks Stan Grant.

column1: Centenarians are now Australia's fastest-growing demographic —  how do they do it?
column2: Exercise, eat your veggies and don't smoke: the age old advice for a long healthy life remains true but education, staying social and even optimism are important too, writes Catherine Taylor.

column1: From 'gold standard' to ‘national emergency’ — the five weeks that changed everything
column2: When NSW Treasurer Dominic Perrottet strutted into Parliament to deliver this year's state budget on June 22, the mood was one of unbridled optimism. Just a month later, the outlook is very different — here's how the current COVID-19 crisis played out.

column1: Pfizer has been approved for children aged 12 and over, but most kids will have to wait
column2: Australia's medicines regulator has approved the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine for young teenagers, but experts say it'll be some time yet before most kids are included in the wider vaccine rollout.
column3: Sophie Scott, Mary Lloyd, and Leonie Thorne

column1: Samoa's new Prime Minister moves quickly after historic court decision
column2: Fiame Naomi Mata'afa, Samoa's first female Prime Minister, says her government will formally take office next week, with the country's Court of Appeal affirming her government is legal.
column3: Sophie Scott, Mary Lloyd, and Leonie Thorne

column1: Alicia's bid to escape came too late. Her mother wants domestic violence laws reformed
column2: The mother of a Victorian woman killed by the actions of her partner wants the state to allow criminal records to be handed over to anyone fearing they could be subject to domestic violence.

column1: ODI live: Australia's series against West Indies resumes in Caribbean
column2: Australia and West Indies meet in Bridgetown in the second ODI after a COVID-19 scare briefly halted the series. Check out the live scores and stats in our ScoreCentre.

column1: Chinese man survives three days in flooded garage as typhoon barrels towards east coast
column2: A man in central China is rescued after spending three days trapped in a flooded underground garage following torrential rains.

column1: Aussie swimmers break national records, reach finals in Tokyo
column2: Brendon Smith sets a national record in the men's 400m individual medley by topping qualifying for Sunday morning's final, while Emma McKeon has a new Australian mark after reaching the women's 100m butterfly semis.

column1: Labor's James Martin wins Stretton by-election
column2: Labor claims victory in the seat of Stretton in south Brisbane after a by-election triggered by the death of Labor MP Duncan Pegg.

column1: Kerr scores two but misses penalty as Matildas lose to Sweden
column2: Qualification from the group stage now looks dicey for the Australians, with a final game against the United States looming after they were sliced open all too easily by the Swedes.

column1: Your daily guide to the Games: Swimming finals headline day 2 of Olympics action
column2: Medals will be awarded in the pool with the first swimming finals, and on the road with the women's road race, plus the Boomers get their campaign off and running. Here are the Olympic events to watch out for from Tokyo on Sunday, July 25.

column1: Car retrieved from Swan River as police lay charges amid three separate incidents
column2: Police charge multiple people after three separate incidents in Perth's CBD overnight left several police officers with minor injuries and a car submerged in the Swan River.

column1: 'Cruel disease': Woman in her 30s dies, teen in intensive care as young people face 'higher risk'
column2: A Nobel Prize-winning immunity and infection expert warns there is a "considerable risk" from the Delta variant of COVID-19 to young people after the death of a Sydney woman in her 30s.

column1: 'I wish I could have done better': O'Neill bows out in men's street skateboarding heats
column2: Australian skateboarder Shane O'Neill would use different tactics if he had his time again challenging the men's street skateboarding at Tokyo Olympics.

column1: A group of mayors wanted better trains, so they won Brisbane the Olympics
column2: Brisbane is gearing up to host the Games, but it was a group of mayors worried about something else entirely that got the plan on track.

column1: Ice turns Adelaide Hills street into makeshift ski run after mini tornadoes
column2: As SA continued its coronavirus lockdown overnight, residents were also bunkering down for entirely different reasons — but one decided to make use of the thick hail and get out his skis.

column1: Curfew announced for most of Afghanistan as Taliban 'atrocities' continue
column2: The curfew will affect 31 of the country's provinces where the Taliban claims half of Afghanistan's 400 districts, as Human Rights Watch warns there could be more killings by the insurgents.

column1: Party over: Ash Barty knocked out in opening round of Olympics singles
column2: Australia's Ash Barty is out of the women's singles event at the Tokyo Olympics, losing in straight sets in round one.

column1: NRL live: Titans thrash Dragons, Sharks lead Bulldogs
column2: The Titans beat the Dragons in a Gold Coast double header, with the Bulldogs and Sharks now doing battle. Follow our ScoreCentre for all the live scores and stats.

column1: US golfer DeChambeau to miss Olympics after testing positive for COVID-19
column2: World number six Bryson DeChambeau will miss the Tokyo Olympics after testing positive for COVID-19 before leaving the United States for Japan.

column1: Westfield Chermside added to Queensland COVID exposure list
column2: Three barber shops at Westfield Chermside have been added to Queensland's COVID-19 exposure list after a man ignored Sydney quarantine orders to travel to Queensland.

column1: Additional Pfizer doses are on their way —  but it won’t help you be vaccinated more quickly this year
column2: Pfizer will produce 85 million booster shots to be offered to Australians who have already been fully vaccinated against COVID-19.

column1: New match-up app provides lifeline for disabled, elderly
column2: A "match-up" app is giving NDIS participants, the elderly and their families greater choice and flexibility when it comes to how they are cared for.

column1: AFL live: Swans beat Dockers, Cats lead Tigers
column2: Geelong play Richmond, and Essendon face GWS after Sydney's big win over Fremantle. Follow our live AFL ScoreCentre for all the scores, stats and results.

column1: Aussie women break their own world record to storm to relay gold in Tokyo
column2: The Aussie women's 4x100m freestyle win the nation's first gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics, topping off a huge morning in the pool for Australia.

column1: SA records three new COVID-19 cases, sets new testing record ahead of 'D-Day'
column2: Two of South Australia's new cases attended either a winery or a restaurant linked to the Modbury cluster. SA Premier Steven Marshall says while the state is still on track to emerge from lockdown after seven days, tomorrow would be "D-Day".
column3: Tom Fedorowytsch, Alice Dempster, and Daniel Keane

column1: 'You might not care about the rest of us': Premier's message for Sydney lockdown protesters
column2: Premier Gladys Berejiklian says she is "utterly disgusted" by yesterday's anti-lockdown protest in Sydney's CBD, which saw protesters wrestle with police officers.
column3: Tom Fedorowytsch, Alice Dempster, and Daniel Keane

column1: Queensland still 'at risk' of new COVID cases after man from NSW ignores quarantine orders
column2: Queensland is on alert for new COVID-19 cases after authorities say a man from Sydney ignored orders to quarantine for 14 days and instead travelled north to Ballina then Brisbane, where he spent time in the community.
column3: Tom Fedorowytsch, Alice Dempster, and Daniel Keane

column1: Sydney woman in her 30s who died from COVID-19 had no pre-existing medical conditions
column2: A woman aged in her 30s is one of two new COVID-19 deaths recorded in NSW, with the state confirming 141 new locally acquired cases.

column1: Critically endangered birds find 'paradise', but for how long?
column2: The plight of the hooded plover is well known. But recent studies have revealed the shorebird's found a slice of heaven near a coastal Victorian city.

column1: Budapest Pride parade sees thousands march against Hungary's anti-LGBTQ laws
column2: Organisers say this year's Budapest Pride is not only a celebration, but also a protest against the Hungarian government's current policies targeting the queer community.

column1: 'Disappearing' clues about forced labour, mass kidnappings
column2: To the untrained eye, a few crumbling mounds of concrete are the only clues as to what happened on this nondescript patch of land in Central Queensland cane country.

column1: Here's your wrap of today's COVID news from around Australia
column2: It can be difficult to keep up with all the COVID news, especially at the weekend when there are other things to do. So here it is, all in one place.

column1: R Kelly accused of abusing underage boy
column2: Federal prosecutors in singer R Kelly's sex trafficking case allege he had sexual contact with an underage boy in addition to girls, as more allegations against him are aired.

column1: Lauren went on TikTok for a laugh. She left it with an eating disorder
column2: Beyond the dances and skits there's a darker side to TikTok. The app's algorithm is exposing users to dangerous content while controlling which people and political movements get attention.
column3: Avani Dias, Jeanavive McGregor, and Lauren Day

column1: Delta 'changes everything' for Australia's vaccination targets. This is what the modellers are looking at
column2: With Australia lagging behind world vaccination rates and more than half the country in lockdown, the when and how of the nation's return to normalcy are becoming even more vital.

column1: Ballet-dancing Melbourne plumber Harry Garside is setting Australia's boxing standards
column2: Australian lightweight boxer Harry Garside was considered an easybeat in his early years in the fight game, but the ballet-dancing plumber from Melbourne is eyeing gold in Tokyo.

column1: The 'COVID class' of 2020 is sending messages of hope to the Year 12 students of 2021
column2: The uncertainty of lockdowns on top of exam stress is leaving many of 2021's Year 12 students unsure of how to cope. But a student from the class of 2020 has started a unique project offering advice and support to this year's students.

column1: Australia is racing to make mRNA COVID vaccines here — but can we do it without Pfizer or Moderna?
column2: Experts say local manufacturing could ensure a steady supply and help with developing booster shots. But getting this happening any time soon could hinge on a single global player.

column1: How the carbon tax has come back to haunt the Australian government
column2: The federal government's stance on carbon tax policy means its risks being caught on the wrong side of history and damaging the economy, writes Ian Verrender.

column1: Arizona is still counting ballots, trying to prove that Trump won. Democracy is shaping up to be the big loser
column2: A group of Trump supporters in Arizona stopped trusting their democratic institutions. And then those institutions, struggling to get the trust back, tried giving them legitimate power.

column1: NSW to 'see the fruits' of lockdown in coming weeks despite 141 new cases and two deaths
column2: NSW enters this week of lockdown with stubbornly high COVID-19 Delta variant cases as Premier Gladys Berejiklian defends her government's strategy.

column1: If these athletes win at the Olympics, their flag won't be raised and their anthem won't be played. Here's why
column2: The last time Tokyo held the Olympics, Taiwan was able to compete under its own name and flag. But that's no longer the case. Here's why.

column1: Australian golfer Minjee Lee wins her first major at Evian Championship
column2: Minjee Lee etches her name amongst Australian golf's major winners with a dramatic playoff victory at the Evian Championship.

column1: 'Amazing': France's Evan Fournier buries Team USA in Olympic basketball upset
column2: Lightning has struck twice for France. Two years ago they beat the US at basketball's world championships, now they've ended a 25-match Olympic win streak that dated back to the Athens Games in 2004.

column1: Victoria's COVID lockdown could end soon. Here's what authorities are watching for
column2: Victorian health officials and senior ministers have met overnight and will meet again today to discuss the end of the state's fifth lockdown. Here's what we know so far.

column1: Titmus sets up showdown with Ledecky in 400m freestyle final, McKeown breaks Olympic record
column2: Australia's Ariarne Titmus will face defending champion Katie Ledecky in a much-anticipated final, while Kaylee McKeown adds an Olympic record to her world mark in the 100m backstroke.

column1: Rejected for Australian citizenship, Quade Cooper selected in Wallabies squad for Bledisloe Cup
column2: The 33-year-old five-eighth, who last played for Australia in 2017, is selected in a 42-man squad, with coach Dave Rennie's options limited by Queensland's border closure.

column1: Boomers start with a win, Kookaburras thump India but brave Olyroos lose to Spain
column2: The Boomers and Kookaburras flex their muscles with impressive wins, but the men's football team can't quite go the distance with Spain.

column1: Bus crashes in Croatia, killing 10 and injuring at least 45 others
column2: In an accident the local police chief describes as one of the worst he has seen, a bus carrying more than 60 people crashes on a highway busy with summer tourists.

column1: This Dutch rider was ecstatic when she thought she'd won gold. Unfortunately, she hadn't
column2: Annemiek van Vleuten celebrated winning the women's road race. Unfortunately for her, she actually finished second by over a minute.

column1: Second ship in a week on way to WA with suspected COVID-infected crew
column2: A week after the BBC California docked in Western Australia with COVID-infected crew, another ship en route to the state has alerted authorities about sick personnel on board.

column1: Flights cancelled as typhoon hits China's east coast
column2: Shanghai, a city with about the same population as Australia, cancels inbound and outbound flights and suspends subway trains as In-fa makes landfall.

column1: Your daily guide to the Games: Aussies hoping for more swimming gold on day 3 of Olympics action
column2: Australians Emma McKeon and Ariarne Titmus swim for gold, while the Hockeyroos and Stingers continue their Tokyo campaigns and the men's triathlon takes place. Here are the Olympic events to watch out for on day 3.

column1: Japan wins skateboarding gold, COVID ends DeChambeau's Games
column2: Australia's unassailable women's 4x100m freestyle relay team steal the show again as the medals begin rolling in for the Aussies. Here are the best bits so far from day 2 of the Tokyo Olympics.

column1: Woman in her 30s dies, teen in intensive care as young people face 'higher risk'
column2: A Nobel Prize-winning immunity and infection expert warns there is a "considerable risk" from the Delta variant of COVID-19 to young people after the death of a Sydney woman in her 30s.

column1: Ministers will be made to attend sexual harassment training, but little consequence for no-shows
column2: The recommendations of a review into the Parliament's workplace, ordered in the wake of the Brittany Higgins rape allegations, have been accepted by the government.

column1: 'Head out early': BOM encourages workers to head home before dangerous peak hour storm front hits
column2: People in Western Australia's south-west, including the Perth metropolitan area, are warned about an impending cold front which will bring intense rain and dangerous winds during the afternoon rush.

column1: Police patrol car rammed by stolen firefighting vehicle
column2: Two police officers have spent the night in hospital after their patrol car was rammed by a stolen government firefighting vehicle near Lakes Entrance in Victoria's east.

column1: Dieter Brummer, Home and Away 90s heart-throb, dies aged 45
column2: Dieter Brummer, who starred in Home and Away as the hugely popular heart-throb Shane Parrish in the 1990s, is found dead in his Sydney home.

column1: Federal MP at anti-lockdown rally alongside QAnon supporters
column2: George Christensen was just metres from QAnon supporters at a rally in Mackay,  North Queensland, as photos seen by the ABC reveal.

column1: What you can and can't do when SA's lockdown ends
column2: Lockdown is set to be lifted in South Australia from Wednesday, as long as no new "unlinked" cases pop up. Here's a look at what you can and can't do.

column1: Hockeyroos' unbeaten run continues, Ariarne Titmus claims gold over rival
column2: The Hockeyroos continue their dominance, and there's more success in the pool as the Aussies claim more medals. Here are the best bits so far from day 3 of the Tokyo Olympics.

column1: Nightclubber admits punching, kicking elderly man to the floor, but denies intent to kill
column2: Accused murderer Sebastian Ruiz testifies he punched and kicked a 76-year-old stranger in the elderly man's own home because he wanted to make a point about how to treat women.

column1: Gambling regulator may call for Crown's Perth casino licence to be cancelled, royal commission hears
column2: WA's gambling regulator may call on Racing and Gaming Minister Reece Whitby to cancel Crown Perth's casino licence before the royal commission has handed down its findings, the inquiry is told.

column1: How many older Australians have been vaccinated so far?
column2: More than 150 days into Australia's vaccination rollout, no age group is yet to reach a first dose vaccination rate of 80 per cent.

column1: WA, NT criticise extra vaccines for NSW as federal government denies stockpile
column2: WA Premier Mark McGowan and NT Chief Minister Michael Gunner question the extra doses of Pfizer vaccine being allocated by the Commonwealth to NSW, saying the entire country needs more vaccines.

column1: California wildfire destroys homes as blazes burn across western United States
column2: More than 85 large wildfires are tearing through across the US, threatening thousands of homes.

column1: 'Arnie' Titmus terminates Ledecky's reign, then thanks her for the push
column2: She may describe herself as happy and giggly, but Ariarne Titmus is more Terminator than she likes to let on, as shown in her epic showdown with US rival Katie Ledecky, writes Paul Kennedy.

column1: Fauci says US headed in 'wrong direction' as COVID-19 cases surge
column2: The United States is seeing more COVID-19 cases fuelled by unvaccinated Americans and the Delta variant, the nation’s top infectious diseases expert says.

column1: Slaughterhouse worker who stabbed mate 49 times guilty, but not of murder
column2: Jamie Cust's defence team argued that Jesus Bebita had sexually assaulted him while he was sleeping and that he had acted under "extreme provocation".

column1: A world superpower is missing from these Olympics, replaced by the initials ROC
column2: Australia's Beach Volleyball team is going up against athletes representing ROC this afternoon at the Tokyo Olympics, but you'd be forgiven for thinking no such country exists — it doesn't.

column1: Labor vows to keep stage 3 tax cuts for wealthy Australians
column2: Tax relief for people earning between $45,000 and $200,000 is locked in for 2024, as Labor agrees to keep the final stage of the government's legislated tax cuts.

column1: Shut the NSW border: Key NT Aboriginal organisations demand action
column2: Three key Northern Territory Aboriginal organisations call for a hard border to NSW as the Delta variant spreads.

column1: Women are taking a stand against skimpy sport outfits, but not everyone agrees
column2: Women's dress codes in sport are determined by "traditions" that are both outdated and gendered that have turned women into objects to be admired rather than being valued for their sporting skills. However, there is recent rebellion in the ranks, writes Rachael Jefferson-Buchanan.

column1: 'Alleged idiots' arrested over third illegal lockdown party at Adelaide home, police say
column2: Five people are arrested and a further eight are fined for allegedly breaching South Australia's current strict lockdown, after police were called to another house party at an address in suburban Adelaide.

column1: Adelaide on track for wetter-than-average July with more rain to come
column2: Monthly records have been thrown out and Adelaide is about to reach its average rainfall for this time of year as a dramatic turnaround from South Australia's dry autumn continues.

column1: Door-to-door agents used phoney accents and fake names to switch customers' energy accounts
column2: Melbourne-based company Simply Energy is fined $2.5 million for not obtaining proper consent to sign up customers.

column1: Artist explains meaning behind Australia's Irukandji surf team's Olympic identity
column2: Jasmine Craciun was given the opportunity of a lifetime when she was asked to work on a design for the Australian Olympic surfing team.

column1: Triathlon's wild ride in Tokyo: A false start, a broken nose, and an unbelievable finish
column2: Norway comes out on top with a dramatic finish as Australia's top ranked triathlete Jake Birtwhistle leaves battered in a Tokyo 2020 men's triathlon to remember.

column1: NSW's top cop admits police can't stop second lockdown protest in Sydney
column2: NSW Police say a second anti-lockdown protest in Sydney will "not be tolerated" after thousands of people marched through the CBD on Saturday.

column1: Revitalisation of Ipswich's 'ghost town' CBD restores confidence after years of council waste
column2: It was known as the "never never" project, taking more than 10 years of false starts to get off the ground. Now, a multi-million-dollar CBD redevelopment promises to breathe new life into a city once plagued with corruption scandals.

column1: A mystery COVID case and possible border breaches — this is what Queensland authorities know
column2: There are three cases of concern in Queensland, including a flight attendant and a man facing police investigation, and another man who had already been fully vaccinated in China and undergone quarantine before he tested positive. Here's what we know.

column1: 'It's devastating': Tasmanian child protection system reforms yet to be fully implemented, review finds
column2: A former health worker who blew the whistle on Tasmania's child protection system five years ago says the latest report into the troubled system is disturbing.

column1: The factors Berejiklian is weighing up before deciding on lockdown future
column2: Premier Gladys Berejiklian is weighing what life will look like beyond July 31, but declares "our mission is to allow our citizens to live as safely and freely as possible."

column1: Why shutting Western Sydney due to COVID could impact your local grocery shop
column2: Wherever you live in Australia, you could be affected by a shutdown of Western Sydney. The south-west suburbs at the centre of Sydney's COVID-19 crisis are also major hubs of retail distribution, transport and logistics.

column1: What to watch for when the GOAT vaults back onto Olympic stage
column2: One of the biggest names at the Tokyo Olympics might also have the smallest stature, but everyone is excited to see what mighty Simone Biles will do in the gymnastics.

column1: NSW is worried about low vaccine rates in over 60s but it's not just hesitancy to blame
column2: Hesitancy may only be one reason behind the low COVID-19 vaccine uptake among over 60s and experts warn the issue should not be oversimplified.

column1: All over in six minutes. The brutal world of Taekwondo
column2: Athletes spend years, decades even, to appear and perform at the Olympic Games. For some though, the entire experience can be over inside six minutes.

column1: 'Great success story': Bhutan achieves rapid vaccination of population
column2: UNICEF's Bhutan representative says the world can learn from Bhutan, a country with very few doctors and nurses to administer the vaccines, but with a committed king and leadership.

column1: China reports highest COVID case numbers since January
column2: The Chinese city of Nanjing sees a surge of COVID infections as the nation reports its highest case numbers since January.

column1: Here's how Victorians are expected to move out of fifth COVID lockdown
column2: Given the COVID-19 situation in New South Wales, and with thousands of Victorians still in isolation, the Victorian government is likely to take a cautious approach to easing out of lockdown.

column1: Your daily guide to the Games: Swimming finals, Opals and Matildas headline Tuesday action
column2: Australia's medal pursuit in the pool continues on day 4, and we will also get our first chance to see the Opals in action. Here are the Olympic events to watch out for on day 4.

column1: COVID symptoms 'would have been worse' if not for SA man's first AstraZeneca vaccine
column2: As South Australia prepares to emerge from lockdown, a man who contracted COVID-19 during the state's coronavirus outbreak is encouraging people to "go and get vaccinated".

column1: 'Grim and chilling' figures show women, children casualties on the rise in Afghanistan
column2: Afghanistan records a sharp increase in the number of civilians killed and wounded in violence, as Western security forces pull out of the war-torn country.

column1: 'I just couldn't keep it in': Wild celebration by Titmus's coach goes viral
column2: Ariarne Titmus's stunning swim in the 400 metre freestyle has had Australians cheering — none more so than coach Dean Boxall, whose intense "Ultimate Warrior" celebration has gone viral.

column1: 'New dictator' in Tunisia as president suspends parliament, fires prime minister
column2: Tunisia's largest political party decries a "coup d'etat" after the dismissal of Prime Minister Hichem Mechichi, in a country held up as the only success story of the Arab Spring.

column1: Michael Gunner 'extremely worried' wet season downpours will delay remote vaccination effort
column2: The NT Chief Minister says he fears the annual deluge — which sees many remote communities isolated for months at a time — could hamper the rollout of COVID-19 vaccinations in remote areas.

column1: Thirteen-year-old takes gold in female street skateboarding at Tokyo
column2: Two 13-year-olds and a 16-year-old ascend the podium after winning the street skateboarding event at the Tokyo Olympics, dragging the women's sport into the spotlight.

column1: Pink offers to pay fine issued to Norway's beach handball players for not wearing bikini bottoms
column2: Lashing out against the game's governing body on Twitter, pop star Pink says she is "proud" of the team for protesting against the "very sexist rules about their uniform".

column1: 'There are no winners here': Canberra man faces sentencing for manslaughter of friend Jae-Ho Oh
column2: Joshua Higgins faces sentencing after being found guilty of manslaughter for the death of Jae-Ho Oh in 2019.

column1: Ministers will be made to attend sexual harassment training and threatened with the sack if they don't
column2: The recommendations of a review into the Parliament's workplace, ordered in the wake of the Brittany Higgins rape allegations, have been accepted by the government.

column1: 'Dangerous' storm front set to hit WA's south bringing strong winds and heavy rain
column2: People in Western Australia's south-west, including the Perth metropolitan area, are warned about an impending cold front which will bring intense rain and dangerous winds during the afternoon rush.

column1: Dolphin rescuers take cues from whale stranding to move mother and calf to clear water
column2: A pair of bottlenose dolphins beached in Tasmania is successfully set free using a technique developed during Australia's largest mass whale stranding last year.

column1: Olympian Nathan Baggaley and brother get more than 20 years' jail over failed cocaine plot
column2: The former kayaker and his younger brother Dru were found guilty of trying to smuggle up to $200 million worth of cocaine by boat into Australia.

column1: 'I'm going to kill you': Canberra court views video of man allegedly chasing partner with chainsaw
column2: A man remains behind bars after a video was played to a Canberra court of him chasing his partner with a chainsaw as she tries to protect herself with a vacuum cleaner.

column1: Man infected with COVID-19 who left locked down Sydney for Queensland slapped with fines
column2: The 26-year-old man was fined almost $10,000 for three breaches of COVID-19 health directions while the woman, a flight attendant, who collected him from northern New South Wales has been fined $4,135.

column1: Best bits of day 4: Wright clinches bronze, Kookaburras win again, McKeown gets gold
column2: Owen Wright claims the first medal in Olympics surfing, while the Kookaburras remain undefeated after a convincing win over the defending champions. Here are the best bits from day 4 of the Tokyo Olympics.

column1: Florida man beached during attempt to walk to NY on water
column2: Reza Baluchi's wanted to raise money for charity by running on water from Florida to New York with the help of a flotation device. It did not go as he expected.

column1: Cooked in champagne and sprinkled in gold, these are the world's most expensive chips
column2: A restaurant on Manhattan's Upper East Side is plating up the most expensive chips on the planet, with a single serve going for $US200.

column1: Fears customers exposed to COVID-19 at Sydney shopping centre for 11 days
column2: Health authorities say a shopping mall in Sydney's south-west is "a key venue of concern" amid fears customers could have been exposed to COVID-19 there for 11 days.

column1: Hospital workers exposed to COVID-positive crew 'chose' not to take vaccine, health chief says
column2: Three "critically ill" crew members taken off the MV Darya Krishna berthed in Fremantle spark a COVID scare after protocols failed when they were taken to a Perth hospital.

column1: Public masturbator avoids jail after assaulting women at music festivals, on tram
column2: A Melbourne man who ejaculated on women at music festivals will not spend a moment behind bars or be registered as a sex offender.

column1: Tasmania has been COVID-free for 447 days — how much longer can it last?
column2: Today marks 447 days since the last active case of COVID-19 in the Tasmanian community. Is it good luck or good management?

column1: Afghan farmer refers to Australian soldiers who raided villages as 'infidels' in Roberts-Smith trial
column2: An Afghan villager tells the defamation trial of war veteran Ben Roberts-Smith he regards Australian soldiers as "infidels" and those who were killed by them as "martyrs".

column1: NT declares all of NSW a COVID-19 hotspot as it reopens to VIC and SA
column2: The NT Chief Health Officer makes a "pre-emptive" move in declaring regional NSW a COVID-19 hotspot amid rising cases in the state, while revoking the declarations for Victoria and South Australia from later tonight.

column1: Dieter Brummer, and why it's OK to mourn a celebrity you never met
column2: Fans of Home and Away star Dieter Brummer have been shocked to learn of the actor's death at the age of 45, but they can help each other deal with the collective grief, an expert says.

column1: Mother of dead toddler Mason Jet Lee granted parole
column2: After serving time for manslaughter and child cruelty over the death of her son in 2016, Parole Board Queensland agrees to release Annemarree Lee subject to a number of conditions, saying they are satisfied her risk of reoffending is reduced "to an acceptable level".

column1: Miami building collapse final death toll at 98, after last missing person is identified
column2: Authorities identify the final victim of the condo collapse in Florida, more than a month after the 12-storey building crumbled in the middle of the night.

column1: Here are the new COVID restrictions in Victoria from tomorrow
column2: The five reasons to leave home have been dumped as Victoria eases out of lockdown five, but a number of restrictions will remain in place for at least another two weeks.

column1: Kaylee McKeown breaks the Olympic record to win 100m backstroke gold
column2: Rising Australian star Kaylee McKeown is now an Olympic champion, blitzing home to win the 100m backstroke final with an Olympic record time.

column1: 'What a lovely zero-case day': SA to emerge from lockdown after no new COVID cases detected
column2: There have been no new cases of COVID-19 recorded in South Australia overnight, allowing the state to emerge from its seven-day lockdown just after midnight.

column1: Dean Boxall is the talk of the Tokyo Olympics, but who is Ariarne Titmus's enigmatic coach?
column2: Ariarne Titmus's coach Dean Boxall has risen to internet stardom after his wild celebration went viral on Monday. A peek into his backstory reveals his spirited antics aren't at all out of character.

column1: Steady on Queensland, Titmus is a Tassie girl
column2: As Australia celebrates Olympic golden girl Ariarne Titmus, Tasmanians have gently reminded whoever will listen that the swimmer hails from the island state.

column1: Britney Spears makes formal request to remove and replace her father as conservator of her estate
column2: The pop star launches a legal bid to remove her father from a controversial guardianship controlling her finances and replace him with an independent accountant.

column1: COVID spreads in hospital as NSW records worst day of Delta outbreak
column2: NSW records 172 new locally acquired COVID-19 cases with an outbreak at Liverpool Hospital spreading with two nurses, a student nurse and eight patients testing positive.

column1: Sandstorm engulfs north-west Chinese city within minutes
column2: It takes minutes for a heavy sandstorm to wreak havoc in the ancient Silk Road city of Dunhuang in north-western China.

column1: Sydney apartment block under police guard after six positive COVID cases
column2: Residents are locked down inside a Blacktown apartment building after a number of positive cases were confirmed, and police stand guard outside to make sure public health orders are followed.

column1: Bipartisan leadership needed to quell anti-lockdown sentiment, experts warn
column2: Academics say a lack of bipartisan leadership has contributed to anti-lockdown and anti-vaccination sentiment, urging politicians to present a united front and treat protesters with empathy to curb their dissatisfaction.

column1: British court reopens $9.4 billion lawsuit against BHP over deadly dam collapse in Brazil
column2: The collapse in 2015 of the Fundao dam, owned by a joint venture between BHP and Brazilian mining giant Vale, killed 19 people and obliterated villages as a torrent of more than 40 million cubic metres of mining waste swept through.

column1: When poker machines were turned back on after COVID-19 lockdowns problem gambling skyrocketed
column2: Since lockdowns were lifted Queenslanders have been pumping more money into pokies than ever before — and up to half of those gamblers are addicted, advocates say.

column1: 'It's not safe in here': Hotel quarantine health fears grow for couple after another guest gets the virus
column2: A couple in quarantine in the same Brisbane hotel where the latest leaked COVID-19 case came from say they fear for their safety. One of the women is claustrophobic and has doctor's evidence she has a condition that she needs fresh air.
column3: Rory Callinan, Nibir Khan, and Lexy Hamilton-Smith

column1: How financially literate are you? Take this quiz to find out
column2: Financial products are getting increasingly complicated, and it's getting tougher to stay on top of regulations that govern what can happen to your money. So we made this quiz to test how much you know.

column1: 'So laborious': JobSaver payment scheme for COVID-19 lockdown cops scathing reviews
column2: It's designed to provide NSW employers with much-needed cash to stay afloat, but some businesses complain they're finding the application process for the COVID-19 JobSaver payment clunky and confusing.

column1: Bipartisan support for rapid COVID-19 tests to be used for frontline workers
column2: Rapid COVID-19 tests, similar to home pregnancy tests, should be used to assess frontline workers, according to a growing number of health experts and politicians across party lines.

column1: As unis cut Asian studies programs experts say 'we need more engagement with Asia, not less'
column2: Australia's universities are cutting back on Asia specific programs in the wake of the pandemic, threatening the nation's ability to understand, engage and do business with the region, experts say.

column1: Do sudden, sharp lockdowns help to curb the Delta COVID-19 variant? This epidemiologist thinks so
column2: Every mainland Australian state, except New South Wales, has now used so-called "snap lockdowns" to halt widespread infections. So what can we learn about how lockdowns have curbed the Delta COVID-19 variant in our major cities?

column1: Under 30s in NSW hardest hit by the COVID-19 Delta strain
column2: Data from NSW Health shows the highly infectious Delta variant is behaving differently to previous strains by infecting more younger people, including small children.

column1: There may be no fans, but the Olympics atmosphere is still awesome
column2: There are no crowds at the Tokyo Olympics, leaving cavernous venues appear cold and empty, and yet, the atmosphere is still surprisingly awesome, writes Tracey Holmes in Tokyo.

column1: Feel like prices are going up by more than the data says? You're not alone
column2: It would be wise to take the CPI figure released on Wednesday seriously. It probably does a better job of recording changes in our cost of living than we'd do ourselves, writes Peter Martin.

column1: Meet two of the youngest recipients of the Pfizer vaccine — and one is just 10 months' old
column2: While Australia has become the latest country to approve the Pfizer vaccine for children aged 12 and over, the US has already been having trials for babies and young children.

column1: US police officers open hearing into Capitol riot by speaking of racial slurs, threats and fears of their own deaths
column2: Capitol and DC police officers testify of brutal violence, taunts, and racial abuse they faced as hundreds of Trump supporters breached the Capitol and sent politicians running for their lives.

column1: Gold Coast Suns take Charlie Rowbottom with AFLW top draft pick
column2: The Victorian teenager, regarded as a bright midfield prospect, will head north to play with the expansion club in the 2022 AFLW season.

column1: Explosion at German chemical plant kills one, four still missing

column1: Man charged over US massage parlour massacre pleads guilty to four of eight shooting deaths

column1: COVID-19 close contacts warned against 'bailing early' from isolation period

column1: 'We can't pay $35,000': The only way off virus-hit Bali is by private jet, so this Aussie family is stuck

column1: 'Too large, too much': Hobart City Council says no to cable car bid for kunanyi/Mount Wellington

column1: Reigning Olympic champion Kyle Chalmers wins through to Tokyo semi-finals

column1: 'I have to focus on my mental health': Simone Biles reveals why she pulled out of team gymnastics final

column1: Star kayaker Jessica Fox still chasing gold, but adds bronze to growing collection
column2: Jessica Fox has been gathering world championship titles for years, but three Olympics in she is yet to strike gold.

column1: Your daily guide to the Games: Swimming finals, Olyroos and Boomers headline Wednesday action

column1: Matildas vs USA descended into a Simpsons meme, but it was just what the Australians needed

column1: 'Armageddon' as more than 2 million Sydney workers hit by lockdown expansion

column2: Carlo Stewart, 31, was killed during a street brawl that involved nine people in North Booval.

column1: Drug cartel doubled price of cocaine imports after Operation Ironside, AFP says
column2: AFP Commissioner Reece Kershaw says crime gangs are adapting after major drug busts, and that "lawyers, accountants and some government officials" have helped cartels for a cut.

column1: Simone Biles withdraws from Tokyo all-around competition to focus on her mental health
column2: Simone Biles will not defend the title she won in Rio in 2016, with USA Gymnastics saying she is "prioritising her wellbeing".

column1: Hospital gives 'ultra-low' COVID jabs, 159 people asked to come back for 'booster' shot
column2: Six people may have been given a Pfizer shot twice diluted with saline and may not be properly vaccinated, Queensland Health says.

column1: Everything you need to know about NSW's COVID lockdown financial support

column1: Should Australians be told how the vaccine rollout is progressing in their community?
column2: Some experts and community leaders argue more detailed information could encourage people to get vaccinated and highlight areas where accessibility is difficult, but not everyone is convinced.

column1: Rescue duck Sally is reunited with family after missing for 10 months

column1: Best bits of Tokyo Olympics day 5: Australia's golden hour sees team equal best single day at Games

column1: Doing them slowly: How Slow-Mo Joe can help the Boomers redeem Rio horror
column2: Patty Mills is perhaps the most legendary Boomer, but if the Aussies are to win their first Olympic basketball medal, he's going to need the best version of sharpshooter Joe Ingles by his side.

column1: Prisoner gets 30 years for strangling cell mate with clothes line in fight over TV

column1: Six more COVID cases emerge in outbreak on ship moored at Fremantle Port
column2: Six more crew members on board the ship the MV Darya Krishna docked in Fremantle test positive for COVID-19.

column1: Lachlan is fully vaccinated, tested for COVID and stuck at the NSW border

column1: Titmus versus Ledecky 2.0 done. And we've still got 3.0 to come

column1: Inquest into massive Namadgi bushfire to focus on why army delayed reporting the blaze's location
column2: The ACT Coroner will examine how the fire began and focus on the 45 minutes that passed between a helicopter sparking the blaze and firefighters learning of its location.

column1: Athletes need to stop pretending everything is OK
column2: Simone Biles's shock exit from the Olympics and Liz Cambage's withdrawal have been pivotal in discussions around athlete wellbeing. Now they have spoken, it's time for us to listen.

column1: What are k numbers, and how do they explain COVID superspreading?

column1: Why Greater Sydney's COVID lockdown is likely to be extended again

column1: Frogs are suddenly dying in huge numbers in Australia. We don't know why

column1: Why real estate voyeurism still runs hot even while houses slip further out of reach

column3: Olivia Willis, Annika Blau, and Joel Werner

column1: 'He's just MIA when we really need somebody': Morrison's COVID response brings back unpleasant memories
column2: A seemingly never-ending lockdown has left voters ruminating on the Prime Minister's past disappointments, writes David Speers.

column1: Australia's miners powering the electric vehicle charge

column1: NSW emissions reductions 'totally undone' by coal mine approvals, analysis suggests

column1: Gesti tested positive for COVID a day before giving birth. Three weeks later, the virus took her life
column2: The number of pregnant women who are dying with COVID-19 in Indonesia is anticipated to increase, as expectant mothers opt for voluntary c-sections or give birth at home out of fear they will catch the virus at the hospital.

column1: Here are the ways cyber criminals are hacking businesses in a pandemic

column1: What is a rapid antigen test? How is it different from other COVID-19 tests?
column2: NSW has announced plans to commence rapid antigen testing in some settings, but how are the tests different from the PCR tests we're used to?

column1: Looted artefacts in the National Gallery of Australia to be returned to India

column1: Beyond the glittering lights of the Olympics, this Tokyo doctor has a warning: 'We're close to a collapse'

column1: 'No hope' for five missing after German chemical blast

column1: McKeon breaks Olympic 100m freestyle record, Titmus to challenge for third gold
column2: Emma McKeon's outstanding campaign continues with a new Olympic mark. And she and Ariarne Titmus will have the chance of winning more gold in the 4x200 metres freestyle relay.

column1: 'We must change our system': Tasmania to end its ties with contentious youth program
column2: The Tasmanian government has committed to stop sending troubled youth to a controversial residential care program based in the Northern Territory following allegations of abuse.

column1: Your daily guide to the Games: Swimming finals, hockey and golf headline Thursday action
column2: There are another five finals in the pool on Thursday, while the Australian women's rugby sevens team begin the defence of their Olympic title. Here are the events to watch out for on day 6.

column1: Court to decide if NT police officer accused of murder can argue he was not 'criminally liable'
column2: The full bench of the NT Supreme Court has been asked to decide whether Constable Zachary Rolfe can argue in his upcoming murder trial that he was not criminally liable for Kumanjayi Walker’s death because he was acting in “good faith” as a police officer during the incident.

column1: Boomers continue bright start with tight win over Italy, Hockeyroos remain unbeaten
column2: The Australian men's basketball team makes it two from two to start their tournament, winning 86-83 against Italy, while the Hockeyroos get past host nation Japan 1-0.

column1: Wests Tigers player James Roberts fined, banned for one game after COVID breach
column2: Centre James Roberts is fined $7,500 and banned for one game for failing to comply with a Queensland public health directive.

column1: Japanese women celebrate German gymnasts' full body suits at Olympics
column2: The full body suits being worn by Germany's Olympic gymnasts have struck a chord with Japanese women, who have been taking to social media to share bitter stories about clothes they have been forced to wear.

column1: Jury finds woman and alleged lover guilty of murdering husband
column2: A jury finds an Adelaide woman and her alleged lover guilty of murdering her husband because "he was in the way", while another man is found guilty of manslaughter.

column1: Nathan Gunn thought his last year of schooling would be the best year of his life but then COVID happened
column2: This former Eltham High School student says the first few months of 2020 was "amazing", studying with his friends and planning schoolies. But then the uncertainty and loneliness of being in lockdown left him feeling depressed. And he is not the only one.

column1: Woman dies in hospital after alleged 'serious domestic assault'
column2: A 37-year-old woman dies after sustaining "life-threatening head injuries" in an alleged domestic assault on South Australia's Yorke Peninsula earlier this week.

column1: The competition is a world away, but these Games seem surprisingly close to home

column1: Chinese billionaire jailed for 18 years for organising an attack on officials
column2: Sun Dawu, known throughout China after being charged with illegal fundraising in 2003, is among 20 defendants to stand trial after stopping a state-owned enterprise from demolishing a company building.

column1: Out of service and out of patience: Telco review to hear 'warts and all' complaints
column2: Rural and regional Australians are set to tell a federal review committee that they feel like second-class citizens because their mobile phone coverage is virtually "non-existent".

column1: NSW Police requests help from Defence Force amid COVID compliance crackdown
column2: NSW asks the Australia Defence Force for an extra 300 personnel as police ramp up their COVID compliance operations with extra powers and increased fines.

column1: Jess Fox claims elusive Olympic gold with victory in C1 canoe slalom final
column2: Jess Fox finally has the Olympic gold medal that had thus far eluded her as she wins the canoe slalom competition at Tokyo 2020.

column1: Sydney GP blasted after charging $370 for Pfizer vaccine 'consultations'
column2: Health Minister Greg Hunt says he'll "throw the book" at a GP clinic in Campsie, in Sydney's south west, that's been asking patients to pay hundreds of dollars for vaccine consultations before receiving their Pfizer jabs.

column1: Einstein was right (again): Astronomers detect light from behind black hole

column1: $80m lottery could boost vaccine rate under new plan
column2: Grattan Institute has released modelling that shows incentives like a national lottery could help Australia improve its vaccination rate.

column1: Record $104m disaster recovery package announced for WA
column2: The largest disaster recovery package in Western Australia's history has been announced for communities impacted by Cyclone Seroja.

column1: For every standalone home built in Canberra, five units are going up — and it's not helping house prices
column2: The price gap between buying an apartment and a house is 74.8 per cent in Canberra, the largest of all capital cities — according to the latest research from CoreLogic.

column1: Few of us can know what it is like to do what Simone Biles does
column2: Simone Biles faced criticism from some quarters over her Tokyo Olympics withdrawal, but few can understand the weight she carries for black athletes.

column1: Man murdered woman during argument after paying $15,000 for an arranged marriage, Perth court told
column2: A man murdered a woman whose family he paid $15,000 to marry, during an argument at their Perth home about their "loveless" six-week relationship, the WA Supreme Court hears.

column1: Pfizer vaccine reallocation met with caution in regional NSW
column2: While regional communities agree for the need to get HSC students in Sydney back to school and to attempt to contain the spread of the virus, there are fears about the consequences.
column3: Kate Aubrey, Adriane Reardon, and Xanthe Gregory

column1: Dog vs drone: Could a 'sky shepherd' be better at mustering than a sheepdog?
column2: Working dogs are synonymous with life on the land, but technology from the sky could soon be moving in on their territory and changing the future of farming.

column1: Australian athletics squad members in the clear after COVID scare in Tokyo
column2: Members of Australia's athletics squad in Tokyo are cleared to return to their regular routines after isolating in response to US pole vaulter Sam Kendricks testing positive to COVID-19.

column1: The NRL has a COVID bubble, so why doesn't the music industry?
column2: Musicians unable to ply their trade are floating the idea of live music bubble, but some in the industry say a vaccine passport would be a better option.

column1: False-positive cases of COVID-19 recorded in the ACT, but no cases confirmed
column2: ACT Health confirms 10 people returned false-positive results of COVID-19 in Canberra, but says there are no confirmed cases of the virus.

column1: Live exports suspended over sheep welfare concerns in Jordan
column2: An Australian exporter says its live export sales to Jordan has been stopped due to "unacceptable conduct" in a breach of animal welfare rules.

column1: 'I'm more than my accomplishments': Biles thanks supporters after withdrawing from gymnastics events
column2: Gymnastics superstar Simone Biles says the support she has received has made her realise she is much more than just her athletic achievements.

column1: Fresh concern at COVID in wastewater just as NSW region emerges from lockdown

column3: Mollie Gorman, Joanna Woodburn, and Shannon Corvo

column1: How many active COVID cases are there in your NSW suburb?
column2: Search your postcode to see how many active COVID cases there are in your suburb and track how the situation has changed over the last 14 days.

column1: Australia wins bronze in shock Olympic women's 4x200m relay upset
column2: Despite being the fastest qualifiers and the heavy favourites, Australia has fallen short in the 4x200 metres women's relay.

column1: Everything you need to know about Sydney's new COVID restrictions

column1: Man sentenced for taking part in kidnap, torture of elderly man lured on Grindr
column2: A man who helped his brother torture an elderly man after luring him back to a Murray Bridge home using a fake Grindr profile could be released from jail on parole in just over a year.

column1: Family of Australian prisoner detained in virus-hit Myanmar prison study new photos of him for clues

column1: The key failure that could extend Sydney's lockdown until September

column1: Matildas to take on Great Britain in titanic Tokyo quarter-final
column2: It's a monumental moment for a Matildas group that needs to capitalise on a special generation of players either with an Olympic medal in Tokyo or a legitimate tilt at the title at the World Cup here in Australia in 2023.

column1: Bec Henderson is the young Aussie race walker you didn't know about at the Tokyo Games
column2: When Bec Henderson was young people would get excited if she came second last in her race. Now, she's preparing for the 20 kilometre race walk as the youngest competitor in the Tokyo field.

column1: Albanese sent a clear message this week — with echoes of a former foe
column2: Anthony Albanese this week sent a clear message — he intends to use John Howard's 1996 model as his strategic guide to the election, writes Michelle Grattan.

column1: The advice on AstraZeneca has changed a lot, but data shows it's effective where it counts

column1: Indy airs, inverts and feeble grinds: These are the tricks that will grab Olympic glory
column2: The skateboarding community is split over whether the Olympics is good for their sport. But, for some, the benefits are already starting to flow.

column1: From flowering weeds to feral cats and fire ants: These are the introduced pests costing Australia the most

column1: Here's the latest medal tally from the Tokyo Olympics

column1: This Chinese city wants to snuff out a Delta outbreak in days. Here's why Sydney won’t try their tactics
column2: China's health authorities, like their counterparts everywhere, are facing a much tougher challenge — the fast-spreading Delta variant. So far, they appear to be holding back a surge, but could there be any lessons for Australia?

column1: 'This isn't a game of Monopoly where you can roll the dice and avoid the income tax box', warns ATO

column1: What do COVID vaccine passport systems look like around the world?
column2: Countries with relatively high vaccination rates have started rolling out various versions of vaccine passports. What do they look like and are there similar plans for Australia?

column1: More than four months after blocking the Suez Canal cargo ship finally reaches destination

column1: National Cabinet will today see a set of numbers that might just chart a path out of the pandemic

column2: About half a dozen beach-goers helped the whale swim back to sea earlier this morning, but it became beached again just before midday.

column1: George Bailey appointed Cricket Australia's chief selector

column1: In these grim times of lockdowns and lives delayed, Australia's swimmers have lifted our spirits

column1: Simone Biles withdraws from individual floor exercise final

column1: Best protection from tick-borne ehrlichiosis is prevention, says flying vet tackling surge
column2: An overwhelmed outback vet dealing with dozens of sick and dying dogs is pleading with travellers and tourists to be aware of a deadly tick-borne disease that can be prevented.

column1: Australia's Logan Martin claims Olympic gold in freestyle BMX

column1: How this Alice Springs primary school is strengthening culture one step at a time

column1: Queensland has recorded its highest daily number of community COVID cases in almost a year. See the exposure sites list
column2: Contact tracers are investigating more possible COVID-19 exposure sites in Queensland. See the full list of locations as they are released.

column1: Kate witnessed her first death when she was eight – now, she wants to help others die well
column2: Death is inevitable, but a growing number of end-of-life doulas across Australia want to support and empower people to die well.

column1: Former NSW MP won't be charged over alleged rape of sex worker

column1: Gold in 50m freestyle and 4x100m medley relay put McKeon firmly in Olympic history books
column2: Emma McKeon wins two more gold medals in Tokyo, taking her medal tally at this Games to seven — the equal most by any woman in any sport in Olympic history.

column1: What is a night at the Tokyo 2020 Olympics athletics really like?
column2: Superhuman performances still bringing joy and an electric atmosphere inside the Tokyo Olympics track and field stadium despite the crowd element missing.

column1: Twelve nursing home residents test positive for COVID-19 after staff member worked while infectious
column2: Twelve residents of a Sydney nursing home are taken to hospital as "a precaution" after testing positive for COVID-19.

column1: 'You would be my daughter's aunt': Sister's grief overwhelming three decades on
column2: Decades after Frauke Grunwaldt's older sister Nancy vanished from Tasmania's east coast, Frauke writes about how different her life would be if her sister were still by her side.

column1: Masks are blocking more than COVID-19 for people with disabilities
column2: While masks are a vital barrier against the spread of COVID-19, they are also complicating the lives of people with disabilities, some of whom are calling for a permit system to prove their exemptions to the rules to people who don't believe them.

column1: Pet food crisis deepens with spotlight on NT horse meat, questions over recalls
column2: Horse meat from the Northern Territory is being investigated as the cause of 21 pet dog deaths in Victoria amid a worsening scandal which now includes up to 30 Melbourne retailers.

column1: Lance jumped at the chance to get his COVID vaccine, but others don't find it easy to understand public health messages
column2: A medical team is travelling around Tasmania to help vaccinate the state's homeless and vulnerable populations, but there are calls for public health and vaccine information to be made easier to understand for those with low literacy.

column1: The Queensland couple who have given more than 50 senior dogs a forever home
column2: Karen and Jamie Goullet's home has been a happy retreat for senior dogs north of Brisbane for 15 years.

column1: 'Things are going to get worse': US will not lock down despite Delta variant surge
column2: The United States will not lock down again to curb COVID-19, but "things are going to get worse" as the Delta variant fuels a surge in cases, Dr Anthony Fauci says.

column1: Parent of COVID-positive child fears Delta strain unable to be contained

column1: Remote learning could hurt future job prospects of NSW students, expert warns
column2: Thousands of students are engaging in remote learning without access to a computer, smartphone or the internet, causing concern for parents and experts it will affect their ability to be "job ready".

column1: 'This virus is hell': Sydney family reveals what it's like to battle COVID-19
column2: Melissa Green and her partner Dion Mason are usually fit and healthy, but both ended up in hospital after contracting COVID-19, which he describes as feeling like "a 200-kilogram man standing on your chest".

column1: China's war on everything turns towards its own tycoons, with Jack Ma being a prime example
column2: The aggressive economic approach the Chinese Communist Party has taken to its perceived enemies is also being used against some of its most wealthy citizens, writes Ian Verrender.

column1: Australia's pandemic focus shifts north as south-east Queensland joins Sydney in lockdown

column1: Domestic violence services are failing women with disabilities
column2: Domestic violence services are inaccessible to many women with disabilities, say advocates, and this needs to addressed urgently.

column1: NSW is adapting its COVID vaccine strategy. Should we be diverting vaccines there too?

column1: Meet the vaccine refusers who decided to get the COVID jab

column1: Investors helped by housing tax breaks pile into property market as prices rise

column1: Roya and her son slept in a park while trying to find housing – and they're not alone
column2: Refugees and migrants are overrepresented among the homeless in Australia. Advocates say it's a "hidden problem", with many not knowing who to turn to for help.

column1: 'We should have included Luc': Michael Jordan reveals his regret for Luc Longley's omission from The Last Dance doco
column2: For decades Luc Longley has remained largely silent about his years with Michael Jordan's legendary Chicago Bulls team.  Now he reveals his disappointment about being omitted from The Last Dance documentary and how he made peace with his basketball past.

column1: Myanmar's military ruler Min Aung Hlaing appoints himself Prime Minister
column2: Myanmar's military ruler Min Aung Hlaing takes the role of Prime Minister in a newly formed caretaker government, state media reports.

column1: Rohan Browning may have missed out on golden glory but Peter Bol will chase it in the men's 800m final

column1: Nearly 400 rescued from dangerous, overcrowded migrant boat in Mediterranean

column1: Opening corner carnage in Hungary leads to Esteban Ocon's first F1 victory

column1: Lamont Marcell Jacobs wins Italy's first 100m gold medal in athletics

column1: Your daily guide to the Games: Matildas and Hockeyroos headline Monday's action

column1: 'Losing to Taiwan was a disgrace': Chinese trolls react to Taiwan beating China in Badminton

column3: Emily Sakzewski, Georgina Piper, Colin Gourlay, and Tim Leslie

column1: Woman who spoke out about 'rogue' COVID policy in Sydney hospitals sacked

column2: The completion of the long-delayed electrification of Adelaide's Gawler train line has now been shunted off until 2022, angering commuters who have been forced onto substitute buses since last year.

column1: Three men acquitted of attempted murder over shooting of former police detective

column1: Alex Porter praised for 'courageous' team pursuit ride as investigation starts into bike failure

column1: Andrew Hoy's mum still gets a thrill out of watching her son

column1: Minister says eligible NT kids may be able to get vaccinated at school

column1: 'A tremendous and overwhelming honour': Orthodox rabbi becomes Supreme Court judge in Australian first

column1: Hundreds of health workers stuck in isolation by Brisbane COVID outbreak

column1: 'I really miss my Dad': What it's like to be a child in a COVID-19 quarantine ward

column1: Sydney renters fearful of COVID-19 infection during open house inspections

column1: Comedy 'written by bots' is still one big joke
column2: Scientists are trying to give artifical intelligence systems the gift of comedy, with hilariously strange results.

column1: How Afterpay went from zero to $39 billion thanks to loyal millennials, powerful lobbyists and COVID
column2: Afterpay's Anthony Eisen and Nick Molnar have taken the group from zero to $39 billion in just six years but it hasn't been an easy ride.

column1: Own shares or want to buy some? Pay attention for the next few weeks

column1: What 6 million vaccinations will mean for Greater Sydney's lockdown
column2: NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian wants 6 million vaccines administered by the end of this month — but even if that's achieved, this expert says it could mean little changes to the state's lengthy COVID-19 lockdown.

column1: Emma McKeon joins list of Olympians blazing trail for other women

column1: A Senator has forged his own COVID-19 vaccine certificate to prove the system is broken

column1: How Operation COVID Shield might be executed later this year
column2: The Prime Minister announced Operation COVID Shield in June, now some of the details about what it entails are released.

column1: Paying Australians $300 to get vaccinated would be value for money

column1: Investigation finds New York Governor Andrew Cuomo sexually harassed multiple women

column1: Worse than the Great Depression, this nation is in the most dire collapse the world has seen in 150 years

column1: South Korea warns that North Korea is facing food crisis
column2: Major trouble is building in the secretive state according to South Korea, and this time it has nothing to do with the threat of war but a problem it has faced before.

column1: 'Your stolen money is no good here': The message MPs want to send to human rights abusers
column2: Some in Canberra are asking why the federal government has been slow to act on human rights — and the answer could be found in Australia's worsening relationship with China.

column1: Peter Doherty talks vaccines, National Cabinet's roadmap out of lockdown, and kids getting the jab
column2: Peter Doherty has backed the plan to give kids COVID vaccines and says National Cabinet's new roadmap out of lockdowns is "not the 10 commandments handed down to Moses".

column1: One graph shows why COVID vigilance will be a challenge in the months ahead
