column1: Cows, houses and restaurants. This is how Indonesia is rewarding badminton gold medallists
column2: Five cows, a meatball restaurant, and a new house are among prizes offered to Indonesian badminton gold medallists Greysia Polii and Apriyani Rahayu when they return home from Tokyo.

column1: Elaine Thompson-Herah becomes first woman to win Olympic sprint double twice in athletics
column2: The Jamaican creates history by completing the 100m-200m double at consecutive Olympics following a stunning victory in the half-lap event in Tokyo.

column1: Aldi, Coles, Foodworks, IGA and Woolworths urge NSW shoppers to follow COVID-safe rules
column2: Several major supermarket chains in New South Wales issue a joint statement urging people to be respectful of workers and to observe the rules for checking in and wearing masks in their shops.

column1: Mills leads Boomers to showdown with Team USA as Kookaburras win their way into hockey's gold medal match
column2: The Boomers book a date with Team USA as they chase Olympic glory, while the Kookaburras head to the gold medal match for the first time since 2004.

column1: Australian Olympians accused of 'unacceptable behaviour' on flight home from Tokyo
column2: The Australian Olympic Committee condemns the alleged poor behaviour of members of the men's rugby sevens and football squads on their return to Sydney.

column1: Murder investigation launched after Australian woman's body found in Georgia
column2: The federal government confirmed the death of the woman and said an officer from the Australian embassy in Turkey has now travelled to Tbilisi.

column1: Your daily guide to the Games: Aussies to wrap up sailing gold medal, Opals face the US
column2: Mat Belcher and Will Ryan are set to be crowned Olympic champions in the men's 470 class and the Opals will take on the US in the quarter-finals of the women's basketball. Here are the Olympic events to watch out for on day 12.

column1: Fremantle, Scarborough and Subiaco among the list of exposure sites visited by COVID-positive man
column2: Here's what we know so far about the places visited by a potentially COVID-positive man in Perth.

column1: 'It just blew us away': How an autism assistance dog is helping 6yo Lucas and his family
column2: Requiring human touch to stay asleep, six-year-old Lucas Bugg used to sleep in his parents' bed — that was until assistance dog Vinnie arrived last month after years of campaigning.

column1: Central Land Council offers cash incentive for staff to get jab
column2: The Northern Territory's Central Land Council says 50 per cent of its staff are now fully vaccinated, compared to just 2 per cent before a $500 cash incentive was introduced five weeks ago.
column3: Saskia Mabin, Justin Fenwick, and Stewart Brash

column1: Barbie launches six new dolls celebrating female scientists — including an Australian doctor
column2: Australian doctor Kirby White has many accolades, but she now shares an honour with Beyonce, Marilyn Monroe and Eleanor Roosevelt: a Barbie doll in her likeness.
column3: Saskia Mabin, Justin Fenwick, and Stewart Brash

column1: Is it time to vaccinate young children? Experts say they already 'know the drill'
column2: With more than half of the cases in Queensland's Delta outbreak 19 and younger, a disease expert says giving the jab to younger kids is worth considering.

column1: CAAMA set to emerge from a year under special administration
column2: Australia's largest First Nations media body will soon emerge from a year under special administration after the earlier discovery of escalating debts, funding misuse and unpaid royalties.

column1: Costly, quiet, clean and lonely: How the Tokyo Games are different for our athletes
column2: Competing at the Olympic Games in a pandemic has been an unusual experience for these Aussie athletes.

column1: Opals out of Tokyo Olympics after big loss against USA
column2: Australia's women's basketball team ends their Olympic run in the quarter-finals for the second straight time, beaten 79-55 by Team USA in Tokyo.

column1: Royal Darwin Hospital hits capacity, prompting cancellation of elective surgery
column2: Elective surgery has been cancelled at Royal Darwin Hospital, where patients numbers have hit capacity for the second time this year.

column1: Aussies Mathew Belcher and Will Ryan win Olympic gold in men's 470 sailing
column2: Mathew Belcher and Will Ryan win the medal race to seal victory in the men’s 470 sailing at the Tokyo Olympics. It's Australia's 15th gold.

column1: Perth man returns weak positive COVID result, no lockdown likely Health Minister says
column2: WA Premier Mark McGowan says a very weak positive case has been detected in a FIFO worker, who may have been infectious in the community in Perth.

column1: South Koreans say a Chinese Olympian was swearing. She says it was just 'bad pronunciation'
column2: South Korea's badminton association is lodging a formal complaint after a Chinese player appears to repeatedly and loudly swear in Mandarin during a match at the Tokyo Games.

column1: Retail association slams direction to avoid online shopping
column2: Government pleas for south-east Queenslanders to avoid unnecessary online shopping during the lockdown has prompted strong criticism that the retail industry could be decimated.

column1: 'Breathtakingly stupid': Man who escaped hotel quarantine using bed sheets escapes more jail time
column2: A man who escaped hotel quarantine in Perth by climbing out of his fourth-floor room and shimmying down tied-together bed sheets is fined $4,500 but avoids spending more time in jail.

column1: Japanese skateboarders dominate epic park final, Poppy Olsen finishes fifth
column2: Young skaters from Japan have soared to victory in the women's park competition, with hometown heroes Sakura Yosozumi and Kokona Hiraki clinching gold and silver.

column1: Boeing halts Starliner space launch after latest glitch
column2: US aerospace giant Boeing continues to face setbacks in its effort to launch that Starliner capsule, with the latest system glitch coming a week after an incident in which the International Space Station was briefly thrust out of control.

column1: The giant centipedes roaming Phillip Island eating 3,700 seabird chicks each year
column2: Giant bird-eating centipedes may sound like something out of a science-fiction film — but they're not and they can kill and eat up to 3,700 seabird chicks each year.

column1: Victoria to offer thousands more Pfizer jab appointments but demand outstripping supply
column2: About 60,000 extra appointments will be available for the Pfizer vaccine this month, on top of the hundreds of thousands already on offer.

column1: Frankie first fed money into the pokies when she was 16. They became her 'best friend'
column2: Frankie Atkinson developed an unhealthy relationship with pokies early in her life and fed thousands into the machines. Now there are calls for the tax Tasmania raises on poker machine losses to exclusively fund problem gambling services.

column1: Sydney's youngest COVID-19 victim 'just got married a few months ago'
column2: Friends and family of Aude Alaskar, who died "suddenly" from COVID-19 just months after getting married, say the news has left them with “breaking hearts”.

column1: Homicide squad interview 17yo over 18yo woman's death from serious injuries in southern Perth
column2: An 18-year-old Perth woman dies after attending a medical centre with serious injuries and a 17-year-old boy is assisting police with enquiries.

column1: Worker offers boss $14k of house savings as fear and anger grow in lockdown
column2: Businesses and residents on the Gold Coast are growing increasingly frustrated and confused as the state desperately tries to get its outbreak under control before the scheduled end of lockdown.

column1: New case of COVID-19 a teacher at school in Melbourne's west
column2: Authorities are still trying to confirm how a teacher at Al-Taqwa College in Truganina caught the virus as the person's household contacts are urgently tested.

column1: Coronavirus vaccine coverage worse in vulnerable areas in Sydney and Melbourne
column2: Parts of Australian cities most vulnerable to serious Delta outbreaks have vaccine coverage well below the national average — and it could be an ongoing problem.

column1: Rainbow-coloured 'Kids' Bridge' gives sick Perth children the chance to get outside
column2: A brightly coloured footbridge linking Perth Children's Hospital to Kings Park has opened, a decade after a group of sick children first suggested the idea.

column1: Socioeconomics, culture or is it just too hard to get? Why COVID vaccine rates are low in Ipswich and Logan
column2: New data released by the federal government shows regions south-west of Brisbane have some of the lowest COVID-19 vaccination rates in the country. Experts say it could be for a number of reasons.

column1: NSW Health gives up on publishing its venues of concern on social media, because there are too many to list
column2: NSW Health says its regular list of venues of concern vanished from social media earlier this week because it had simply become too long, as contact tracers deal with hundreds of new cases every day.

column1: 'Only a couple of pay cheques away': Many essential workers on brink of homelessness in capital cities
column2: Social housing advocates say the federal government is asleep at the wheel on social housing and that new research shows essential workers now find housing unaffordable across most areas in Australia.

column1: These Australians were 'devastated' to leave their husband and father in Fiji, but COVID left them little choice
column2: As the COVID-19 outbreak in Fiji worsens, people are making the difficult decision to leave their family, home and business behind for the safety of Australia.

column1: Closing the Gap measures to get $1 billion, as Aboriginal leaders warn the plan 'has to work'
column2: Indigenous children in crisis "can't wait" for the nation to close the gap, Aboriginal organisations have warned, as the federal government details its plan to address rising inequality in communities.

column1: The jabbed and unjabbed could soon be treated differently. Is that legal? And what will it look like?
column2: A COVID-19 "vaccine passport" is coming, and rules about access to businesses, masks wearing and even public transport could all be very different for people depending on whether they are vaccinated or not. Here's what you need to know.

column1: Melike and Ibrahim try not to pay or receive interest. Here's how they do that.
column2: Australia's finance sector is tapping into the Islamic market, with one of the country's biggest lenders today launching a Sharia compliant loan and smaller institutions vying to become the first bank for the nation's Muslim population.

column1: A million women, one clinic, and the doctor fighting to save it
column2: In Colleen's line of work, doctors need to watch their backs. Her home is under 24-hour surveillance and even her son's identity is kept secret.

column1: After 46 days in isolation, the PM has emerged with a COVID plan that could decide his political fate
column2: Armed with new vaccination targets and the promise of greater freedom, and his political fate tied to achieving vaccination thresholds, Scott Morrison is trying to stir the nation to get a jab, any jab, as quickly as possible. But there are limits, writes David Speers.

column1: Snakes, the CIA and nitric acid: How 'mind-control' experiments came to the University of Sydney
column2: Experiments performed at the University of Sydney set out to see if hypnotised people would engage in anti-social behaviour.

column1: Google 'carefully curating' search results around COVID, researchers say
column2: Researchers are enlisting the help of the public to investigate one of the great mysteries — how does the Google algorithm work?

column1: 'We will not forget or forgive': Lebanese demand that heads roll a year on from Beirut port explosion
column2: Thousands of Lebanese protesters gathered in Beirut to demand accountability from government officials, one year after the devastating explosion that flattened Beirut port and killed over 170 people.

column1: Inside the small Melbourne club that made Peter Bol an Olympic sensation
column2: Justin Rinaldi only started the Fast 8 Track Club a few years ago, but it's quickly becoming a factory for breeding 800m stars like Olympic finalist Peter Bol.

column1: 'Proud is an understatement': Peter Bol's family react to his 800m final
column2: It may not have been the fairytale finish Australia hoped for, but Peter Bol's fourth place in Tokyo is still the best result by an Australian in the men's 800 metres since 1968.

column1: Indonesia passes 100,000 COVID deaths as Delta variant fuels the nation's worst wave
column2: It took Indonesia 14 months to officially record 50,000 deaths from COVID-19, nine weeks later and that number has doubled as the Delta variant wreaks havoc.

column1: Andre De Grasse wins Canada's first 200m athletics gold in 93 years
column2: After claiming a bronze earlier in the Tokyo Olympics, De Grasse wins gold in the men's 200m in the stunning time of 19.62 seconds.

column1: Australia's Genevieve Gregson ruptures Achilles tendon in Tokyo steeplechase final
column2: The three-time Olympian is taken from the track in a wheelchair after sustaining the injury late in the women's 3,000m steeplechase final.

column1: Bol finishes fourth in 800 metres final at Tokyo Olympics
column2: The Australian was leading for much of what was a slow race but was overtaken with 200 metres to go, as Kenyan runner Emmanuel Kipkurui Korir claimed gold.

column1: Your daily guide to the Games: Kookaburras fight for gold, Boomers set for showdown with team USA in semi-final
column2: Australia will fight for another gold medal when the Kookaburras go head-to-head with Belgium in the men's hockey final, while the Boomers take on team USA in the men's semi-final. Here are the Olympic events to watch out for on day 13.

column1: Athens residents told to flee as bushfires rage on city's outskirts
column2: Strong winds and tinder-dry conditions caused by extreme heat are fuelling blazes across Greece, with one fire near the capital forcing the evacuation of thousands.

column1: Man charged with terrorism offences

column1: Olympics highlights: Aussies well-placed going into final days of competition
column2: Catch up on all the best (and most wholesome) highlights from the Tokyo Olympics today.

column1: Two passenger trains collide, killing three people in the Czech Republic

column1: 'Thousands of mice in the roof': Regional families struggle as mouse plague drags on with no end in sight
column2: Farmers first started noticing mice populations growing a year ago. Now it's a full-blown plague, and scientists are struggling to stop it.

column1: ACCC launches legal action against Mercedes-Benz over Takata airbag recall
column2: The consumer watchdog alleges the car maker failed to convey to customers that the airbags posed a risk of serious injury or death.

column1: Countries that commit 'egregious acts' to face travel bans, financial sanctions from Australia
column2: The government agrees to write new laws that would allow Australia to impose financial sanctions and travel bans against countries that commit human rights abuses.

column1: Canberra prisoner sentenced for starting fire in jail cell during Black Summer bushfires
column2: Jordan Beroukas, 24, a prisoner in the Alexander Maconochie Centre, used a bed sheet to start the fire, which resulted in $2,300 of damage.

column1: Australia stopped the Great Barrier Reef being listed as 'in danger' – what happens next?
column2: Australia has succeeded in stopping the Great Barrier Reef being immediately listed as "in danger", but the federal government is under mounting pressure to demonstrate how it's tackling climate change.

column1: Police search for Gold Coast hotel quarantine dodger who was on bail before escape
column2: Police search for a 24-year-old woman who was already on bail for serious offences and who escaped hotel quarantine at Broadbeach.

column1: NSW woman, 34, becomes Australia's seventh AstraZeneca-related death
column2: The Therapeutic Goods Administration says the woman died on Wednesday from a confirmed case of thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome.

column1: Taliqua Clancy and Mariafe Artacho del Solar are about to go where only two other Australians have gone before

column1: Regional NSW's borrowed Pfizer vaccines set to be returned

column1: Boomers lose semi-final to USA despite strong start, but hope remains for bronze
column2: Despite bursting out to an early lead, the Boomers lose their Olympic semi-final match 97-78 to the USA, ending their hopes of a gold medal.

column1: Hillsong leader charged over the concealment of alleged child sex offences
column2: Hillsong leader Brian Houston is charged over the concealment of alleged child sex offences by his father in the 1970s.

column1: Van packed with migrants crashes in southern Texas, killing 10 and badly injuring more

column1: Teenagers face court over breaching COVID-19 directions in Adelaide medi-hotel

column1: Victoria to enter sixth lockdown in response to new mystery cases

column1: Woylies released in Northern Territory after 60-year absence

column1: Unknown WWI Aussie soldier's remains identified after more than a century
column2: For 103 years the remains of an unknown World War I soldier lay in a grave in France, a mystery to historians and to the Australian Army, until now.

column1: Man accused of assault at junior footy match appears in court

column1: 'We gave Taylor the morning off': Walker a no-show at Crows training amid racism probe

column1: The voting age won't be lowered for the next ACT election, but corflutes are set to be banned
column2: The ACT Greens fail in their mission to have the electoral commission investigate lowering the voting age, but succeed in a move that could see the use of corflutes banned.

column1: Keegan Palmer wins gold for Australia in men's park skateboarding at Tokyo

column1: Why are some older Australians still hesitant about booking their vaccine appointment?

column1: 'No jab, no work' policy on table as incentive to ease Sydney lockdown

column1: Covert cameras catch 417 Queensland drivers on first day they're switched on
column2: The new high-tech cameras were turned on last Monday, busting hundreds of motorists on their phones or not wearing seatbelts. Despite flouting the law, they'll get a reprieve for now.

column1: Australian bikie arrested in Greece over alleged involvement in drug syndicate
column2: The man recognised by law enforcement authorities to be the Australian National Lone Wolf president is arrested in Greece over alleged drug and money laundering offences.

column1: How was Tasmania's new COVID case allowed into the state?

column1: 'Take this very seriously': Experts warn of outdoor COVID-19 risk after beach party cases

column1: Imagine losing your only social outlet and not understanding why. For many, that's the reality of lockdowns
column2: The closure of day programs for people with disability has caused serious harm to many clients' mental health, and advocates are worried the pandemic's impact on some of society's most vulnerable will be long term.

column1: 'Voodoo dolls' hurled at Myanmar embassy amid calls for ambassador to reject junta
column2: Activists say they are trying to convey the depth of anger among members of Australia's Myanmar community, who are disappointed the ambassador has not defected from the military junta.

column1: Israeli jets hit targets in Lebanon after rocket fire burns fields in northern Israel

column1: Zena couldn't make ends meet if it wasn't for the 'warm hearts' of volunteers in her community
column2: Amid Sydney's COVID lockdown, members of multicultural communities are helping the vulnerable by distributing food and other essential items.

column1: Rich club has $140 million theatre but would not give $10,000 to a local disability charity
column2: An ABC investigation reveals a multi-million-dollar western Sydney club did not follow recommendations from an advisory group and awarded funds allocated to community causes into other projects.

column1: Pregnant women 'calling and begging' to get Pfizer vaccine
column2: Pregnant women are being denied access to Pfizer COVID-19 vaccines, despite being in a priority group and eligible under phase 1b of the vaccine rollout.

column1: No tattoos, no crime, must 'love the motherland': Beijing has a new zero-tolerance policy for China's stars

column1: Hundreds protest against Victorian COVID lockdown, leading to clashes with police

column1: Ashley Moloney secures Australia's first Olympic decathlon medal with bronze
column2: Spurred on by his teammate Cedric Dubler, the young Australian makes history in Tokyo after sealing the bronze with a gutsy display in the decathlon's final event, the 1,500 metres.

column1: More than 900 Australians have died from COVID-19 – but there's been a hidden toll
column2: Thousands of Australians remain stranded abroad and unable to easily get home. For more than 50 who were in that situation, the consequences proved fatal.

column1: Kookaburras take silver after losing to Belgium in dramatic shootout
column2: The Kookaburras collect silver for the fourth time at an Olympics, with Belgium claiming victory in a penalty shootout at the Tokyo Olympics.

column1: Your daily guide to the Games: Australia fights for gold in women's beach volleyball, javelin throw and the 1,500m final
column2: Australia will take on the USA for gold in the women's beach volleyball on Friday, while Australia will also be represented in the women's 1,500m final. Here are the Olympic events to watch out for on day 14.

column1: Biden offers 'safe haven' in US to Hongkongers escaping Beijing crackdown
column2: Hong Kong residents currently in the US will be eligible for a temporary extension on their visas to support their escape of the Chinese regime President Biden describes as having 'deprived of their guaranteed freedoms'.

column1: The Matildas' hopes of an Olympic medal have been ended by the US superstars
column2: Australia rue their defensive mistakes as the United States's women's football team pounce on opportunities in a clinical display in front of goal.

column1: National Landcare winners recognised for their passion, environmental excellence
column2: The country's most dedicated and passionate landcarers have been recognised tonight in front of more than 2,400 people at a virtual National Landcare Awards.
column3: Kim Honan, Kristy Reading, and Michael Condon

column1: Explosive death of star captured in never-before-seen detail
column2: Astronomers capture a supernova shock wave from beginning to end in exquisite detail for the first time.

column1: Victoria's lockdown list: What you can (and can't) do under the new restrictions
column2: A snap lockdown has been implemented in Victoria to curb a growing COVID-19 outbreak. Here are the rules you need to know.

column1: WA's chief casino officer went on fishing trips with Crown executives on a boat he called 'The Good Ship Compliance'
column2: Today's hearing was told of the extent of the personal relationship between Western Australia's former chief casino officer Michael Connolly and Crown's general manager of legal and compliance, Claude Marais.

column1: Champion calls for urgent review into Triathlon Australia after Tokyo Olympics
column2: Australia won five Olympic medals in the women's triathlon from 2000 to 2012, but our performance in Tokyo leaves one former champion angry enough to call for an overhaul.

column1: Day 13 highlights: Australia equals best Olympic performance with two more gold, while Wu gets diving bronze
column2: Keegan Palmer wins the men's park skateboard final to deliver Australia its 17th gold, while Melissa Wu collects her first Games medal in her fourth Olympics appearance.

column1: A woman who refused to check in at a Canberra store claims to be a 'sovereign state'
column2: A woman who failed to check-in at a Canberra store tells a magistrate she is exempt from COVID-19 public health orders because she is a "sovereign state".

column1: Almost 60 plaques taken from gravesites in northern NSW
column2: Authorities fear scores of irreplaceable plaques stolen from cemeteries in the Northern Rivers might be melted down and sold, in a "despicable" act by thieves.

column1: One variant, three lockdowns, three sets of rules
column2: Each state is taking a slightly different approach to containing and suppressing the highly contagious Delta strain.

column1: Day 14 highlights: Garside wins first Australian boxing medal in 33 years
column2: The 24-year-old from Melbourne took it up to two-time world champion Andy Cruz, but went down in two rounds and will now collect a bronze medal.

column1: COVID-19 traces detected in Broome wastewater
column2: The WA Health Department is urging people in Broome to get tested if they have COVID-19 symptoms, after weak traces of the virus were detected in the town's wastewater.

column1: Imported dates recalled over hepatitis A contamination fears
column2: A brand of imported Medjool dates, sold in independent supermarkets including IGA, are pulled off shelves after three cases of a "unique strain" of hepatitis A were discovered in NSW.

column1: Police to search Port Pirie for remains of suspected murder victim
column2: South Australian Police believe 29-year-old Robert Atkins was murdered at Port Pirie in November last year and are preparing to search the area for his remains.

column1: 'You see something, you say something': Football community reacts to Taylor Walker's racist comment
column2: Taylor Walker's racist comment was flagged not by an opponent but by a club official. That anonymous individual is now being praised for having the courage to defy football's code of silence.

column1: Man accused of sexual assault at Parliament House to face court
column2: A 26-year-old man will be charged over an alleged sexual assault at Parliament House in March, 2019.

column1: Disgraced former MP faces jail time after admitting to forging documents and lying to parliament
column2: Disgraced former WA politician Barry Urban learns he could face time behind bars after misleading parliament about his education and police service.

column1: New venues in Ipswich and Brisbane's west added to Queensland Health's contact tracing list
column2: Scores of locations make up the list of COVID-19 exposure sites across south-east Queensland, Rockhampton and Cairns as contact tracers race to keep on top of any new venues. See the full list.

column1: Canberra Raiders' Curtis Scott charged with assault after alleged nightclub fight
column2: Raiders centre Curtis Scott is charged by police with assault occasioning actual bodily harm.

column1: Brisbane tower residents alarmed after uni students moved in for quarantine
column2: More than 50 university students who are possible close or household contacts in the latest Delta outbreak have been moved to quarantine in a Brisbane city private student accommodation provider, catching other residents off guard.

column1: NSW residents 'fleeing' to Tasmania, Premier says, as state reviews hotel quarantine rules
column2: Tasmania's Premier says the state's hotel quarantine rules will be reviewed after a NSW man was allowed to leave the state before receiving the results of a positive COVID-19 test, and that the system is under pressure from interstate arrivals "fleeing" hotspots.

column1: This kid gets a buzz out of bucking beekeeping's mature-age trend
column2: The typical Australian beekeeper is well over 50 but one keen apiarist is doing his bit to bring the average age down.

column1: 'The King of King Island': Their own Stewart McSweyn in 1,500m Olympic final
column2: Community support for King Island Olympic runner Stewart McSweyn has reached fever pitch ahead of his 1,500m final Saturday night in Tokyo.

column1: Swan Hill dad fears for his wife and baby's lives as Taliban gains control of their village
column2: While the world battles a pandemic, families in Afghanistan are also facing increasing threats from the Taliban and that fear is gripping one Swan Hill dad, whose wife and infant daughter half a world away had to flee their village last month.

column1: New rules will require Australians who live abroad to give a 'compelling reason' to return home

column1: 'Catastrophic decision': Man jailed for eight years over fatal Port Augusta crash
column2: A Port Augusta man who made a "disastrously bad decision" to drive home drunk will spend at least six years in jail for a crash that killed two people.

column1: Man who assaulted Fun Tea employee tells court he thought she was complaining about him
column2: An Adelaide man who was caught on video slapping a young female worker at the Gouger Street Fun Tea shop tells a court he did it because he thought she was complaining about him.

column1: 'Having an Olympic medal around our necks is just so special': Australia's beach volleyballers take silver
column2: Australian pair Taliqua Clancy and Mariafe Artacho del Solar win a silver medal in the women's beach volleyball, going down in the final to the USA pairing of Alix Klineman and April Ross.

column1: America is grappling with the Delta variant even with a 70 per cent vaccination rate
column2: America has a vaccination rate that's the envy of the world. But US President Joe Biden is suddenly battling an enemy he thought he had beat.

column1: Before home pregnancy tests, cane toads told Australian women if they were expecting

column1: Talks underway for possible Perth AFL grand final but Premier predicts 'very few' interstate fans
column2: WA Premier Mark McGowan says he's been contacted by the AFL about the prospect of hosting this year's grand final in Perth, but he remains confident the Victorian government will get COVID under control.

column1: 'A game changer': Apple to scan US iPhones for images of child abuse
column2: Apple announces its messaging app will use on-device machine learning to warn about sensitive content on iPhones, in a move applauded by child-protection groups.

column1: Sifan Hassan’s quest for Olympic history is still on track after 1,500 metres bronze
column2: It might seem rash to proclaim a bronze medal as a staggering achievement. But if Sifan Hassan finds her way to the podium after her final event, it will be something unprecedented and, yes, crazy.

column1: Peak body turns back on clubs' control of pokies handouts
column2: The group's greenlight for a scheme to direct pokies tax towards local charities was key to ClubGrants being introduced in the first place, but the NSW Council for Social Service finally pulls the pin, saying big clubs are ignoring its members' recommendations.

column1: Why some Olympic cities become multi-billion-dollar graveyards for white elephants after the Games
column2: Olympic hosts have big dreams of attracting tourists, advertisers and the eyes of the world. But in recent years they have usually been a poisoned chalice, leaving cities littered with white elephants.
column3: Jake Sturmer, Rebecca Armitage, and Lucia Stein

column1: Wuhan residents report 'post-traumatic stress' as 40 Chinese cities battle COVID outbreaks
column2: Chinese authorities have previously curbed outbreaks within days or weeks by mass testing and strict lockdowns, stopping infection from spreading. But now China is facing its biggest COVID battle since last year.

column1: COVID crisis is burning across Australia, and someone needs to hold the hose
column2: There were so many fires to put out this week, yet never has it felt quite so much like no-one was holding the hose, writes Laura Tingle.

column1: A blunt, no-platitudes guide for surviving lockdown number 6
column2: So you are stuck in another lockdown and feeling like it's groundhog day? We spoke to psychiatrist and executive director of the youth mental health facility Orygen, Professor Patrick McGorry, and came up with a toolkit to help you navigate Victoria's sixth lockdown.

column1: Australia's Kelsey-Lee Barber captures javelin bronze in Tokyo
column2: A consistent series of throws helps Barber claim Australia's second medal in the athletics program in Tokyo, as she adds bronze to her world title in the women's javelin.

column1: Taliban assassinates Afghan government's top media officer in Kabul
column2: The militant group claims responsibility for the killing, saying it was in retaliation for increased air strikes by Afghan and US militaries.

column1: Your daily guide to the Games: Boomers fight for historic bronze medal, McSweyn and Hoare to run 1,500m final
column2: The Boomers get one more chance to win Australia's first Olympic medal in men's basketball, while Stewart McSweyn and Ollie Hoare will run for gold in the men's 1,500m final. Here are the Olympic events to watch out for on day 15.

column1: Australian men's hockey players reprimanded for COVID protocol breach at Tokyo Olympics
column2: Members of the silver-medal-winning Kookaburras squad breach COVID-19 protocols by leaving the athletes' village to buy beer, but the Australian Olympic Committee will not take any further action beyond a reprimand.

column1: Scott Morrison says government won't mandate no-jab no-job for all workplaces
column2: A no-jab no-job policy will not be pursued by the federal government, which says it is up to individual companies to make their own decisions about mandating vaccinations for staff.

column1: National Cabinet 'fully agrees' on plan to start saying goodbye to COVID-19 lockdowns
column2: After mulling it over for a week, National Cabinet now agrees on a plan out of the COVID-19 pandemic. Let's catch up on what that means.

column1: Men being flown to Cairns after suspected crocodile attack at Lockhart River on Cape York
column2: Paramedics are responding to reports two men have been bitten by a crocodile at Lockhart River on Cape York in Far North Queensland.

column1: Google billionaire granted entry to New Zealand despite border closure
column2: Larry Page, Google's co-founder and the sixth-richest man in the world, becomes a New Zealand resident, stoking debate over whether he bought his way into the country, which is closed to visitors.

column1: Get ready for 'Vaxzevria', AstraZeneca's rebranded COVID-19 vaccine
column2: AstraZeneca is rebranding its COVID-19 vaccine to "Vaxzevria" across the globe as it says it wants to prevent confusion over people's vaccination status when international travel restarts.

column1: Ash Moloney decathlon bronze a study in sacrifice and mateship
column2: Ash Moloney did what no other Australian has done in winning bronze in the decathlon at the Tokyo Olympics, but the 21-year-old owes much to the selfless act of training partner and friend Cedric Dubler.

column1: Mungo Man reburial proposal to be discussed with traditional owners
column2: The Federal Environment Minister Sussan Ley will assess the proposal to rebury Aboriginal ancestral remains at Lake Mungo.

column1: Remote WA artist wins top prize in national Indigenous art awards
column2: Timo Hogan wins the major prize at Australia's most prestigious Indigenous art awards with a bold painting paying homage to a sacred site on his father's country.

column1: Joe Biden vows to dramatically cut emissions to help Pacific Islands in climate change crisis
column2: The US President tells Pacific Island leaders the US will make steep emissions cuts this decade in order to stave off the worst impacts of climate change.

column1: Woman who refused to check in at a Canberra store claims to be 'sovereign state'
column2: A woman who failed to check in at a Canberra store tells a magistrate she is exempt from COVID-19 public health orders because she is a "sovereign state".

column1: NSW police fear escalation of gang war after man with links to Alameddine family shot dead
column2: A shooter is on the run after killing 22-year-old Shady Kanj in Western Sydney and injuring an innocent bystander, in what police believe could be another death in the feud between two crime families.

column1: Knife attacker on Tokyo commuter train wanted to kill 'women who looked happy'
column2: A man believed to be in his 20s goes on a rampage with a knife on a commuter train in Tokyo, injuring at least 10 people, one of them seriously, just a few kilometres from an Olympic games venue.

column1: 'Absolute Australian grit': Freestyle BMX Olympian Diehm reveals secret injury that ended Games medal dream
column2: Our first female freestyle BMX Olympian competed in Tokyo on one good leg, determined to make the most of the experience.

column1: US authorities encourage COVID jabs for those already infected to develop 'hybrid immunity'
column2: A US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report adds to growing laboratory evidence that people who had one bout of COVID-19 get a dramatic boost in virus-fighting immune cells when they're vaccinated.

column1: How and when to watch the Tokyo Olympics closing ceremony
column2: The Tokyo Olympics are coming to an end after 17 days of events that saw records smashed and champions forged in a bid for golden glory.

column1: Near-miss was Delta strain, as Tasmanian COVID closures continue
column2: Tasmania's strict border closure with high risk mainland areas will continue as outbreaks spread in the eastern states, as it is revealed the island's recent close call was with someone infected with the Delta strain.

column1: Belarus coaches kicked out of Tokyo Olympics, IOC says
column2: Two Belarus coaches who cut short sprinter Krystsina Tsimanouskaya's Tokyo Olympics have had their accreditation revoked and been removed from the athletes' village

column1: Long wait to settle cyclone insurance claims
column2: Four months on from the unprecedented devastation of Tropical Cyclone Seroja in Western Australia's mid-west, thousands of locals are still waiting for millions of dollars of insurance claims to be settled.

column1: Sometimes lockdown learning is the best classroom
column2: As hundreds of thousands of students in multiple states learn from home, experts say lessons from past COVID-19 lockdowns are yet to be learned.

column1: A supermarket is added to Queensland's COVID-19 contact list. Check the full list here
column2: Queensland Health confirms all 13 of Saturday's cases were in quarantine during their infectious periods. Scores of locations across the state are still listed as exposure sites. Check the full list here.

column1: 'A catastrophe': Two killed as Greek wildfires threaten Athens, while blazes ravage parts of Turkey and Italy
column2: Emergency crews struggle to stop wildfires from spreading as scorching winds fuel blazes across Greece for a fourth day, with hundreds of people evacuated from towns and villages.

column1: Kenyan Kipchoge's race against time will close out Tokyo 2020 in style
column2: These Games began with an emerging rivalry: Ledecky versus Titmus. The finale will involve a long-standing grudge match: Kenyan marathon runner Eliud Kipchoge versus The Clock, writes Paul Kennedy.

column1: How long would you look before giving up on your best mate?
column2: One man spent a week in the Kimberley outback looking for his lost dog and was just about to give up when the power of social media helped him find his beloved Jack.

column1: Celebrities like Lisa Loeb come together to create musicals about 2020
column2: Inspired to capture the weirdness of 2020, Grammy Award winner Lisa Loeb taps dozens of her fellow Brown alumni to create a collection of 10 mini-musicals exploring moments during the year.

column1: 'Nothing was a handout, we've had to fight': Clancy, Artacho del Solar proud to bring back silver for Australia
column2: Their Indigenous and Peruvian heritage may be part of what makes their combination special, but silver medallists Taliqua Clancy and Mariafe Artacho del Solar are very much at the heart of the diverse Australian team in Tokyo, writes Tracey Holmes.

column1: Breathless and 15kg lighter, Victorian teacher ravaged by Delta urges public to 'just get vaccinated'
column2: Before he caught COVID-19, Richard was the fittest person in his family. But since going into intensive care, he's lost 15 kilograms of muscle mass and cannot stand up without being left breathless.

column1: After taking up running at 33, Australia's Sinead Diver finishes 10th in Olympic marathon
column2: In her first Olympic marathon, Sinead Diver finishes in the top 10, 11 years after taking up the sport.

column1: Sydney COVID hotspot shifts, Armidale plunged into lockdown as NSW records 319 new infections
column2: A record 319 infections are identified, five people die and the regional centre of Armidale is plunged into lockdown as NSW endures its darkest day of the COVID-19 pandemic.

column1: Tasmanian salmon farmer being pursued by Brazilian meat giant
column2: A Brazilian meat processing giant is after 100 per cent control of Tasmania's second-largest salmon farming company — with the couple who founded the business set to make hundreds of millions if the deal goes through.

column1: The cheeky, stolen Olympic flag that became an heirloom for McKeon swimming family
column2: Looming over the famous McKeon family's rumpus room the past fortnight has been an enormous Olympic rings flag signed by gold medallists from around the world with a funny and mischievous backstory.

column1: Two men in hospital after alleged stabbing in Adelaide's north
column2: A 29-year-old man is in a serious but stable condition after he was allegedly stabbed in a Blair Athol park overnight.

column1: Queensland's lockdown decision due tomorrow morning as 13 cases added to the south-east's Delta cluster
column2: All 13 of today's cases are linked to the Delta outbreak in South-East Queensland and were in quarantine during their infectious period, raising hopes the lockdown will end at 4:00pm on Sunday, as planned.

column1: 'Hire a hit man': Two charged in US over plot to kill Myanmar's UN ambassador
column2: Investigators arrest two Myanmar nationals as they share details of a foiled attempt to attack New York-based Kyaw Moe Tun, an outspoken supporter of the democracy movement who has refused junta orders to quit.

column1: Howard Springs quarantine facility expected to reach capacity for overseas arrivals for the first time
column2: The ABC understands the Howard Springs quarantine facility in the Northern Territory is set to reach full capacity for international arrivals for the first time, as the number of repatriation flights surges this month.

column1: Indonesia's huge coronavirus outbreak could be the perfect 'hotspot' for the world's next variant
column2: Experts fear Indonesia, considered one of the world's COVID-19 epicentres, is now a high-risk "hotspot" for the emergence of a new coronavirus "super strain".

column1: Dean Cross thought he had to leave the regions to succeed — but his return suggests otherwise
column2: The artist is showing at Sydney's Museum of Contemporary Art and the Art Gallery of South Australia this year — but it's a "home turf" solo exhibition in Goulburn that everyone is talking about.

column1: A farewell to Tokyo as the Olympics come to an end
column2: Thank you, sorry or congratulations? It's hard to know what to say to Tokyo after an enthralling Olympic Games that seemed so unlikely for so long, writes Tracey Holmes.

column1: Police fire rubber bullets at hundreds of Thai protesters demanding PM's resignation
column2: Hundreds of Thai protesters throng Bangkok's streets in protest against the government's pandemic response and economic distress.

column1: A deadly game with no end: We haven't learnt the lessons of decades of war
column2: A decade ago, I learned a little lesson in the endless Afghanistan war: the battle may be over, but the conflict rages on — and the Taliban never goes away, writes Stan Grant.

column1: Going hard, fast and often: Australia's east coast struggles under the Delta load
column2: With the highly transmissible Delta variant snaking its way up and down the east coast, "go hard, go early" has become the nationwide approach — and we're seeing it daily.

column1: The key to ending lockdown is vaccinating young men — and we're going about it all wrong
column2: For years people have put young guys into the too-hard basket when it comes to health promotion, but it doesn't have to be that way, writes Zac Seidler.

column1: Aliir Aliir shines as Port Adelaide move to third with victory in Showdown over the Crows
column2: Aliir Aliir wins the Showdown medal after producing one of the best performances of his career in victory over the Crows.

column1: Aussie Nicola McDermott claims high jump silver
column2: McDermott wins Australia's first medal in the women's high jump since 1964 with a national record, while countrywoman Eleanor Patterson finishes fifth in the final.

column1: After finishing fourth four times, the Boomers finally get on the Olympic podium
column2: After falling agonisingly short so many times, the Boomers win the bronze-medal game against Slovenia by 14 points to claim Australia's first men's basketball podium finish at an Olympic Games.

column1: Your daily guide to the Games: Marathon gold up for grabs, Aussie cyclists take to the velodrome
column2: Sunday marks the final day of competition in Tokyo, with Kenya's Eliud Kipchoge looking to win back-to-back men's marathons, while Australia finishes its track cycling campaign. Here are the Olympic events to watch out for on day 16.

column1: COVID workplace changes allows Sydney workers back on site, with a catch
column2: Vaccine hesitant construction workers are changing their minds about getting the jab as changes are made to work sites opening.

column1: Boat 'filled with blood': Cape York croc attack survivor stabbed reptile in the eye
column2: A man pried his friend from the jaws of a crocodile that attacked them while swimming in the sea off Cape York.  "I couldn't believe what I was seeing, it was like I was in a movie," said a local resident who went to their aid.

column1: All Blacks beat brave Wallabies in first Bledisloe Cup Test match
column2: The All Blacks have a 1-0 series lead in the Bledisloe Cup after defeating the Wallabies in Auckland.

column1: Day 15 highlights: Mat Belcher announced as flag-bearer for closing ceremony, Team USA wins men's basketball
column2: Men's 470 sailing gold medallist Mat Belcher will have the honour of carrying the Australian flag in the closing ceremony of the Tokyo Olympics on Sunday.

column1: Conroy's kabana and ham recalled because of difficulty verifying their safety
column2: Kabana sausages and three types of ham made by Adelaide-based Conroy's Smallgoods are being recalled because Primary Industries and Regions South Australia is unable to verify their safety.

column1: Boomers' bronze medal feels more like gold
column2: Decades of work by generations of Australian basketball players and coaches has finally been rewarded. Perhaps no bronze medal in Australia's long history at the Olympic Games has ever meant so much, writes Tracey Holmes.

column1: Regional Queensland travellers join south-east in ban from entering South Australia
column2: Only people with exemptions or essential travellers will be able to enter South Australia from regional Queensland after a three-day lockdown was declared for Cairns following an unexpected COVID-19 case in the city.

column1: Taxi driver prompts COVID-19 alert for Cairns Taxis passengers over six days. Check the exposure list
column2: A surprise new case of COVID-19 creates more work for contact tracers, with a general alert issued for passengers of Cairns Taxis at certain times over six days.

column1: WA government unveils plan to spend extra $1.9 billion on health in upcoming budget
column2: The WA government outlines a plan to spend an additional $1.9 billion on the state's health system, including hiring an extra 100 doctors and 500 nurses in hospitals to ease staffing pressures.

column1: Port Adelaide condemns racist post directed at Showdown medallist Aliir Aliir after win against Crows
column2: The Port Adelaide Football Club says racism has to stop following a social media post directed at one of its players.

column1: 'The Taliban are everywhere': Taliban's hold on Afghanistan tightens as foreign troops withdraw
column2: Qader Malia, the deputy governor of Jawzjan province, says the northern city of Sheberghan has fallen, with government forces retreating to the airport on its outskirts.

column1: Campbell Newman seeks political comeback outside LNP
column2: The former LNP premier of Queensland is seeking a return to politics, announcing his candidacy for the Senate ahead of the next federal election.

column1: Could Sydney's Delta outbreak spread into Queensland across the border?
column2: Thousands of residents in the Queensland-New South Wales border zone are still being allowed to cross the border despite Sydney's escalating COVID-19 outbreak spreading to just south of the border.

column1: The Moderna vaccine is about to be approved in Australia. Here's what we know
column2: TGA approval of the Moderna vaccine is imminent. Here's what you need to know about Australia's third COVID-19 vaccine candidate.

column1: As one lockdown ends, another begins — here's what you need to know about Queensland's new rules
column2: Stay-at-home orders have lifted in south-east Queensland, but a new three-day lockdown has started in Cairns and Yarrabah. Here are the rules you need to know in either end of the state.

column1: Full list of NSW COVID-19 exposure sites
column2: As Penrith enters a stricter lockdown, a medical practice and a pharmacy are added to NSW Health's list of COVID-19 exposure sites.

column1: Harsher restrictions for 12 Sydney suburbs as 'front of pandemic' moves into new area
column2: NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian says she hopes tougher restrictions will "stem the tide" and stop the virus "seeping into additional communities", as Penrith in Western Sydney becomes a new area of concern.

column1: There are five lessons our political leaders could learn from Patty Mills
column2: Patty Mills has long been acknowledged in basketball circles as a leader of rare quality. His skills were on display again at the Olympics and it's to be hoped our political class was taking notes, writes Russell Jackson.

column1: Australia's third COVID-19 vaccine will be approved within a fortnight
column2: Federal Health Minister Greg Hunt says he expects the national rollout of the Moderna vaccine to begin from the middle of next month, with the TGA set to approve the vaccine shortly.

column1: Cairns plunged into three-day lockdown over 'unexpected' COVID-19 case
column2: Cairns and Yarrabah have officially been plunged into a snap three-day lockdown from 4:00pm, after an "unexpected" positive case of COVID-19 in the community.

column1: Man allegedly stabbed in back at pole dancing studio that may have breached COVID-19 directions
column2: A man is in the Royal Adelaide Hospital after allegedly being stabbed in the back at a function in Adelaide's northern suburbs that attracted about 30 people.

column1: Abducted Nigerian schoolgirl freed after seven years
column2: A girl abducted from the Nigerian town of Chibok has been freed and reunited with her parents seven years after Boko Haram militants kidnapped her and more than 200 of her classmates.

column1: McSweyn faithful know he is a winner, despite missing a medal
column2: Stewart McSweyn may not have been among the medals, but that does not matter to the King Island faithful who watched every moment of the local hero's bid for Olympic glory.

column1: NT bans travellers from using Howard Springs as 'halfway house', adds Cairns and Yarrabah to list of COVID hotspots
column2: Chief Minister Michael Gunner says "too many people are taking the Territory for a ride" and has banned all non-approved travel from declared hotspots, as Howard Springs Quarantine Facility reaches capacity.

column1: 'We all have names': Nick's life is looking up, but he knows how it feels to be homeless
column2: Nick has a job trial and is one step closer to having a permanent home thanks to a band of volunteers who see him and others experiencing homelessness, as people, not problems.

column1: New national park near Victor Harbor set to open next year on site of former dairy farm
column2: A new national park on the Fleurieu Peninsula is set to be a little different to most infrastructure projects — enjoying almost total support from the community.

column1: Kool and the Gang co-founder Dennis Thomas dies aged 70
column2: Dennis “Dee Tee” Thomas was the alto sax player, flutist and percussionist for Kool and the Gang.

column1: How to check in with your mental health during lockdown
column2: Lockdowns can have insidious impacts on your wellbeing, so here are some tips to help keep your mental health in check.

column1: 'A day does not make a trend': Premier plays down drop in NSW COVID cases as 262 recorded
column2: Residents in Penrith are subject to tougher restrictions after an increase in COVID cases as NSW records 262 new infections and another death.

column1: Kenya's Eliud Kipchoge wins men's Olympic marathon in Tokyo
column2: Kenya's Eliud Kipchoge wins the Olympic men's marathon with a commanding performance in Sapporo, claiming his second-straight gold medal and cementing his place among the all-time greats of the sport.

column1: Businesses 'stoked' to reopen as millions enjoy first day of freedom after lockdown lifted
column2: Thousands of businesses across Queensland's south-east scramble to reopen their doors within COVID-19 restrictions as millions of residents enjoy their first day of freedom after lockdown was lifted.

column1: Jay couldn't find a suitable football program for his son with cerebral palsy, so he set one up
column2: Dissatisfied with the sporting opportunities available for his son who has cerebral palsy, Jay Larkins set up is own program, giving other families something he didn't have.

column1: Cairns and Yarrabah residents face anxious wait to learn extent of COVID outbreak
column2: A mysterious case of COVID-19 sends Cairns and Yarrabah into a 3-day lockdown. Residents are being urged to get tested as contact tracers race to find people who crossed paths with a taxi driver who was infectious in the community for 10 days.

column1: Hat trick on debut not a bad start for cricket 'battler'
column2: Fresh from becoming the first male cricketer to take a hat trick on their T20 International debut, Nathan Ellis doesn't have to reach back very far to recall a time when as a struggling up-and-comer he barely had enough money to pay rent and fill up the fuel tank.

column1: All you need to know about Hobart's new passenger ferry service
column2: The long-awaited Bellerive to Sullivans Cove ferry service will begin plying Hobart's River Derwent from Monday.

column1: Why Apple wants to become your bank
column2: Traditional banking has been under threat for decades, forced to change behaviour in response to interlopers and upstarts. Now they are staring down a much bigger foe, writes Ian Verrender.

column1: 'This is a race': NSW Premier issues warning over easing of lockdown restrictions
column2: NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian says the state needs to reach 6 million COVID vaccinations by the end of August for restrictions to ease, but warns life will not go back to this way it was before the Delta outbreak.

column1: Gladys Berejiklian intervened in $5.5m grant pursued by Daryl Maguire
column2: New documents released to the NSW Parliament have raised fresh questions over Gladys Berejiklian's role in facilitating a grant that Daryl Maguire stood to gain a political benefit from.

column1: Schools are Australia's new Delta battleground. How risky are they really?
column2: As another week of home learning begins for thousands of Australian students, and those in south-east Queensland head to class in masks,  a return to school-as-normal seems further away than ever.

column1: 'Too many hoops to jump through': Business support lacking as pandemic drags on
column2: More than 18 months since the start of the pandemic, for many workers and business owners it feels like those turbulent beginnings of the crisis, with weak support and an uncertain future.

column1: The pandemic is killing trans women in Indonesia, but not always due to COVID
column2: Life is rarely easy for Indonesia's transgender women, known as waria, but without family and neighbourhood support networks, many are struggling to survive during the pandemic.

column1: Got plans tomorrow night? You do now — it's census night
column2: It's almost time for the twice-a-decade survey that delights data nerds and gives the whole country Tuesday night plans, even in lockdown.

column1: Thousands flee Greek island of Evia as fires continue to burn out of control
column2: Hundreds of residents and tourists evacuate Greece's second-largest island as flames burn through forests and encroach on villages.

column1: Australia's census is only available in English. So the Chinese community has decided to translate it
column2: The Australian Bureau of Statistics has provided information on the census in 48 languages, but the census itself can only be completed in English.

column1: As the US withdraws from Afghanistan, why is China rolling out the red carpet for the Taliban?
column2: America's military adventurism has long been a lightning rod for criticism from Beijing, but the hasty US withdrawal from Afghanistan has Beijing changing its tune.

column1: Five of the best moments from the Tokyo Olympics closing ceremony
column2: And just like that, the Tokyo Olympics are over. If you missed the closing ceremony, here's a recap of some of the main highlights and best bits.

column1: Companies that received JobKeeper to remain secret as government rejects naming them
column2: Big businesses that received JobKeeper will be able to keep the financial support secret, with the federal Coalition rejecting a bid to make it public and the Labor Party backing down from insisting on it.

column1: Tearful Lionel Messi says Barcelona departure is 'like a bucket of cold water has been poured over me'
column2: Lionel Messi says he is still coming to terms with his exit from the club where he has played for 21 years, scoring 682 goals and winning 35 trophies, and confirmed he was in talks about a move to French club Paris St Germain.

column1: Fiery crash stops Styrian MotoGP
column2: The Styrian MotoGP is red-flagged on lap 3 after a collision left two motorcycles engulfed in flames on the track and one rider carried away on a stretcher.

column1: The Tokyo Olympics are over, and Paris 2024 provides a teaser, as it happened
column2: The greatest sporting show on earth has come to a close, with Tokyo providing a classy farewell to the Olympics, handing over to Paris for three year's time. Look back at the closing ceremony in our blog.

column1: French protesters reject President's vaccination health pass
column2: More than 230,000 people protest against a new French law that requires proof of vaccination to eat in a restaurant, access non-emergency treatment in a hospital or travel on an intercity train.

column1: Inside Australia's first drive-through COVID vaccination clinic
column2: At the site of a former Bunnings warehouse, nurses prepare doses of Pfizer COVID-19 vaccines from a portable fridge. The shots will soon be administered at Australia's first drive-through COVID vaccination clinic.

column1: Taxi driver prompts COVID-19 alert for passengers of Cairns Taxis. Check the exposure list
column2: A surprise new case of COVID-19 creates more work for contact tracers, with a general alert issued for passengers of Cairns Taxis at certain times over several days.

column1: Baby dies after mother falls while trying to dodge swooping magpie
column2: A baby girl dies after her mother trips and falls while trying to avoid a swooping magpie at a Brisbane park.

column1: Businessman made the 'most stupid decision of his life' when he tried to import nearly 300kg of cocaine in excavator
column2: Naive, a bit of a dreamer and an unsophisticated businessman – this is how a Bungendore father is described as he faces court over the attempted importation of nearly 300kg of cocaine hidden in an excavator.

column1: Young people rush to get COVID vaccine at Adelaide clinic welcoming people who don't meet eligibility rules
column2: Confusion surrounds the availability of the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine for young people in Adelaide, with one state government-run clinic appearing to offer under-40s the jab, despite them not officially being eligible.

column1: The Moderna vaccine is coming to Australia. Here's what we do (and don't) know
column2: The Therapeutic Goods Administration has approved the use of a fourth COVID-19 vaccine which is already in use across much of the world. Here are your questions answered.

column1: Woman awarded $130k damages in sexual harassment case against boss at laundromat
column2: A woman who was found to have been sexually harassed while working at a Brisbane laundromat is awarded $130,000 in damages — a sum her lawyers believe could be a record-breaking amount in Queensland.

column1: WA nurses and doctors face exhaustion and 'horrific' stress as government pledges $100 million ED spend
column2: The WA government announces an almost $2 billion plan to overhaul healthcare in public hospitals, but some doctors say it could be a case of too little, too late.

column1: ‘We need a justice system that's just': NT plan to reduce Indigenous incarceration
column2: The NT government is hailing a landmark step towards equality for Indigenous Territorians, launching its first Aboriginal Justice Agreement — a plan to reduce high rates of Indigenous incarceration.

column1: Event cancellation fund included in $40m package for SA businesses hit by lockdown
column2: Small and medium-sized businesses hit by SA's recent lockdown and ongoing social distancing rules will soon be able to access a new $40 million COVID-19 support package — but not all are happy, with one local pub owner describing the grants as "hush money".

column1: Prominent irrigators lose court appeal against water theft charge
column2: Two prominent New South Wales irrigators, Peter and Jane Harris, have lost their appeal to the Supreme Court over illegally taking water, highlighted in the Four Corners program Pumped.

column1: Byron Bay area to go into lockdown after COVID-19 case visited from Sydney
column2: The NSW North Coast local government areas of Byron Shire, Richmond Valley, Lismore and Ballina Shire will go into lockdown after a positive case travelled to the region from Sydney.

column1: Moderna's COVID-19 vaccine approved by medical regulator
column2: Moderna's COVID-19 vaccine is approved by the regulator, making it the third to be officially added to Australia's vaccine arsenal when the first doses arrive next month.

column1: Fight to reopen controversial Tasmanian 4WD tracks hits end of the road
column2: An almost decade-long battle over 4WD tracks on Tasmania's West Coast has come to an end with the state Liberal government conceding that three controversial tracks it promised to reopen will stay shut.

column1: Farm gates forced open as government grants access to new riverfront campsites
column2: The Victorian Government is allowing camping on 27 river frontages in northern Victoria that are currently licensed by farmers and some are "pretty pissed off about it".

column1: 'Inadequate training': Cherry orchard used 'mime' for safety induction, coroner finds
column2: A coroner criticises a cherry orchard for using mime to induct workers with limited English skills after an Ethiopian migrant is dragged under a trailer and crushed.

column1: Charges dropped against children of WA couple wanted over alleged Fremantle Ports corruption
column2: The children of a Perth couple who are wanted by WA Police over alleged corruption at Fremantle Ports walk free from court as property laundering charges against them are dropped.

column1: Two people arrested after allegedly ramming SA Police car in stolen Mercedes
column2: A man and woman will face court today accused of ramming a police car in a stolen Mercedes Benz as they tried to escape arrest for stealing from car wash coin machines.

column1: 'They keep treating them badly': Watchdog accuses Telstra, Optus and TPG of misleading consumers over NBN speeds
column2: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission is taking Telstra, Optus and TPG to court, alleging they misled hundreds of thousands of consumers over NBN speeds.

column1: Data reveals only 14 per cent of child sexual abuse claims before Family Court believed to be true by judges
column2: The authors of a new report into findings in Family Court matters where sexual abuse was alleged say they began the project because of a lack of data.

column1: Outback's legendary Birdsville Races called off for 2021
column2: The Birdsville Races have been called off for 2021 due to COVID-19. It is the second year in a row the September event has not proceeded after it was cancelled in 2020 due to the pandemic.

column1: Regional Victoria's lockdown lift explained: The rules, the enforcement, and what we know about Melbourne
column2: Regional Victoria will be released from lockdown restrictions from midnight tonight. Here's what you need to know.

column1: Crime 'out of control' as more than $100,000 worth of cars stolen from cookbook author
column2: A police officer is injured while trying to stop an alleged gang of juveniles in stolen cars on the Sunshine Coast.

column1: Snow couldn't stop this man from conquering his 'Cradle to Everest' challenge
column2: Piotr Babis likes a challenge — even if it means running against icy cold wind and wading through waist-deep snow. This time, he's conquered 10 summits of Cradle Mountain.

column1: Ex-bikie Brent Simpson had no idea cannabis oil product was illegal, court hears
column2: A Gold Coast ex-bikie charged with trafficking cannabis oil gets bail after his lawyer told a court his client did not know the product he was the "face of" contained a dangerous drug.

column1: Darwin Turf Club board vote delayed in wake of damning anti-corruption report
column2: A vote to decide the make-up of the Darwin Turf Club board has been delayed as the club continues to deal with the fallout of an ICAC report into the handling of a $12 million government grant for a new grandstand.

column1: West Gate tunnel project blows out by $3.3 billion, all estimates on completion date scrapped
column2: Tolling giant Transurban says it will need $3.3 billion in funding to complete the delayed project, and has suggested the Victorian government and builders should help foot the bill.

column1: It's not just those with a home who will be captured on tonight's census
column2: Rob Newitt was evicted from his home of 20 years a few months ago. And even though he's now living at the Hobart Showgrounds, he says it's important he's captured in the census.

column1: Soccer is off but golf is on. Questions about restrictions on community sport in Queensland, answered
column2: The rules surrounding sports and exercise classes can be a little hard to keep up with as millions in south-east Queensland adjust their regular routines after the recent eight-day lockdown. Here's everything you need to know.

column1: Jacob is desperate for a job. To hand out resumes he embarks on a treacherous commute every day
column2: Jacob Foster's arduous trips to the nearest town to hand out resumes are emblematic of a broader problem — a lack of public transport options facing those in regional Australia without a car.

column1: 'Sense of camaraderie': Young people explain why they're seeking out COVID jabs
column2: As vaccines become more accessible to people under 40, young people lining up to get their shots share their thoughts, fears and hopes.

column1: This 'fearsome beast' is the closest thing Australia has to a 'real-life dragon'
column2: Scientists have discovered a new species of a prehistoric flying reptile in outback Queensland describing it as the closest thing we have to Australia's own dragon.

column1: Gary earns money by plugging his car into the wall. What's the catch?
column2: Owners of electric vehicles may soon be able to get paid for simply plugging their car into the wall. But there are a few things to consider first.

column1: Shotguns, dog bites and Jedis: Inside the controversies and triumphs of the Census
column2: Not a census goes by without controversy, and for all the census controversies there are triumphs and reasons for celebration, writes Liz Allen.

column1: Talyah went from being frustrated at school to wanting to be a teacher. And it's all thanks to this
column2: Like an estimated 50 per cent of low-income families, Vanessa struggles to pay for internet and she fears her daughter will get left behind. But one program is stepping in to change that.

column1: Temperature rises and time shortens for both the planet and for Coalition action on climate change
column2: The IPCC report makes clear that climate change and its impacts are accelerating. The heat is also on Scott Morrison and the Coalition, writes Melissa Clarke.

column1: Australia's cricketers bowled out for historic low by Bangladesh

column1: Belarusian President Lukashenko remains defiant in face of sanctions and defections
column2: One year after an election win that his opponents say was rigged to extend his 27-year rule, Alexander Lukashenko says he won fairly, and that the world now pays attention to Belarus.

column1: NSW considers mandatory COVID-19 vaccination for all health workers

column1: How many Australians do you think support giving everyone a basic income? The answer might surprise you
column2: While the COVID pandemic has been an economic and social disaster of unimaginable proportions, for well over a million Australians struggling to survive on welfare payments it briefly opened a window to a better world for them, one with a universal basic income.

column1: Lightning delay can't save Eagles as Melbourne move back to top of AFL ladder
column2: Melbourne moves back to the top of the AFL ladder, holding on for victory against West Coast in a game that was briefly halted by an electrical storm.

column1: Carlton captain Docherty to undergo chemotherapy after second testicular cancer scare
column2: Carlton co-captain Sam Docherty is expected to make a full recovery after being diagnosed with testicular cancer for a second time.

column1: Troubled naval shipbuilding projects set to prompt another Defence shake-up
column2: A major overhaul of the Defence Department is looming as government frustration grows over delays and cost blowouts associated with Australia's multi-billion-dollar naval shipbuilding projects.

column1: 'What I said was racism': Taylor Walker apologises next to the player he targeted

column1: As Messi leaves Barcelona, another piece of football's magic is lost forever

column1: Man accused of lighting fires finds them 'scary', court hears
column2: A man accused of deliberately lighting fires in Tasmania's Fingal valley tells police in an interview played in court that he hates fire and he finds them "scary".

column1: World could hit major global warming threshold by 2030, IPCC report says

column1: Woman awarded nearly $160k damages in sexual harassment case against boss at laundromat
column2: A woman who was found to have been sexually harassed while working at a Brisbane laundromat is awarded almost $160,000 in damages — a sum her lawyers believe could be a record-breaking amount in Queensland.

column1: The ICC is plotting cricket's return to the Olympic Games after a 121-year drinks break

column1: Natural medicine body urges naturopaths to stay in their lane over vaccinations

column1: WA government to pay $8,000 in relocation costs for UK doctors as system struggles to cope

column1: Global screen time study 'wake-up call' for parents, finds girls suffer worst impacts

column1: George Christensen condemned by Parliament after calling for end to COVID-19 restrictions

column1: Authorities locate the source of toxic horse meat found in pet food

column1: These workers were at the front of SA's vaccine queue — less than half have had their first shot

column1: Father who murdered son and son's girlfriend argues jail term 'excessive'

column1: Greta Thunberg says global warming's 'worst consequences' can be avoided

column1: China rejects Canadian drug convict's appeal against death sentence

column1: Aboriginal man's human rights may have been breached at hospital, coroner hears

column1: Tonight's census will show how we've changed, but so do these census ads from 1966

column1: Matilda the mascot could return for the Brisbane 2032 Olympic Games

column1: Finding the news too depressing? Sabra Lane might just have a solution

column1: In two weeks, New York will have a new governor — so who is the woman set to be the first female leader of the state?

Here's a look at Kathy Hochul's career, what she makes of the allegations her outgoing boss is facing, and what those who will have to work closely with her think.

column1: What does the latest IPCC report mean for Australia?

column1: Need help making ethical decisions? There's a counselling service for that

column1: Committee recommends eased pathway to permanent residency for migrant workers

column1: Instagram's new tools will help athletes copping racist abuse, but it may be too little too late

column1: 'It makes me feel like we do not exist': Ethnic groups say they are not being counted in census

column1: This one chart explains why Victoria's lockdown has been extended

column1: 'We went early': Expert says quick response helped Queensland avoid high COVID caseload

column1: Aunty Joyce has spent decades standing up for her regional community — her latest fight is more personal

column1: Sylvia could 'read a book again' after taking this new Alzheimer's drug. But some experts aren't convinced
column2: The first new Alzheimer’s drug approved by US regulators in almost two decades is generating global interest and global controversy.

column1: Three more Sydney LGAs expecting 'the worst' as Premier warns of harder lock downs

column1: Jane fled an abusive relationship hoping for peace. She didn't expect her son to turn aggressive

column1: Army investigates leaks but insists new armoured vehicle fleet remains on track

column1: Claims Australian crypto-celebrity owes an investor half a million dollars

column1: Content delivery networks hope you've never heard of them — but when they go down, the internet breaks
column2: It may seem strange for a business to hope you've never heard of it, but that's exactly what content delivery network providers would like. Recent high-profile outages of news sites and bank apps have highlighted how reliant we are on these networks.

column1: Namibia sells 57 live elephants amid outcry from conservationists

column1: Plea for Australia to help push back against 'brutal' Taliban advance in Afghanistan

column1: US authorities granted more grounds to appeal on Assange extradition

column2: The man in charge of the finances of Crown's two Australian casinos, Alan McGregor, was warned of multiple suspicious transactions which could indicate money laundering but can not remember taking any action, the royal commission hears.

column1: Mining magnate rules out mandatory workers vaccinations for now
