column2: A Tasmanian man found guilty of starting a major bushfire in 2019 told police they should investigate a man who had been kicked out of the alternative community he was trying to set up for people "sick of their government".

column1: PM criticises 'crazy' COVID conspiracy theories as George Christensen defends his comments on restrictions
column2: The Prime Minister criticises what he describes as "crazy, rubbish" conspiracy theories about COVID-19 a day after the views of one of his backbenchers were formally condemned by Parliament.

column1: Six people wrongly given 'ultra-low-dose' Pfizer jab, but it could be anyone from group of 66
column2: Queensland Health says it picked up the mistake quickly, but can only narrow it down to six people out of a group of 66, meaning all of those people will need to get another injection.

column1: One third of COVID-19 cases in NSW among children and teens
column2: One in three people infected with COVID-19 in NSW in the past week are 19 or younger as some students prepare to return to school next week.

column1: Hackers pull off cryptocurrency heist, then give back hundreds of millions of dollars' worth
column2: Hackers behind one of the biggest ever cryptocurrency heists have returned more than a third of $832 million in digital coins they stole, according to the company at the centre of the hack.

column1: British man arrested in Germany after allegedly spying for Russia
column2: Germany has arrested a British citizen on suspicion of spying for Russia while working at the UK embassy in Berlin.

column1: Sydney police officers tried to pick up women while on shift
column2: Two Sydney police officers who tried to pick up women while on duty using fake names and what they called a "bat phone" will be sentenced for misconduct after having more serious charges dropped.

column1: NT declares ACT a COVID hotspot
column2: Travellers coming into the Northern Territory from the ACT after 4:30pm central time will be required to enter mandatory supervised quarantine at their own expense.

column1: This restaurateur survived six lockdowns only to have two cafes listed as exposure sites
column2: Cafe owner Bob Barbar has lived through six lockdowns. Now two of his family-run businesses have been listed as exposure sites in Melbourne's latest COVID-19 outbreak, and it is getting all too hard.

column1: Man who allegedly posed as Uber driver charged with sexually assaulting six women in Perth
column2: The owner of a Perth restaurant is behind bars accused of sexually assaulting six women in separate incidents over six years, in what police allege are the actions of "a dangerous sexual predator" who hung around nightclubs to prey on vulnerable women.

column1: Woman pursued by police after allegedly failing to stop at SA border says she was escaping domestic violence
column2: A 33-year-old woman who had been living in Mildura is refused bail after being charged with breaching COVID-19 border directions and a number of traffic offences.

column1: Canberra is going into lockdown, here's what that means for you
column2: Canberra is entering lockdown, here's what you can and can't do for the next seven days.

column1: Super Netball's top four teams are locked in for the semi-finals, but what stands in their way?
column2: The 2021 Super Netball finalists have showed determination to get here, but there are obstacles each team will have to overcome as they head into the knockout stages, writes Brittany Carter.

column1: Julie suffered 60 concussions during her sporting career. Now her brain has been permanently damaged
column2: More girls are playing contact sport than ever before, but researchers say little is known about the long-term effects of concussion in women.

column1: 'We are all suffering': South Australians unsympathetic to Olympians forced to double quarantine
column2: South Australians have hit back at the Australian Olympic Committee saying tough rules that will see athletes having to "double quarantine" are necessary to protect the community — and it was up to the committee to protect its athletes. Olympian Bel White said while it was a "hard pill to swallow" she understood why authorities had maintained their stance.

column1: 'Excited' Wallabies ready for second crack at storming Eden Park fortress
column2: The Rugby Championship kicks off with the second of back-to-back matches at Eden Park with the "excited" Wallabies ready to have another crack at breaking the All Blacks' 35-year stranglehold at the venue.

column1: 'I don't think we'll ever find him': Authorities still baffled over High Country disappearance
column2: A former police officer has told a coronial inquest that he believes a lapsed Scientologist who disappeared on Mount Buller will never be found.

column1: Women in WA become last in Australia to be protected from intimidation when seeking abortion
column2: Protesting outside abortion clinics will no longer be allowed in any Australian jurisdiction, following laws to introduce safe access zones in Western Australia passing State Parliament.

column1: Sydney's COVID-19 lockdown is changing in some areas — this is what you need to know
column2: Stricter COVID lockdown conditions are extended to three more Greater Sydney local government areas after infections continue to leak in from the city's south-west.

column1: What we know about the two cases who flew from Sydney to Melbourne
column2: Authorities say two women who flew from Sydney to Melbourne on Monday afternoon will be fined, and everyone on board the flight has been put into quarantine.

column1: Here are the ACT exposure sites visited by Canberra's COVID-19 case
column2: Here's the list of exposure sites recorded in Canberra after the territory discovered its first local COVID-19 case in over a year.

column1: Much-loved Yallingup Beach in South West WA smashed by storms
column2: Locals say they've never seen anything like it as the clean up of their beach begins, but some fear it won't be rebuilt in time for the summer tourist flood.

column1: It's the largest contaminated area in the southern hemisphere. So why are people still travelling there?
column2: Wittenoom in Western Australia's Pilbara is riddled with blue asbestos. Yet despite the serious health risk, people are still visiting the former mining town.

column1: NASA's helicopter spotted the Perseverance Rover on Mars — but will you be able to?
column2: NASA's Perseverance Rover can be seen in an image the Ingenuity helicopter captured while snapping photos of the Red Planet.

column1: 'A message to every female playing footy': AFLW expanding to 18 teams from 2022
column2: The AFLW will feature 18 teams from the 2022-23 season onward, as the AFL Commission grants licences to Essendon, Hawthorn, Port Adelaide and Sydney Swans.

column1: 'Should've blown up the Hawkesbury Bridge': Hunter health official points finger at Sydney as COVID cases climb
column2: Newcastle public health officials say Sydney interlopers caused the Hunter region's deepening COVID crisis as Gladys Berejiklian confirms the region will stay in lockdown for another week.

column1: Sicily's 48.8C scorcher might be Europe's hottest day ever
column2: Regional authorities on the Italian island say the temperature surpasses the all-time record of 48.5C, set in Sicily in 1999, and the 1977 record of 48C in Greece.

column1: Grave fears for vulnerable communities as child listed among new NSW infections
column2: Residents in western NSW are being urged to prepare for the worst, with anger building over the handling of vaccine distribution amid fears COVID-19 is about to tear through vulnerable communities.
column3: Olivia Ralph, Lucy Thackray, and Xanthe Gregory

column1: NSW COVID-19 vaccination rates surge as state battles Delta outbreak
column2: As NSW continues to battle the highly infectious Delta variant, health data shows the number of daily doses has risen 20 per cent this month, with half the state's adult population on track to be fully vaccinated by the end of September.

column1: Thousands of Queensland's 'lockdown legends' released from home quarantine
column2: More than 6,000 "lockdown legends" are released from home quarantine after spending two weeks stuck indoors, as the COVID-19 threat at Brisbane schools is reigned in.

column1: Police slam 'lunacy' of motorists going to extreme length to avoid seatbelts
column2: A growing number of Queensland motorists are going to extreme lengths to avoid wearing a seatbelt designed to save their life, in what authorities describe as "lunacy" that "defies logic".

column1: Coal-fired power pollution a 'toxic time bomb' for nearby homes, expert warns
column2: It has been almost 10 years since Swanbank A power station at Collingwood Park was closed, but a toxic ash dam on the site is yet to be dealt with and environmental experts and nearby residents are worried about the risk.

column1: Crown compensation claim could have no limit and taxpayers are on the hook, royal commission hears
column2: In October, the Royal Commission into the Casino Operator and Licence delivers its findings. But Crown may not be the only one penalised.

column1: Who is set to challenge Manchester City this Premier League season?
column2: The Premier League season 2021/22 kicks off this weekend. Simon Smale takes a look at who could challenge Manchester City for the title, and who is in line for the drop.

column1: Here's where politicians picked commuter car parks to be built — and where they should have gone
column2: The Coalition canvassed its MPs and candidates to decide where to build 47 car parks in Australia. But those car parks don't line up with the country's most congested roads, or its fastest growing areas.

column1: Mental health during lockdowns 'depends on where you live' and better-designed homes could help, study says
column2: New research suggests noisy, dark, and problem-plagued homes lead to significantly increased mental health impacts during lockdown.

column1: Morrison handed business a very hot potato this week
column2: From the start, Scott Morrison has insisted his government would not make taking the vaccine mandatory. And that leaves businesses in a very awkward position, writes Michelle Grattan.

column1: How the ATO could be forced to name and shame overpaid companies that pocketed JobKeeper
column2: Tax commissioner Chris Jordan has rejected a motion in the Senate to out the private companies who have received JobKeeper, saying revealing the names of the companies and individuals behind them would breach their privacy and tax secrecy laws.

column1: 'It was truly shocking': How the arrest of Australian Cheng Lei unfolded a year ago in China
column2: In one of her last Facebook posts before she disappeared, Cheng Lei's thoughts turned to her children in Australia. On the one-year anniversary of her detention, media colleagues are calling for her release.
column3: Bill Birtles, Bang Xiao, and Erin Handley

column1: China's COVID-zero strategy could leave it isolated for years. That may be just the way Beijing wants it
column2: Rising nationalism and potential fears about the efficacy of Chinese vaccines mean Beijing may keep the world's most populated nation locked down for years. But with isolation comes risks.

column1: Travel diary of a 17,000 year old woolly mammoth stored in its tusk
column2: An analysis of a woolly mammoth's 17,000-year-old tusk offers a vivid snapshot of the places the creature visited, from its first of year of life up to until its death at 28 years old.

column1: Pakistan Foreign Minister labels bus crash that killed Chinese workers 'suicide bombing'
column2: Pakistan's Foreign Minister claims India's and Afghanistan's intelligence agencies were behind the attack which they say was carried out by Pakistani Taliban militants.

column1: Some employers want to make COVID vaccination mandatory. Can they?
column2: COVID-19 vaccines are mandatory for aged care workers and most people working on the quarantine front line, but what about everyone else? Can your boss make it mandatory for you to get immunised?

column1: Russian agents arrest hypersonic technology expert on suspicion of treason
column2: The general director of the Hypersonic Systems Research Facility is accused of passing secret information to a foreign citizen about technology research.

column1: 'Fear porn': Nationals senator Matt Canavan attacks scientists who released climate change report on Q+A
column2: Nationals senator Matt Canavan is called out on Q+A for being "part of the problem" when it comes to Australia's climate change policy and raises controversy by refusing to condemn Liberal MP George Christensen's controversial comments on COVID-19 restrictions.

column1: Abbott meeting triggers new trade talks between Australia and India
column2: Trade Minister Dan Tehan reveals in a speech that India's Commerce Minister agrees to resume free trade talks with Australia after they stalled in 2015.

column1: Disgraced former K-pop star Seungri sent to jail and fined $1.3 million in prostitution case
column2: The former member of popular boy band Big Bang denied all nine charges, but a court found his testimony lacked credibility and his offending was serious.

column1: Next chance to host World Cup in 2034, but no bid yet, says Football Australia
column2: FA chief James Johnson says Australia does aspire to host the World Cup at some point, and that 2034 would be the next realistic opening — but he deflects speculation that a bid is in the works.

column1: SA Police clear and clean CBD station after man arrives saying he had been in NSW
column2: The Hindley Street police station in Adelaide's CBD closes for about three hours this afternoon and is thoroughly cleaned after a man turns up stating he had been in NSW within the past 14 days.

column1: Sydney woman believed to have caused Newcastle COVID-19 outbreak allegedly lied to police twice
column2: It is alleged a 21-year-old woman twice defied police orders to return to Sydney before spreading the virus in Newcastle over several days.

column1: Sydney school for students with autism linked to 18 COVID-19 cases
column2: A special needs school in Gladesville in Sydney's north is closed after seven students and three staff members contracted COVID-19.

column1: Storm add to their winning streak against Canberra, as Raiders finish game with 12
column2: The Storm were given a scare before scoring their 18th straight victory — this time over Canberra on the Sunshine Coast — as the Raiders look set to be without Corey Harawira-Naera for a number of weeks after a late send-off.

column1: Apartment buyers 'distressed' after being locked into 'defective' Sydney development
column2: A group of apartment buyers are pleading with the NSW government to help break their contracts after purchasing off-the-plan units in a Western Sydney development where defects were recently discovered.
